Really interesting history. We really enjoyed our visit to Ben Youssef Madrasa. We visited with a tour guide who told us a lot about the history of the school. I would recommend reading up about the history before visiting, or coming with a guide, to get the most out of the visit. Although even if you don't, the building is really beautiful!

A Marrakech Medina "Must-Do". The skill, workmanship and pure artistry seen in this old medersa is astonishing. That it has survived so completely is wonderful to see but it also gives an insight into what must have been a tough life for the students studying the Koran. The dormitory areas upstairs should be visited.
Must see!. This Madrasa used to be the biggest one coranic school in whole Northern Africa. It's just must, if you wanna feel the Arabic climate and beautiful architecture, don't miss ir!

Great Old School-Labyrinth of hallways and dorm rooms. Definitely worth a stop. Easy to finish in 30-60 minutes. Kids enjoyed the winding hallways and hidden dorm rooms. Awesome to see where the students lived!

Fine work but seen too many similar & better works else ware.. Having visited the Madrasa in Fes, this one felt low key. Does have fine mosaic work on walls. Carvings, plaster work done around the windows are great to look at but what stood out for me was the ceiling panels for the illumination, the wood work in these balconies are awesome (refer the pic). Being a popular tourist attraction, its over crowded spoiling the settings. When it was still running there were about 900 students living in the 132 rooms. Those room are bare and small, hard to imagine 6 to 7 students fitting in there, must have felt like a prison. With such places a lot depends on your guide, ours didn't have much to offer, so we were done with the site in under 10 minutes.

Nice way to spend an hour. This is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Marrakech and it's not difficult to see why. The detailing is just extraordinary and worth the money. I came out of there thankful that this is not where I would have lived as the rooms were incredibly basic for the students. Beware of the official guides that want to show you around, you can glean the information from Lonely Planet (or equivalent).

largest Medrasa in all of Morocco needs some love and care. Also listed in the top 10 attractions of Marrakech Ben Youssef was on my list to see. The building itself and details are lovely it's just a shame that it's not taken care of. Walls and tiles are crumbling down and are dirty. It would be nice to take care of it a little bit more. The upstairs terraces look like after bombing. Hope they will give it some love soon.

Typically Moroccan. Doesn't take long to visit but is worth it. The architecture and decor is so what I expected of Moroccan design. An incredible clear pool that you can see the tiles on the bottom through. Lovely.

Beautiful Islamic building with stunning interior decorations. Very peaceful and serene building in the middle of north medina. The dormitories aren't much other than bare rooms but the arrangement of courtyards surrounding central courtyard is interesting and the Islamic tiling and stucco decorations are outstandingly beautiful and a real gem of a find. A bit difficult to find midst the twists and turns of the medina but well worth it. Especially if you like Islamic architecture as you cannot visit inside the mosques in Marrakech unless you are Muslim.Only downside was the guy inside who kept pestering us to take him on as a guide and we had to say no several times but he eventually goes away!
Beautiful.. As ever with Marrakesh we stumbled upon lovely historical places such as this. Architecture is superb. Pleasant place to visit and take in some local history. Make sure you visit.
great architecture. worth a visit great place to see make sure you take your camera get some nice pics you will have to take your shoes of to visit here

A must . Of all the buildings we visited in the 5 days in Marrakech - to me, this was the best. It does not take long to visit and fairly well signed. Lovely arches near the entrance and beautiful, ornate carving throughout the building. Don't miss it.
interesting historical site. A very interesting site in the heart of the old city which is very rich in culture and alot of architecture to appreciate
Great pictures, architecture, and history!!!. BEAUTIFUL cedar, marble, plaster, and mosaics.... We loved exploring here and having a little photo shoot of our family. Would definitely recommend :)
Must see. A great insight into the culture and architecture of Islam a must see place.Definitely worth walking here through the souks whilst soaking up the atmosphere.
Robert. Well worth going to but hard to find might be an idea getting a licensed guide to help took 3 attempts to find great view from restaurant directly acroos from it

Beautiful building. We went with a guide, who was able to explain the history. The architecture is really beautiful. It is small, so will not take long to explore but then it does not cost much to get in.

Beautiful Islamic Achitecture. This former religious school is one of few Islamic buildings open to non Muslims in Marrakech and it is well worth visiting for its beautiful and impressive architecture. There is a central open air courtyard decorated with ornate wood and stone carving. The former prayer hall and upper storeys that used to be dormitory quarters are also open to the public. It is inexpensive to visit, 20 MAD and will be of interest to those who like history, architecture and art.
was good. if you are in marrakech you must to explore this medrassa to know about the reall moroccan culture ,,
Worth a visit - v beautiful. It's a nice building with beautiful artichecture. If you are to visit any historical places in Marrakech, you should try this.
beautiful mosaics. Worth a visit to see the beautiful mosaics and the architectural style. Cool break in the heat of the day.

Impressive. Empty shell of a building left, but beautiful detail In the architecture. Only 20dh worth a visit. Iphine there's also a local man that hangs around offering tours, no idea how good though
Interesting.... It was an interesting place to visit, but it wouldn't make any bucket list of things to do before you die.

Particularly impressive building with an insight to a religion not usually offered. This was an unexpected pleasure - access to a site with so much history and significance. Low entrance fee did not indicate the quality of the visit.The architecture is superb with resplendent archways and colourful tiling.A slow thoughtful walk around the cells will give you some understanding of schooling at the Madrasa.A wonderful example of 16th century Moroccan building.

Great atmosphere. We wandered in here by accident, not design and it is a lovely place to just wander around and dream a bit if you feel so inclined. There are great photos of the place over 100 years ago and so little has changed!

Great Architecture. This is one of the "must see" sights of Marrakech: the building is a delight, the detail superb throughout. The time that must have gone into this decorating building is mind boggling.
Historical and Beautiful. Everyone said it was easy to find but we didn't find anything very easy to find in the Medina. But well worth the visit
it's not a must. if there is time left over, go an visit ... interesting if you like history and architecture and choose a time when there ar not too much tourists.
Interesting. We went up a different way, no idea what way we went but it was interesting as we went through interesting parts of the souks.
Architecture very good. You only need less an hour as its small and most of the areas of a similar design. Upstairs is the sleeping quartets ( as was), but just empty rooms, no furniture.

Worth a look!!. Fully restored the madrasah is rich in detail and is very photogenic. Walking around the various areas gives you a good impression of how the place must have operated back in its time.

Very Beautifull. It is very beautifull, the attention to detail in Morrocan Architecture is fantastic! We spent an hour here just looking around, it is not very big but we were amazed by the details...

outstanding traditional workmanship. The decorative woodwork and tilework here are of a very high quality, not readily seen in other buildings. There are some old photos in the courtyard which show the Madrasa when it was in use. I was not aware that it was possible to visit the students quarters upstairs, something that would be worth seeing.

Impressive. This Madrassa is really impressive. You can actually walk in and explore the building, and get to see how the students lived. The workmanship is beautiful and the architecture, sort of labyrinthical, very interesting. A great example of Islamic architecture. A must see.

Interesting historic site. Very beautiful old building that was a Koranic school until the late 60s. Lots of little nooks an crannies to see and amazing areas to take photographs. I think the place would benefit from more information for example signs that tell you what each room was originally used for. Luckily, we had a guide who was quite knowledgeable, but if he wan't there we would have missed out on a lot if interesting information.
Quaint and charming. a cute building in the middle of the busy souks, extremely hard to find the first time. Bare building, with no firniture etc, but nice to visit, Entry is less than 2 Euros

A beutiful place to spend an hour.. Just a few metres from the Museum, this place has so much history.. The problem is that you even pay for a guide, or you have to sit and work things out for yourself. There's nothing to explain what you are looking at. The decoration is fascinating. The bedrooms upstairs just need you to imagine living here.

Great. Fantastic architecture and a real insight into how the religious scholars lived.
It is a beautiful building with intricate carvings everywhere and a sense of calm right in the middle of the Medina.

Fascinating, beautiful building.. Highly recommend a trip here if you are in Marrakech. Not only is it a stunning piece of Moroccan architecture, it is also fascinating to see how this old Quaranic school would have functioned and to get a real feel for the place,
Simply beautiful. Be sure to see this when visiting Marrakech! The upstairs rooms are especially funny to have a look at.
Low entry fee, nice architecture. Enjoyed our visit, a bargain at 10dhs to enter. My kids enjoyed this place too especially as only a 5 minute walk from our beautiful riad. Recommend.

Really interesting and stunning building. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit. Wish I had read more about it before hand as there isn't much info inside in English, a little more in French but there is lots I wanted to know.
Amazing tiling and carving. Cheap to get in, loads of carving and glazed tiles. The student chambers were a bit repetetive. Also has reasonable toilets!

Beautifully preserved, peaceful setting for a step back in time.. Truly a beautifully maintained example of life in ancient times. The architecture and design work were clearly ahead of their era. If you are seeking a peaceful place away from the hustle and bustle of the souk, this is definitely the place to visit. Historical monument that brings anyone who enters a tranquil moment or two.

Interesting place, maze of nice views. It's interesting just to find this place, through the maze of the souks. It was a little busy but lovely to see such traditional architecture, and worth going up to look through the little windows.
Amazing decoration. This was one of the architectural highlights of our trip, the museum is well preserved and is full of lovely details. Definitely put it on your list.
Beautiful historical site with gorgeous architecture.. We had a guide for our tour here which I recommend. A lovely religious school building, gorgeous architecture. Well worth a visit.
Very intersting Medersa. In the middle of the big Souk you can find this oasis of old arabic architecture. Stunning. Take some time when visiting.

Fascinating and well worth a visit. This is a museum but was once a thriving Madrasa or school. The architecture is wonderful with some of the most intricate and ornate mosaic and tile work in existence. You can self-guide or hire a professional guide as we did. It was well worth it as he explained so much about how the madrasa operated and the meaning of various rooms and features. We were able to see the tiny cells in which the students slept and wander all over. This should not be missed.
Great place. The architecture is truly stunning. I would budget for about a twenty minute visit if you go without a guide.

Important historical site. To imagine that young men came to study here for hundreds of years is daunting. Right now, there is an exhibit of historical photosgraphs of the Madrasa that give it nice context.
Beautiful.. The site is beautiful, but do be prepared for queues! I would recommend arriving early in the day to be able to appreciate every area.
Lovely place, worth a visit. We loved this gorgeous building. The architecture is just amazing and we got some lovely photos here. It's worth a visit.

must see. this historical site is on every must see list. so yeah you have to see it. we went with a guide which i think really helped us appreciate it more. he told us about how the marble used to make the madrasa was obtained by trading sugar with italy. don't forget to look up :-)
Wow!. Loved this place. Was the first place we visited and took so many photos! Perfect place to start our journey into the history of Marrakech.
Amazing historical site. Hidden away in the medina, we stumbled upon this gem. The architecture is mind-blowing, definitely worth the visit if you are in Marrakech!
Beautiful traditional architecture. Very beautiful courtyard, with a simple layout but amazing wall decorations. Centrally located in the medina. Entrance is cheap - we went twice.

Beautiful architecture. Lovely building, beautifully maintained. Well worth a visit. Takes no more than an hour to look around. There are guides withing the museum, should you wish to pay for a tour. We found all the information we required from Google.

See the art of morocco and Islam come alive. Not only has this been the place where Islam was thought for hundreds of years, but it is also a collection of beautiful art and craft inspiring more than religious and spiritual thoughts.

Amazing detail. A religious school of centuries back that has design and artwork unmatched by modern schools. The level of detail that went to create the myriad geometrical patterns and Islamic caligraphy is awe inspiring.

very interesting but really crowded. This is a nice place to visit where you can discover how the students lived unyil 50 years ago.
It was really really crowded, we went there in the morning and there were many groups.
Historic. Interesting building, old college with small dormitories which look like one person bedrooms of today. No furniture or decoration so rather bland. Worth a visit though.

Beautiful architecture and design.. The school is quite small. Great for photography as the design and architecture is beautiful.
I would be good to have a guide with you to know more about the place, or else it is just a building.
:)
Fascinating and very beautiful. Extraordinary example of Arabic carving and decoration most beautiful building. It's well worth a visit.

Good. Good and open space on the ground floor and children loved running here. Like a little maze on the first floor with lots of small rooms. The pattern and the architecture on the walls and tiles was lovely. Entry fees is 20 dirhams for each adult and 8 dirhams for each child. Not bad for the price.

Great place to visit in Marrakech. Great place to visit during the day while you are in Morocco. Wonderful architecture and history. you can spend 20 minutes or 2 hours depending on your level of detail and history you want to learn.

Beautiful Riad - if architecture and art are your thing. Located in the traditional back streets of Marrakesh is Ben youssef madrasa.Used as an old school, a monument to Moroccan architecture and style. Typical and traditional Moroccan influence. My photos show it off best - there's lots of art and you can get a guided tour of you're into your history.A good stopping point to tie in with a trip to the Souk. It will give you a peaceful break from the bartering and hectic atmosphere of the market.
Stunning. A true demonstration of the beauty and art that Islamic cultures have contributed. A must see on any visit to Marrakech.
Beautiful building!. Beautiful building to just wonder around in, worth the 20dh. Not much information regarding it's use but there are tour guides around

Go there! . The entrance fee of 20MAD is a good barging considering the amount of time you could spend here.
It is one of the nicest buildings within the medina and well worth a visit!

Antique koranic school open to the public in an impressive building!. Medersa (Madrasah, koranic school) Ali Ben Youssef with some 130 rooms bears the name of the sultan Ali Ben Youssef Ben Tchefine, the son of the founder of the city. Originally built in the XIV century and rebuilt by the saadies about 1570, is considered one of the most important koranic schools and knowledge dissemination centers in the Maghreb. Now open to the public cultural heritage, it is one of the few places with religious significance authorized for access to non-Muslims. Situated in the Medina, slightly north of the souks, very near the Ben Youssef Mosque and the Marrakesh Museum. The entrance, in a corner of the Ben Youssef square, is through a dark and ugly corridor leading to an impressive patio equipped with a large pool and surrounded by well-crafted columns and white marble floor. The madrasah is a beautiful example of architecture from the saadí period for its harmonious spaces and materials used –colored mosaics (zellij), marble, and intricately carved stucco and wood panels. Must see a "student room" rebuilt, endowed with antique furniture that recreates the atmosphere of meditation and study of this institution. It is worth of devote three hours to this visit or more depending of the number of photos you may wish to take!! Very enjoyable with a group of friends: every one discovers a new corner!
Idea about preaching. Good old building except that there was nothing informative about the decor or the architecture. More can be done at this building structure.
Interesting. Nice little tour of this beautiful building - and completely free of charge. A must do when you need a break from the Souks.
Beautiful and interesting!. Very interesting and fascinating spaces for the students. Beautiful architecture, unfortunately not well preserved and little information on site. Read up ahead of time.
Little bit of history. historic, beautiful and well worth a visit. Very cheap entrance- with alot to explore. GO... you'd be silly not to
A must see in Marrakech. We visited this on our first day and it was a great example of Marrakech architecture. I recommend it
wonderful!. Make sure you include this in your itinerary! There's a photo opportunity every step. Very well preserved and delightful to explore

Absolutely Stunning. If you like history, arts and culture then you need to check it out...See all the different craftsmanship and architecture...all the different prayer rooms...shame its not being well preserved or used for something to enhance its beauty!

‘You who enter my door, may your highest hopes be exceeded’. It has to be one of the must see places in the world. Astonishing! I found it difficult to leave. Stunningly beautiful, great, great history and then the student accommodation gives a sense of plain and hopefully kind devotion (or perhaps duty/discipline (?)) either way it blows the mind. Even now my heart is thumping ...
Beautiful and historic. Fantastic spot to soak in the history of Marrakech. Great place to take photos and see beautiful tile and plaster.

Terrible to find and navigate. The place is not easy to find at all, due to the total lack of decent signage, which Marrakech really needs to improve. But this place costs MAD 20 and is really interesting or could be if they charged MAD 50 and then put the money into a decent multi-lingual guide book, better signage and get the place updated! Come on Marrakech, get updated, you have a lot to offer, but do nothing about it!
fascinating. Really beautiful. So quiet and unique. We had a great time exploring the hidden rooms marveling at the architecture. Also a nice way to take a break from the hectic streets of Marrakech.

Amazing building. The problem for us was finding this place having got hopelessly lost we ended up getting a taxi and then being instructed to follow two french men from the taxi in front of us, which i must admit was quite an adventure in itself. However once we got there it was worth the trouble, exquisitely moorish and so worth the 20 dirhams it cost to enter.

Must see with guide. This was part of our half day Medina tour with a guide arranged by the Riad. Great architecture and intricate workmanship for the structure. Spartan living accomodation for the students of this madrasa during its operational days. Interesting history; great for photos.

Nice architecture and Moroccan culture. Nice place to visit and to immerse in the Moroccan culture. You can find nice local architecture, although one of the busiest places with tourists. Anyway, a must in this city!

You can probably skip it.. I was disappointed by the Madrasa and quite simply it didn't do justice in person to the photos I had seen of it online. There was no water in the reflecting pool and other than the beautiful symmetrical tile work there wasn't much more to it. Inside and upstairs is just empty room after empty room. And the final kicker; for a place that charges entry admission, to have quite simply the most disgusting toilets in the whole of Marrakech, with no toilet seats OR toilet paper, and then have a guard standing at the entry way holding out his hand for a tip before standing aside to let you exit, is utterly reprehensible. He heard exactly what I thought and stepped aside timidly with an empty hand. Don't be bullied by people holding out their hand at toilets in Marrakech.
Beautiful. The madrassa is absoutly beautiful, it could do with a little more general up keep however its well worth a visit. Take your camera as you can get some lovely photos whist visiting.

Open to explore. The Ben Youssef Madrasa was my favorite site I visited while in Marrakesh. The architecture is stunning and intricate, absolutely beautiful. The best part is you are free to wander around on your own, take your time, and enjoy the madrasa as you please. It was interesting going from room to room and imagining what it was like while the madrasa was still in use. This is a must see for your trip to Marrakesh!

Lovely journey to the past!. The school has an authentic essence of Islamic Andalucian architecture.. It's really easy to have a look around without the help of any those that offer guiding.. Basically the place speaks for it self.. In addition to posters with some information here and there
amazing details. It was amazing to walk into this palace. Exquisite yet low-key. Absolutely worth half day time to appreciate the well crafted details.
Beautiful place. An old school with lots of storues to tell Just a breathtaking place , lots of things to see and good place as well for taking pictures .

Fantastic. Not expensive to get in so well with a visit. The architecture was fantastic and it was nice to soak up Moroccan history. Doesn't take long to get around but close to other tourist spots, as well as restaurants, shopping g etc so in a very good location
Impressive detail in the decor/architecture. Hunt this one out... There's brilliant detail in the carving on the walls. It's really interesting and you'll have seen it all in about half an hour.
It needs restoration. Madraza Ben Youssef is an interesting place to see, but the building needs major restoration. It is not well preserved.

Extraordinarily Beautiful.. During our 14 days in Morocco we saw many beautiful, historical places. This was one of our favorites. The interiors are so intricately carved and tiled. It is difficult to take it all in and you have to force yourself to look slowly at one thing and then another. We loved it here. This is one of our favorite examples of Moroccan artistry in architecture and handicrafts. It is a must see when visiting Marrakech!
Nice place to visit. Enjoyed our visit. Very close to where we stayed so visited early one morning. Worth the very low entry fee.

Silent, magnificent and full of religion. Do not miss the opportunity to visit his amazing place. It was a kind of "school" where religious men had gone to study the coran. It was the biggest one in Morocco. Take a look at the carves made by the artisans
semble ok. Its a good place to pop in to if your passing on the way to the museum its also cheap to enter. I don't now if we missed something but it was just a small empty house.

Best thing to see in Marrakech by far. Fascinating Madrasa with loads of history and amazing carvings and architectural features. Entry fee was minimal - be prepared for aggressive man looking after toilets who silently demands money for use of WC facilities. Have a small coin handy!
Really enjoyed seeing this place.

A great place in need of some real attention. This is one of the main attraction museums in Marrakech with some amazing pieces, architecture, rooms. Sadly it is tired, uninformative for anyone who does not speak French! (yawn yawn) pieces are dusty and neglected . A real sadness and missed opportunity to convey a wonderful history and culture!

Really interesting place. Apparently dates back to its origins in the 14th century and was only closed in 1960. The building has character and some very ornate decoration which is mostly well preserved. I would visit again to soak up the atmosphere.
Beautifully evocative. Great location, some artefacts, mystical building. Winding stairs, second level a must see. Plenty to buy and eat in the vicinity

impressive. The arabian architecture can be seen troughout the city, but in this place it becomes clear, how beautiful arabian archicture is, the tiles give a beautiful backdrop for pictures, the little study rooms and big yards are a must see. It is hard to find, look for the next mosque close by and then ask somebody for the way, everyone will help.

Nice with a guide. The tilework here is beautiful as are the wood and plaster work. Without a guide there is no explanation of anything though so it loses something in the viewing. We had a guide and even so it was only somewhat interesting. My daughter asked some insightful questions and was ignored by the guide until my husband forced the issue.
A Popular Visit. Give yourself time to find this attraction as again it is in the Old Medina. It gives you an idea of what form of architecture is considered the norm in this part of the world.

Great building, no information, a guide is needed. The building is unassuming for the outside, it pretty cheap to get in and looks great on the inside with lots of detailed tiling and wood caving decoration. There isn't any information in English, so hire a guide or you'll probably only need 30 mins to look around the place.
Fascinating. We found it by ourselves (quite a feat!) and it was totally worth the search. Fascinating and beautiful but I would have liked more information. Better with a guide perhaps.

Just love the place!. A great place to take great pictures. As hobby photographer I really enjoyed my time there. An old historical school available for just a small entrance fee. A bit difficult to get there but it is worth it.
Nice place. The construction and the art work is nice to look at. There are some great photo spots. The courtyard is also nice.
Another beautiful historical building. A beautiful example of Andalusian art/architecture. Very atmospheric, loved walking around and taking pictures. Entrance is 20dh each. A must see in Marrakech.

Fantastic Architecture. The madrasa offers a look at a really amazing and beautiful architecture. It is based on the Riad styles but offers amazing mosaic tiles with continuous writings in Arabic all around as well as some verses of the Quran carved on the walls. The wooden panels at the top are astonishingly in good shape for such an old building. It is definitely worth a visit, the kids loved it too.

Fascinating and interesting. We would never have found this without our guide. An extremely interesting building with amazing workmanship. The rooms upstairs are so small considering they slept more than 1 student at a time.

Interesting, lovely carved wood work. A peaceful place to visit with a lovely architecture, specially the carvings and tiles. The rooms are very well preserved and it's easy to imagine the madrasa full of students retired in their cells studying the Quran.

The Quran school - I really enjoyed this one. We visited this on a general tour of Marrakech and I much preferred this to the museum nearby. The intricate work here is wonderful and we took lots of photos. You probably need to allocate an hour or so to this place.

Nice place and atchitecture. This place is within Medina and i don't see any reason to visit with tour guide. You can just walk to thia place. During our visit, we actually had a taxi (nice drive) and made a deal for 3 hours. He took us 3-4 places in Merrakech, and a very lunch at his recommendations.

Step back in time to a 12th century college. We stumbled across the Madrasa whilst randomly walking through Marrkech and found it to be a lovely diversion from the street scene outside. It could possible do with a little more explanation about what some of the rooms were used for (compared to what you might otherwise get in Europe), but it was presented and worth a visit
Absolutely stunning. The architecture and artistic design in this historic building are absolutely stunning. Well worth a visit.
Back in time.. Once a Quranic school....it gives a good insight into the teachings....also if like me, you are into Islamic Architecture then there is a lot to take in.

A "must" see while in Marrakech. Interesting visit, one of the highlights while in Marrakech. Both the architecture and history/culture around this place, makes it a "must see" if you are in Marrakech. Important to find a guide tonexplain the place or have some background reading.

A fasciniating glipse at the past. A simple but attractive building which still resonates with the history it witnessed. A place to think about the young boys who were sent to receive a religious education and who probably experienced some hardship being separated from the families and subject to fairly strict discipline.

Interesting attraction, not much to do other than walk about.. For some reason some guys hang out outside the entrance to the Madrasa, which can make you not notice the entrance or reluctant on entering. They can't follow you inside and it's worth looking at it. Entrance is not free but affordable.Inside, there's not much to do, and not much displayed. You basically just walk about the rooms and corridor. Could be more interesting if there's a guide.I think it would be nicer if they filled a room or two with furniture of what it might have looked like when the Madrasa was operational. Or describe what each room was for. Either your guide can paint a picture for you, or you just guess on your own.
Very interesting, religiously historic. It's about an ancient Quran school where students used to stay, learn with court yard and prayer hall. Very nice.

Scholastic Exquisite. This Madrassa was built in the 12C and is beautiful. The architecture and decoration is typical of the period but has stood the tests of time. Upstairs are tiny cellular rooms that are not dissimilar tithe cells found in Catholic seminary schools found in England up until the mid 1980's! Really worth a visit.
History and architecture buffs will love. Set within the old city, you find this old university with its small dorm rooms beautiful carvings and lovely tiles.

Only way to see the inside of a mosque. We were taken here by our guide to be able to see what a mosque in Morocco looks like since all mosques in marrakesh are closed to nonmuslims. The architecture is truly stunning. I would budget for about a twenty minute visit if you go without a guide.
nice way to spend an hour. quite easy to find out of the souks - nice to look round for an hour or so. architect is amazing and the size is impressive.

Would have liked to learn more. We visited this Medersa (Madrassa) as part of the Thomson 'Magical Marrakech' tour. Unfortunately we only had twenty minutes or so, and our guide wasn't that useful - apart from telling us that the school had opened in the 12th Century, and pointing out the obvious (like the washing area and the Mosque itself) he passed on very little information. This was down to our guide on the day though, not a failing of the Medersa. Left feeling very disappointed at how superficial this visit was, and wished we could have stayed longer.
Simply beautiful!. What a special place to visit! It's a beautiful building and you can sense the history everywhere. Loved the courtyard with the gorgeous tiles. Well worth a visit!

Simply gorgeous. Such a pretty place, even though i'm moroccan i was stunned looking at the architecture of the place and the huge effort put in details. Ii was really beautiful the colors used for decoration and the writing of Quran on the walls just magnificent and really pleasant to look at. I would definitely visit the madrasa again whenever i get the chance to.
A great visit. Amazing architecture, and lots of history. Wonderful place to take photographs, lot of interesting tile work and detail. Don't miss this gorgeous site.
Great Mosque. Beautiful, calm mosque. Walking through was so interesting. Would visit here again if given the opportunity.
Beautiful architecture. definitely worth a visit. The location is right next to Marrakech museum. Also near the photo museum. You could see them at one shot.
Interesting old school !. Enjoyed walking around the school building. Lots of rooms on the upper floor. Nice view from the top of the court yard.

Impressive architecture. The architecture is impressive. Admission is pretty cheap. I almost gave up visiting because I lost my way in the souks. They can be confusing. But grab your map and soldier on :)
Spectacular! . A must see of Marrakech. Absolutely in love with this place. Is 20MAD and its worth it! Is a small place, you can go upstairs and have a nice view of the Madrasa

Unmissable ! +++. The most beautiful place in Marrakech to visit ! If you miss it while you visit the city, you'll miss the treasures of the Arabic architecture and decoration.. It's magnificent and so cheap to visit (only 200 dirhams, 2€)
A gem. Hard to find (be wary of people who want to show you the way) but once inside you will marvel at the gorgeous architecture.

Interesting place to spend a little time.... I visited this place as part of a private tour. There is a small entrance fee to get in. It is basically just an empty building but there is some nice architecture. There are steps and the stairways are narrow so make sure you can go up and down dimly lit stairs.
Must visit. nice place to spent few hours. I went with family. Me and My wife enjoyed with Islamic history, not sure if children liked.
Nice courtyard , no English . Nice place to see with lots of details in the courtyard. However , the museum was all in French , hard for the English speaking!!!
Interesting and artistic building. I enjoyed the visit to this place. The architecture is breathtaking. I also went to the museum, however the Madrasa is enough.
Intersting photo opportunity. This old building is great to walk through with your camera. Nice light aspects and views through windows and doors.

A great start on our walking our of the Medina. This ancient school is where priests came for centuries to study the Koran, and the building, the architecture and design are incredible. We learnt about the construction methodology, and even some Arabic so we could understand the writing in the walls.

very interesting building. Great place to look around and gives a rest from the souks. Lots to see and the building itself has a great history. You can for a small fee get a guide who will tell all in a very interesting way.

Beautiful architecture!. Tricky to find in the maze of Marrakech's Medina district, but allow patience and time and you'll get there! Beautiful architecture and fun to be able to explore at your own pace.
Great. Enjoyed my visit to this Marrakech landmark. The intricate tilework and plaster work is amazing. My wonderful riad was 5 minutes walk away which was a big bonus.

Interesting and beautiful. I enjoyed visiting the Madrasa not only for its interesting and beautiful architecture, but also for what insight it gave me into the culture and history of Morocco. I believe entry was very cheap--ten or twenty dirhams--as well.

it's cheap but you get what you pay for, which is not much. It's hard to beat $2 USD entrance fee but they didn't not put a single sign telling you anything about the place. If you don't have a guidebook and want to know more, you have to employ a service a guide, who stands around near the entrance. Not sure how much it'd cost. It takes 15-20 minutes to walk around and admire the architecture and artwork. That's about it. If you're nearby in the Medina, be sure to visit it. If not, don't worry about it. You won't miss much.

More than just the beautiful architecture. I had a day and a half in Marrakesh, and according to Travel Adviser this was a site not to miss. As usual, it was right. I love the architecture of holy places and have visited mosques and places of a spiritual nature in all the Muslim countries that I have visited. This Madrasa is a jewel ... assuming you can find it because it's buried in the principal Medina souk. I went with a personal guide who knew exactly where to go. For whatever reason (it is the onset of winter in Morocco and cold), there were not the hoards of visitors reported by other commentators here.So, yes, the subtle colors, the complex designs, the various materials used (wood, marble, etc.) all combined to make this just a very special place and one that I'll never forget. But it is also more than that. It is centuries old. It was (and is no longer) a place of Islamic learning and you get a sense of what it would have been like a half a millennia ago. But more than the architecture and it's role as a place of learning, is the feeling of calm and what might be termed spirituality. See (or feel) for yourself.
Beautiful Madrasa. Beautiful Madrasa, well worth a visit. Also the Souk nearest the Madrasa has some of the best shopping in the Medina.
Nice to go around. Interesting building, nice to see the way the "schools" were around there, you won't need a long time there as all the rooms look quite the same.

Wonderful atmosphere and amazing architecture. An oasis of cool and calm on the edge of the medina. Wonderful architecture and some amazing carvings. Takes a little finding if you approach on foot through the maze of alleys in the old city but its worth an hour of your time.

Rich architectural detail. A centuries-old place of Koranic learning, the Medersa Ali ben Yousseff is also beautifully decorated. Explore not only the common rooms downstairs, but also the much more spartan students' quarters. Unfortunately, with a steady flow of visitors, it's not easy to contemplate and visualise what life for students was like in those days. Even harder to try imaging a soundscape of recital and chanting. Nevertheless, a must-see in Marrakech.
Average. We learnt more about this old School by reading up on it afterwards. There were hundreds of people there so if you want people free photos it is very difficult.

Travelling back in time. It was really impressive being in Madrassa Ben Youssef...The architecture, the history, and every detail of the intricate decor, geometrical patterns and inscriptions have a reason for it. It was fascinating to learn about that place, and what it represented. Our guide was so knowledgeable, it really felt like we were back in the 14th century.

Great example of Islamic geometry and architecture. This place is truly beautiful, highly recommend you visit this magnificent building. Very intricate place.A strange thing I found is despite paying for a ticket, you have to pay to use the toilets.
Amazing.. A must see. Absolutely beautiful. Have a guide take you so you know the details and history. The grounds are well maintained.

beautiful place to relax and ponder..... found this place almost by mistake...!but what a beauty.. the place has tranquil feel about it, the mosaic is beautifully laid, definitely worth a visit when you're in marrakesh, take advantage of the picture opportunity by getting a friend to go upstairs and take a pic of yourself while you're downstairs. has a lot of history, i am told it's around 500yr old, the building has stood the test of time...
Beautiful, not too big, nice respite from the heat.. Stunning architecture, detail and courtyards. You may only need 30 mins or so to get good photos. Lots of identical corridors.

Beautiful Building. If it is the first time you have seen this type of building then you will be incredibly impressed by the ornate carvings and very intricate detailing of the mosaic. The Madrassa is a visual feast, however like most tourist attractions in Morocco, if you don't have a guide to talk you through what you are looking at, it won't be more than a few minutes of looking at something pretty, as they do not have plaques explaining what the buildings or rooms were or anything explaining about what you are looking at. You will also constantly be hounded wherever you walk but people telling you that the buildings are closed, there's nothing down where you are walking and to go to their shop.

Busy, but beautiful. The Ben Youssef Madrasa is a popular site in the most visited city in Morocco, so while it's certainly a lovely spot to escape the hubbub of the medina, don't expect to find solitude. It's well known and anyone will be able to direct you to the right spot should you get lost. The courtyard is spacious and bright. The details in the cedar carvings, stucco, and tile work are impressive. Spend some time walking around the second level and you can imagine students in the classrooms and dorms from centuries ago. Any of the small rooms provide a lovely vantage point of the central courtyard. If you're there at the right time, you can hear the call of the muezzin. It's easy to just walk around take some pictures, and that would be a fine - a walk around would take 15-20 min. But if you stay and settle in a bit and put away the camera phone, you'd get to appreciate the space. I sat down in a little room under the sun and read The Alchemist, and it was lovely.
Lovely building. Great building in the centre of the medina, so somewhat hard to locate, but well worth the effort. Check opening times as it seems to be often closed.

Well worth the visit. A fascinating building hidden in the maze of lanes in the old town. It is easy to walk straight by the small entrance door to the former Islamic school without noticing it, but the locals who stop you to direct you in really are being helpful - after a dis-orientating wander around the souks, it is easy to imagine that everyone wants to sell you something or be your guide but Marrakech can always surprise you and many people genuinely do just like to welcome visitors! It is an impressive building. Thousands of beautiful tiles, arches, narrow staircases and what seemed like hundreds of tiny 'cells' (the students' study-bedrooms) arranged geometrically around each corridor. There are toilets in the original bathroom area which are interesting whether you need the facilities or not.

Worth a visit if you are in Marrkech, Morocco. If you enjoy looking at different architecture and getting a feel for how other cultures have developed over the years then this place is worth a visit if you are in Marrakech, Morocco.

WONDERFUL BUILDING. We found the Madrassa quite difficult to find as one has to negotiate numerous souks before finding it However, we thought that it was the most beautiful and interesting building we visited during our weeks stay It is difficult to comprehend that the building was begun in the 14th century.The carvings and mosaic tiles depicting flowers and leaves are breath- takings contrasting with the very austere rooms on the second floor used by the numerous students.
interesting. interesting madressah, beautiful as well, good to see how people live and study the Quran, the architecture is great

Fabulous...takes you back hundreds of years. This must be one of Morocco's top attractions and it is easy to see why. Beautifully restored, the vast building gives you a real sense of what it was like as a school with its living quarters for hundreds and it's gorgeous halls and courtyards. As ever, the detailed carvings and workmanship are magnificent.It is very popular, but so large that it does not feel crowded.It is very easy to walk here from the centre of the medina

Not easy to find, but worth the effort. My experience was that it was not easy to find this place - almost gave up trying to find it, and then stumbled across it purely by luck. Really glad it went, and would recommend it!!
Interesting place. Visit Ben Youssef whist on holiday here. Interesting place, not used as a school any more,a little bit like a museum. Take the tour the guide explains it all very well.

Big Madrasa in Marrakech. While not being allowed in Mosques because we were not muslims, we were able to go into this Madrasa. It has the same beautiful geometric patterns and art you would get in a Mosque, but this was an old dorm for students studying the Qu'ran. Upstairs you can go into the old rooms and see how simple they were and downstairs is the huge open room.

An old Islamic school in the hearth of the medina. Its architecture is charming and very different from any school you could find in Europe.Very well maintained. Definitely one of the most interesting places I visited in Marrakesh!

Nice architecture but not a lot to see. You pay 20DH to enter. It is mostly an empty building with lots of little rooms on different levels. You can just walk around and have a look. Did not find it that interesting but did not regret having a look.

Beautiful architecture!. Difficult to find! After going through many small paths through the souk and getting lost, the easiest thing to do was to walk all the way around the souk, and then eventually I found a path that led to this place. The entrance fee is a bit high, but if there is one museum to visit in Marrakech, it's this one. It would be advisable to rent a guide, otherwise it's just walls and marble, as there is no description anywhere. Check the following pictures for a glimpse of what's inside!
Peace and quiet . Amazing place with lots of history. It is the perfect place to start the day in the Medina. LOVE IT AND ADVISE YOU TO GO

surprising architecture. Walked by chance into this amazing , architectural , beautifull building, not realising that such a significant building would exist within the rather poor and dusty shouk area, this means that it is absolutely worthwile to explore outside the well known paths.
Culture. This is a very interesting place, we were lucky enough to have a guide who explained the history and what it had been used for. The architecture is lovely.

Who knew that a Koranic school would be so interesting?. We weren't going to visit this attraction simply because we didn't realize how beautiful it was inside. The tile, the carving, the woodwork...all is amazing and relatively well kept.It is also interesting to imagine 800+ students here. In the heyday, it was the best school on offer.Just beautiful and definitely worth a stop and see.

Beautiful . This is tucked away in the middle of shops and workshops, close to a square where the leather is tanned. The madrassa is stunning, the architecture and intricate designs are beautiful. While you don't need a tour guide, if you decide on one wait until you are inside and use an official guide as I overheard some wildly incorrect info being given by a street guide. However there is generally and air of calm and no hassle inside, it's very peaceful and you can really let your guard down, lovely.
Beautiful place. I came here not really knowing much about the place......... I learnt that it is beautiful!Amazing architecture and great photo opportunities await you.

Just beautiful. A must see in Marrakech, such a beautiful sight, and you leave wondering how you can have tiles like those incorporated into your own home! Definitely not like any schools I've been to. Go early in the morning to miss the hoardes of tourists

Awesome place!. Deter getting lost we finally found it, it was $2 or 20DHM to enter. The architecture is amazing, it is so detailed, you can spend the whole day inside staring at every single detail. A must if you're in Marrackech.

Great architecture and tile work . Really great architecture and tile work. It needs better maintenance but it's really great wood and stone carving. It's a bit hectic getting there and avoid street guides that try to rob you.

favorite spot in marrakech. i really didn't know much about this place before i went but it ended up being one of the highlights of my marrakech trip. it's an old islamic school that's shut down and they let you have full run of the place. it was so cool to see all the tiny rooms and skinny hallways. definitely put this into your must sees.

Impressive and tranquil. Seriously impressive architecture, very grand and every aspect is a kodak moment. Beautiful plaster and wood carvings, full of historical importance and holds a certain reverence. I'm not religious AT ALL but I felt quite peaceful inside. Worth checking it out on your Medina sightseeing.

Interesting and tranquil. Good place to visit on a hot day. The building is calm and cool and is an excellent example of Islamic architecture. Don't expect any explanations of what you are looking at. There is no information available unless you pay one of the many pushy local guides for a private tour.

Interesting Site. It is very interesting site, and you can easily access it if you are visiting the Souk. The entrance is inexpensive. It great for pics. It can take you anywhere from 30 mins to an hour, or more, depends how much time you would like to spend there. If possibly, hire a local guide.
Inspiring. This is a must see in Marrakech. The architecture is beautiful and so old I found it inspiring and the atmosphere is very calm.
Worth a visit. Worth a visit and cheap to get in. Kids go free. Lots of running around in to the old rooms. My son enjoyed the visit as well.

A Step Back over 100 Years. This Mosque is not to be missed. It is a Madrasa, which means that it was a school as well as a mosque, and young people came to worship and to study. They lived in small dormitories as well (all of which you can see) When bigger Universities were founded, these Madrasa's outlasted their need and became in most cases museums. The tiled interiors are beautiful as well as the carefully laid out fountains and areas for prayer. It is said that this Madrasa in particular spread the "true word of the Koran" which of course means a very peaceful moderate view and study of Islam. I could feel the peace in this Mosque.

An enchanting island of calm in amongst the frenzy of the souk.. This was originally a boarding school for students of the Koran. What remains today is an area of beautifully proportioned arches, carvings and tiles. I really enjoyed my visit.
a must see. The architecture and feeling of grandeur of the building is stunning, seeing the rooms some of the students stayed in was an eye opener

An immense piece of architecture . The then-university building, preserved nicely, leaves us stunned. Such a marvellous institution. The student rooms are small but one for one student. Education is valued high in Andalusia, we understand, seeing this building.
Ancient seat of learning. Very interesting to see the accommodation arrangements for the former students and the many intricate geometric decorative designs in the halls
Great visit. Visited this attraction and was really pleased we did. The mosaic was amazing and very decorative. A small entry charge but well worth it.
beautiful building. well worth a visit shame that some artwork on display ( including a beautiful painting ) was open to the elements and had received a contribution from a pigeon !
Stunning. Beautiful architecture and carving.A shame this place is no longer functioning as a madrassa. A great place to take pictures.

A bit of Tardis. The Madrasa is a far larger complex than it appears from outside and is a peaceful contrast to the hustle and bustle of the souk from which you step inside, similarly the architecture is on a different scale to the small stalls and workshops all around it. Well worth seeing, and as with so many sites in Morocco the entrance fee is really little more than nominal.

One of the finest buildings in Marrakesh. This justifiably popular site is well worth a visit. In the main courtyard the mosaics, ceilings, stucco and wood carvings are absolutely stunning. It is also well worth spending time exploring the scholars living quarters on each side of the building - each section is like a mini riads, built around a small central courtyard. An absolute must do when you are in Marrakesh.
Worth a visit. We enjoyed our visit to this historical building of interesting architecture. It was pleasant to be able to wander around at leisure especially upstairs.

Architecturaly Stunning. What a beautiful building...Moroccan architecture is quite stunning...its so ornate no surface is left untouched whether its carved stone or wood and the colourful tiles are so bright and all so uniformed. We spent a lovely few hours there and taking lots of photos and would recommend you visit this lovely historical building.
Beautiful. Definitely worth a look, peaceful break from the souks! 20dh to enter, loved the carvings and tiles.
Beautiful traditional architecture and craftsmanshop. Gorgeous tile work; amazing central courtyard; tons of history. Small entrance fee, but very worthwhile. Beautiful.
interesting to see that kind of school. really nice, do not miss, you'll envy to these students who were learning here long ago. And of course the main hall is like from eastern fairy-tales.
Nice Place . Historical building. Its in the middle of the markets. It's nice for someone how likes to explore about historical attractions.

Place of tranquility surrownded by beautifull architecture. Place of islamic boys around the 14th century, beautiful carvings and marble courtyard. Hard to find but well worth the visit, visit the ben youssef museum next door
Short break . This was a very beautiful building the architecture was incredible and really enjoyed going around and viewing it...we spent a lovely morning there.
Glimpse of Morrocan rich & poor. You need to like your history or architecture or I would suggest this is not for you. Worth an hour or so.

Amazing architecture. Quintessentially Morocco! Glazed tiles and a pool with arches and detailed carved plasterwork. Well worth a visit and worth staying nearby too in the heart of the old city as I did!

Worth Finding. This was probably one of the most fantastic sites we visited in Marrakech. It's tricky to find, but well worth it. The architectural features are still intact, and the history of the structure is fascinating.

Gives a nice flavour of Morrocan architecture. Gives a nice flavour of Morrocan architecture in a quiet, serene place. Its not a museum, so not exhibits, but a nice place to see the intricate architectural detail up close.

It's ok. So after reading several reviews i decide to go ahead and visit this place since its just 8mins away from my hotel.You have to pay 40MAD each which i personally do not think it was worth it.They said it is like "Oxford/Cambridge" historical richness.Mate, i beg to differ. The scholar seems to be completely abandonand run down. Best to book a guide to give you a full explanation and historical facts.In my opinion its not worth it.

Good price 20Dhs each! a must visit. Really interesting, shame there wasn't any information about the place. You can hire a tour guide to take you around but there are a few rouge guides about so make sure they have a lanyard on them. It's effectively lots of rooms in rooms. I believe it was an old school so would have been nice to see how it would have been set out. The building itself is a bit run down and odds and sods have been put into old cupboards. However the architecture is pretty cool, as are all the tiles. The toilets aren't very nice either, like a few public places- take your own paper. (Takes about an hour to get round. Longer if with a guide)
A must see. Amazing tiles, stone and timber carving. Big contrast between the public rooms and the private students' sleeping quarters.

Nothing Special. Was taken to this Madrasa, which is no longer in use, for its intended purpose. There are a few ornate touches, but nothing special. Overrun with Tour groups. There are certainly better examples of architecture.

Marvellous delight. This Madrasa was one of the highlights of all the places I went to in Marrakech. I got in early as where I staying was on the same side of town and it was an interesting walk to it outside the Medina. The Madrasa like most attractions in Marrakech has little background available freely on the walls as the guides need work I guess but plaques would have detracted from the beautiful decorative and intricate features here. It was a marvellous delight and the carvings, tiles and stone work are wonderful and kept me captivated in contemplation while I was there - they are awesome. You can wander round some of the cells which have received little restorative work and adds to their appeal as it helps you imagine what it must have been like for the students. It got busy after a couple of hours as more people arrived but it was ok (unlike the impact of crowds at the Jardin Majorelle). I would highly recommend this jewel of a building for a visit if you want to get up close to some fascinating Islamic decorative art.

500 year old University!. Situated in the heart of the Souk, this building was once one of the most respected seats of learning in perhaps the entire civilised world. While it concentrated on Koranic studies it was also at the leading edge of many other other specialisations.The mosaics are spectacular (all hand cut) but perhaps not to the same standard as it's fellow seat of learning in Fez.The cedar wooden ceilings and other carved doors have stood the test of time and display an insight into the skills of the craftsman who built this so long ago.Take the time to climb up to the upper floors for views into the courtyard and see the very small student rooms.The lectures were principally held at the nearby mosque.
Exceptional architecture in central Medina. Great place to visit. Very reasonabal for 20dh pp, quite retreat from the busy shopping of the narrow Medina streets.
Stunning example of 'hidden' architecture. beautiful and quiet, almost serene for marrakech! You can really imagine the scholars living and studying here. Amazing wood carving and geometric tiles.

Peace and quiet in the heart of the souk. I visited the Medersa twice. The first time was 10 years ago, the second time more recent when visiting Marrakech. Both times, I loved the old Koran School. It's so quiet inside, with lot's of space to wander around and look through all the tiny windows looking over the courtyard. We also loved the pretty little tiles. Definitely one of the highlights of Marrakech!

Beautifull place..... Go, you have to go. Don´t expect to much, just feel the timeless art...Escape from the guides, you can do yourself with a little help from google. But, pay attention: google maps is not always right in Marrakesh.
Decorative. Came across this by chance and wow an amazing old building with incredible décor all carved by hand, now not used by so worth a visit!

Architecture and the feeling how people lived in the past. The architecture and details of this house are great. I think this is the reason why you go there, and it is easy to reach, so is a real 'must see' if you're in Marrakesh.But besides the above you feel real history, you can nearly still see people living and studying in this former school.

Hard life in a beautiful place. Of course there is the rich architecture, ornaments and reliefs, but what really makes impression are the students accomodations, this was no comfortable dormitory - the students had it really hard, go there and see for yourself. Very much worth visiting

Interesting look into the past.. An interesting look into the past I understand this was a koranic school in the middle ages We were told from ages 8 to 13 where children learnt the very complex Koran.Superb carvings and design features that must have taken years to finish.So lovely with the shadows from the sun bouncing patterns on the walls, would make fantastic photographic opportunities.Only 20Dm entry fee. A must to visit
A hidden gem. This place is amazing so beautiful and you dont want to leave good staffCheap entry well worth itDo not miss this while in marrakech a true hidden gem

Nice place. This is a great venue to escape all the shop keepers and see the reason why Marrakesh was considered a center of learning.. As a religious school in distance past, this was a place for not only spiritual teachings, but also of mathematics and astronomy. Beautifully preserved and well worth the time.
Amazing space. A unique building. Lovely unique tile work is very enigmatic. Very low entry fee too. Make sure you visit this part of Marrakech.
Excellent . Beautiful place to visit when in Marrakech very close to riad I was staying at. Definitely have to visit when visiting Marrakech.
amazing place. went with an organised tour around Marrakesh and glad we did or we would never have found this place.steeped in history and the architecture of the place is stunning.

Interesting Islamic Architecture and designs. This was part of our excursion. It seems all the tours stop here. It is very crowded. A madrasa is a school. This one had many small rooms with a courtyard. There is a lot of carved wood and Islamic tile designs. It was interesting to visit.
A must when visiting Marrakech. This was pointed out to us, but we didn't find it that interesting. Walking the Souks and streets of the Medina was much more fun!

Ok but a bit samey. We came here on recommendation of our guide book. It was quite interesting although full of big tour groups. There are loads of different rooms but they were essentially all empty and looked the same. Nothing special but interesting history.
Best Islamic designs since the Alhambra. Spent an hour here admiring the geometric patterns, the architecture, the layout and history. Nice and cool and calm and not overrun

Intricate carvings and woodwork well worth seeing. If you're in the Marrakech souks towards the north end you should definitely visit here. In fact go here anyway. It takes between 30 and 60 minutes to walk around. You'll see intricate detailed stone and wood carvings and even more fascinating the "cells" that the 900 students of the Madrasa lived in. Only cost 10 MAD to visit!

A tranquil oasis. was taken here by my guide and it was delightful. It offered coolness in the mid day heat and the architecture was stunning. Carved cedar wood, intricate tiling and exquisite plasterwork are worthy of admiration.

Great to see. This is quite a fascinating building. It's really quite lovely in fact. The architecture is spectacular and it's very reasonably priced to get in. Make sure you go upstairs, look through the doors, through the windows and really enjoy the different parts of the complex. There's quite a cool little bit that you can stand in and sound is reflected all around you.
Worth half an hour visit. Not too crowded easy to get a sense of the place no English guide so look up prior to visit. Do go up stairs to get a different view but the dormitories are very similar

Same as all other Marocco madrases, good to see. It is good, but not better than Fes Madrasa, or any other Madrasses. Of course, if it was only one city you visit in Morocco - it worth to visit. It is very difficult to get there, especially with car, sometimes we need to fold back mirrors to drive over narrow streets. Local people propose their help, but charge money for this. Man who was guiding us to there asked first 200 euros, then 200 dirhams per person, and he was very disappointed, when he got normal tips.

Beautiful. I love this place, it is one of the best examples of Islamic architecture in Marrakech. It is well worth a visit and is just around the corner from the far less worth while Marrakech museum!
Impressive architeture. For the ones who are used to european architeture, this will be a big shock. There are lots of details everywhere with different forms and shapes, it is worth the visit.

One of the most beautiful places in the city. The major medersa of Morocco, is one of the most well preserved monuments of Marrakech. The architecture is outstanding, and the price is perfectly reasonable. Don't forget to visit
Beautiful architecture, impressive history. If you visit Marrakech, you have to make a break and visit this place. Architecture is beautiful and entry fee is only 10 MAD.

A definite must . If you're in Marrakesh, you owe it to yourself to see this great and historic Madressa. The Architecture is beautiful and while not very well maintained, shows the intricacy of the Moroccan culture. It is located deep within the Souq and a bit hard to find, but worth a visit.
Beautiful. Don't forget your camera! It's a beautiful building and you can easily welk around and make pictures. A must see

Another hidden gem. Fascinating place.Handicraft in the central courtyard is impressive but the student rooms give you the clearest sense of the place.Don't pass by the wooden poles in the bedroom corners without thinking about their purpose and make sure you visit the WCs

Beautiful. Away from the souks madness hides this little gem but not so little. 20 dhm to get inside and it's well worth the price. The architecture and the geometric designs are breath taking. The Madrasa is not one to be missed. Beautiful.

Amazing carving on wall. Inside d medina, not so easy to find; if u r facing " hotel restaurant de la france", then head towards your left hand side area, ask d shopkeeper along d way; no point taking taxi, they wil charge 50 dirhamEntrance fee is 20 dirham, very reasonableUsed to be largest theological college in north africa once housed 900 studentsAmazing n breathtaking carving on d wall n windowsThe motifs are mainly geometric patterns, as per requirement of islam, no human or animal on decorationA must place to visit!

Beautiful and Interesting. The building which used to house students studying religion. Stunning architecture and carvings and fascinating to see the student apartments (cells!) and the annexe where the lecturers sat. Definitely worth its entrance fee.
Unique. cost 20 dhs to get in. The layout was confusing. I got lost at some point while going around it even though it is just a small area.
Amazing local landmark. A must see to learn more of Morocco and islamic culture. Amazing place, and really really interesting

Mindbogglingly beautiful carvings and restoration. Well worth waiting for the groups of tourists to leave, and get the 'perfect shot' and experience of this magical place. The college has been restored sensitively, and it retains some of the air of learning and majesty of the builders and students. Exquisite carving and woodwork.

A MUST SEE IN MARRAKECH. This is a 'Must See' in Marrakech. There are no signs in English or any language that I could see so read up on it before you go. Beautiful architecture & a nice peaceful hour in the midst of the madness of the Medina

Taste the history. This beautiful Quran-school is a beautiful way to escape the crowded souks. The interior is really authentic and gives you an good idea how the old Arabic art was used. The visit fits perfectly in your schedule while you are shopping in the souks.

Interesting History. Good for an hour to wander around this interesting building where up to 900 student field 130 very small rooms around the central courtyard. Shame there are no exhibits, artefacts and rooms showing how they would have lived to animate the place a little. Entrance is very cheap - around £1.50 per person.
lovely place to view. lovely place full of culture . buy a guide off the bus worth every penny. Mahammod off the bus was very helpful showed us the place and history
Must see in Marrakesh. For some reason this was the place I found most interesting in Marrakesh. You can get great pictures in it as well. Entrance is not that expensive either.

Lovely place to visit. The Ben Youssef Madrasa is a cheap and interesting place to visit in Marrakesh. The central courtyard is really lovely, and architecturally/visually it well worth a visit. Upstairs and around the rest of the Madrasa is where 900 boys would live (in surprisingly small spaces) and was good to wander around. Do not expect to be able to get loads of info about the place unless you have a good guide book, or if you have an actual guide (there were people offering their services but we decided just to wander). An enjoyable place to visit, with some lovely architecture.

The wood carvings are phenominal. This 14th century theological college served the educational needs of young men in northerrn Africa until 1960. It was restored and reopened as an historical site in 1982.

Peaceful history. Fascinating place. Simple in it's beauty. The history I had we read from a guide book, so I suspect we missed out in a way from not having someone show us around and tell us more, however, we also just enjoyed exploring ourselves.

Beautiful building and interesting history. Definitely worth a visit even just to see the beauty of the building. We were with a guide as part of our Marrakech tour and this makes it much more worthwhile getting information on the history.
Very reasonable entry fee.
Beautiful Patterns. Well worth finding in the Medina. Really beautiful tiling and stonework with lot of small rooms to wander into. Had a mint tea in the cafe by the museum close by.
Beautiful architecture. This is well worth a visit for the beauty of the zellig tiling and intricate stonework and woodwork. Finding it can be a challenge, because it is in the heart of the medina.

Worth a visit.. Inexpensive entrance charge. Beautiful building to look around, really enjoyed our visit. Not at all busy when we visited in October. Would benefit from having some information boards up in English.
Beautiful. Lovely architecture. Wold have benefitted from having a guide or info within the building - googled it to find out more when we had returned to the Riad.

Wouldn't recommend a visit . As this was the No.3 thing to do in Marrakech we thought it was worth a visit. It will probably take you about ten minutes to walk around the building of empty rooms and take a couple of snaps. I appreciate architectural buildings but this was not for me. It would be nice to see some money being put back into restoring the building and perhaps some literature available for tourists (who are the only people visiting) to read.

Highly recommended. The architecture and decoration is beautiful and there are multiple rooms to wander around in and get out of the sun and the crowds. The price of entrance is crazy cheap and you can get so close to the detailed ornamentation.

Stunning beauty. Visited here today with my son - we were both completely blown away (and surprised) by the beauty of the architrcture inside. What a place to receive your education within!It is well worth the effort to seek out this place - and just 20DH entry fee.

A beautiful atmospheric place. A visit here is a must when in Marrakech. Try if you can to avoid visiting when the tour buses descend on it. The site is ben observed in a quiet atmosphere, where you can soak up on the reflective ambience and get a feel for the theological history/background of the site. If this not possible, then the beauty of the place is still really very impressive. A must see.

A beautiful architectural marvel . The old Quran school is so intricate in decoration and beautiful to walk around. There are plenty of photography opportunities and at 20md (around £1.30) entrance fee I wouldn't hesitate to visit!
cool architecture. The Ben Youssef Madrassa is definitely worth a visit. I'd recommend using a guide if you want to learn a little more about the history.

Beautiful. The architecture is much to be appreciated. We walked outside and inside the grounds. The upstairs is open to the public too. The children loved walking on the first floor and looking outside down below. The visit here doesn't take too long.Next door to the Morroco Museum and round the corner from the Ben Youssef mosque. It is difficult to find as it is deep in the medina. We used our GPS to guide us. Takes 15minutes walking from the main Jema El Fena square.
outstanding beautiful. A pearl in the medina. The admosphere tells it all. The beauty of the woodcarvings and the decoration of the pilars is outstanding.

Interesting, worth a short visit. You get the feel of what it would have been like to study here as you wander around the maze of study-bedrooms, all of which are quite similar. It would have been good to have seen at least one furnished.
Interesting architecture. Well worth a visit and I would recommend a guide who can explain the history etc. wiorth TE minimal entry fee
impressive. think this place was top 5 on things to do , 2 quid to get in , some amazing carvings ,tiles , rooms well worth a look

Stunning example of the Moroccan Architechture. This place is a must do to look at what religious educational institutes looked like. this is palatial and easily dwarfs the bahaii palace. excellent for pictures and stunning to just soak in the atmosphere away from the madness of Jemma Al Fnnaamake sure to visit the small rooms on the first floor that overlook the courtyard - it is beautiful for pictures.

Beautiful Visit. I would definitely recommend visiting Ben Youssef as the architecture is beautiful. My friend had a lovely visit, costing 20 dirhams each.It was great to be able to take photos (for free!)
Amazing to see what is created by hand. It is a shame that this is still not a school, but the bonus is that tourists can now visit it and marvel and the workmanship.

Great photo opportunities here.. Interesting visit here, with lots of photo opportunities and a magical feel to the place. An oasis of calm from the hectic souks and medina outside......calming and relaxing.
Fine geometry. Nice to reflect on the use of geometry to create beauty. You can see how orderly study could unfold here.

So glad we went.... Our guide from Riad Romance took us here, so glad we went, amazing place...the craftmanship is amazing. think a guide to provide you the interesting facts would make your visit better, ie why the colours of the tiles are those colours, the trading of sugar with italy for the marble...
Detail is Amazing. Go for the tile work and carving, a marvel in craftsmanship. Dont recall the history but the architecture is great.

Highly Recommended - get a guide. An absolutely gorgeous place with an amazing and interesting history. Right in the Medina. We had an English speaking guide who gave us the history and toured us through. I loved this and the pictures were amazing.

Great Architecture!. Brilliant Architecture and a fantastic structure. It is a little difficult to find if you are heading out on your own. The courtyard is absolutely beautiful. Note that is gets fairly busy!
@instabuilt

A scintilating gem of 14th century art and architecture. The intricacy and organic beauty of the arabesques in this madrasa are stunning. There is a very organic floral motif to the plaster work with a very unique protruding shape which I have never seen in any other work. The art and decorations are exquisite. The size of the madrasa also makes it impressive as it's huge compared to those in Fez. I highly recommend visiting this madrasa.

Tranquility. Situated round the corner of a backstreet it can be easy to walk straight past the building (it does not scream for tourism). The design is typical of Marrakech and and is great to spend an hour or two appreciating what this place used to be.

Stunning. Beautiful architecture, we went here with a tour and didn't really have much time here though. Definitely need more time here to take it all in. We're returning to marrakech next year so will return here then to adsorb it all.

Beautiful architecture.. Finding our way here, was easier than we thought. We headed south through the souks, and when we arrived here I was in awe. The rooms, the courtyards and the hallways are all magnificient. We even saw someone creating mosaics from stone for the walls. Me and my partner decided to buy one (20d) and also leave a little something behind. Overall beautiful place, not to be missed!

16th century Koranic school with fantastic architecture and details. We enjoyed visiting this former Koranic school which once house 900 students. The courtyard is of Moorish design decorated with zellij tile work and carved plaster. You can visit the former student cells and enjoy all the calligraphy praising Moulay Abdallah.
Very interesting place. I must admit, I didn't know about this place, until my friends drag me there. It's a beautiful place. Excellent craft cealings and walls. Nice to take pictures.
don´t miss it. great place to go, best to take one of the guides waiting in the main patio to give you information on the place's famous past. really marvellous!

Architectural wonder. This Madrassa is no longer operational; however, walking thorough the hallways, rooms and courtyards one can truly appreciate the architecture of this place.Highly recommend a visit.

Back in time in Marraketch . This is a great size to visit. You are advised to hire a guide for full appeciation of everything you visit inside the Medina. There are restrooms inside. Always have some coins to hand to the attendant (50 cents.)

day trip. Inside the hostel it felt so gloomy! it had so many rooms for all the ex-pupils of this hostel.it was very attractive to everyone who had came.the rooms of the ex-pupils wasn't very as wide.

Interesting for a short visit. This is an inexpensive attraction and worth a stroll around. Some of the detail on the buildings is lovely but we found 30 minutes or so was enough time for our visit. You need to have your own information on the building's history to get the background.
This is what you come to see - stunning. Don't miss this - beautiful tile work, stucco and classic proportions and symmetry in Islamic buildings.
