Worth a Visit. This ancient former Islamic college is right in the heart of the Medina so can be a bit tricky to find but is worth a visit. It only costs 10 dirham entrance fee and takes no more than about half an hour or so to look around.
Enjoyed my visit. Really enjoyed my visit. Well worth paying the fee to see this historical place. Very close to the Mosque too for Muslim visitors.

Calm, Cheap and Colourful. This Madrasa is absolutely stunning. Moroccan architecture is like nothing you will experience in Europe, and this place shows it perfectly. The Madrasa is very calm, peaceful and has a wonderful beauty to it. There was absolutely 0 waiting time to get in, no rush to see everything.

Beautiful tile work and carvings. The Medersa Ben Youssef will amaze you if it is your first encounter with Moroccan tile and carvings. If you have already seen a lot of other buildings, this one will not stand out but it is still beautiful. It is small and can be crowded if a large group enters at one time. If you are short on time, I would skip the upstairs rooms that were formerly dormitory rooms or just peek into one. They are not particularly interesting.

Small and difficult to find. Interesting architecture. .. Don't be persuaded by a young local to guide you there. We were taken on 'walk about' in 40 degrees plus for 20 minutes only to come back to the place we started from and he had the nerve to say our 50 dirum tip wan't enough. They try and rip you off left right and centre in Marrakech. Just beware as it became a little tiring after a while.

Great place to visit with a guide. If you go on your own to this site you will enjoy the wonderful architecture and beautiful tiling but you would struggle to understand the usage and importance of the place. We were fortunate to be taken by a guide who explained its function as a college and place of learning, but I agree with other reviewers that signs and explanations would be very useful.
A delightful boutique and tearoom. An oasis of quiet to the north of the souks close to the Museum of Marrakesh. Go through the polished brass door for the boutique and tearoom with a book exchange

Beautiful building. I was kind of 'lost' trying to find it however it is worth a look. Not a huge place. A couple of hours is more than enough. There is nothing to really made me wow! and nothing to dislike.
Nice Place. Enjoyed visiting this Islamic site. Tiles were amazing. Nice spiritual place to visit. I must see if you are visiting Marrakech.
Well worth a visit. This is a beautiful example of Moorish architecture,lovely tilework and carved wood.It is very peaceful which is a good thing in Marrakech.
Beautiful . Lovely place, you got to go see!! Spent a good hour looking around and it costs penny's to get in. The architecture is stunning
Beautiful architecture. This is a magnificent example of Moroccan architecture, mosaics, and woodcarvings. Do not miss this gem!

Great Place. Lovely tilework, spacious unique place. I really enjoyed by visit to Ben Youssef Madrasa and this is a must if visiting Marrakech. Also conveniently a 5 minute walk from the Riad I stayed in Dar Nour El Houda which was also beautiful. An amazing break to Marrakech, such a unique place.

Wonderful.. Go see it !!! Unbelievable handicraft decoration work, very interesting to visit. Easy to reach in the Medina, and nearby you can find also the Marrakech Museum, another interesting place to visit. Do not miss both.

Fascinating but in need of tlc. This ancient college is an amazing place to explore. We came across it more or less by accident and went in to escape the 40+ degrees C heat. Wandering round we loved the architecture and as we had no prior knowledge of the building's function, enjoyed guessing why there were so many cell like rooms. We did try to sidle up to an organised group but were shooed away by the guide. Worth a visit.

Architecture but no Insight. Fascinating building with a maze of student 'cells'. There were restorers at work repairing the worn tiles, but no information about this or the workings and life during the time it was a school. More info would make it a more rounded experience.
you could skip this. not to my taste ..if you want to please go...not to my interest;there are other day tours and other places to see; so enjoy

Beautiful Moroccan architecture.. Really nice place to visit and it's only 10dh (70p), stunning architecture for pictures and a calm atmosphere inside. The only reason I've not given it 5* is there's no signs or info on the history of the building.

The most exquisite place to visit in Marrakech. Culturally this has to be one of the most fascinating places one can visit.Islamic world is going through a difficult time at the moment but this place takes one back to a time over hundreds of years when the faith of hundreds was captured in a school of learning.The Madrasa is a boarding school where 800 or more students of the Quran studied intensively to become scholars on the subject. Morocco is a secular state and respects all cultures and religions and adopts its own form of Islam. This beautiful and peaceful place is simply beautifully constructed in the heart of the Medina and has not just stunning architecture but beautiful frescoed pictures and tiled murals and floors.It truly feels that only yesterday this was a thriving school. The most impressive and deepest impression this place leaves is how such a peaceful haven can exist in Morocco.I would suggest this as one of the top places in Marrakech to visit, along with:Marjorelle Gardens (stunning)Saadian tombs (last on the list)Comptoir (for dinner)Sofitel terraces (for affordable elegance)

Walking tour of Marrakesh. We did a walking tour of Marrakesh which included all the monuments eg Bahia Palace ,Saddian Tombs, Ben Yussef Medersa, Souks and Djamma el Fna,,square. The architecture,was beautiful also the tiles. Very good tour. ,,,,

Beautiful, well preserved madrasa. Amidst all the chaos, this madrasa provides much needed peaceful moments. Great for those who enjoy intricate design of Islam architecture, we spent good two hours there, soaking up all the fine details and then waiting for snap-happy folks to take a break so we can capture its grandeur.
Stunning architecture. Better to go with a tour guide who can explain what you're looking at, but really stunning architecture.
Interesting and thought provoking. A good way to spend an hour immersed in history... one really has to see for oneself how the students from centuries ago would have lived.A place to visit!

Ok. We went to see this because it's kind of part of the tourist- list of things to see in marrakech. What you see in the picture is basically it. We wondered down hundreds of little streets to find it and once we did we paid 10dh to get in. It is nice to see and quite pretty the carvings in the stone, the tiles the woodwork etc but I wouldn't call it a 'must see '

Well Worth the Visit. This is a stunning example of moorish decor in an ancient,authentic school, not to be confused with modernly pejorative term, "madrasa." Algebra was a major topic at this school, where scholars lived in rooms above the learning centers. It is located quite next to the Souks and could be included in a combined tour.
Beautiful. A really beautiful oasis of calm and tranquility. Entrance is really cheap and the patio is amazing. I would reccommend the entrance to this attraction to everyone.
Worth every penny!. It cost us 10 dirhams to enter the college which is about 65 pence. We spent about 40 mins exploring and taking photos. Well worth the money!

Stunning. Absolutely stunning. We had a guide to explain to meanings all the mosaics and carvings and this was undoubtably well worth it. It is just amazing what superb skill and dedication these people had in the days when this was built. Such intricacy. We spent at least an hour at this place because our guide explained everything so well and made the visit so interesting. Really well worth a visit.
Don't miss this.. Wonderful architecture but very difficult to find...taxis drop you off at the nearest point and then it's up to you.

A shady retreat from the scorching sun. This is a very beautiful place offering shade from the hot May sun. The mosaic tiles and wooden doorways are stunning. We took lots of great photos. Despite being a somewhat busy place, it was very tranquil which made a change from the hustle bustle of the medina. It was a little difficult to find as the entrance is through the narrow streets of the souks but we asked shop vendors who happily directed us. It's only 10Dh each and our 4 year old was free.

Not amazing!. It was only 10 dirhams (70p) to get in. Would have been a better experience if we had paid for a guide but would have been quite expensive for just us 2. Nice to look around for 30 minutes
Charming. Don't expect too much from this charming little place but if you enjoy history and culture this is for you!... The staff were so helpful in suggesting onward destinations too!

Old boarding school. Pretty cool attraction with the architecture and glimpse into the life of a child in boarding school. Not a whole lot of information but you could go just about anywhere in the school which may not preserve the place for too long, it definitely needed some upkeep. The 10 Dhs was worth it though.

In serious need of restoration. Like SO many places here, the building looks scruffy and dirty and is in need of serious attention. It looks nothing like the wonderful photos you see online. The reality is broken tiles everywhere, dirty paintwork and tiling. Nothing special but at least cheap to enter.

Feast for the eyes. A definite must see for anyone in Marrakech, and the way there is also fun because you go through a bunch of souks. This old Koran school is worth seeing because of the beautiful architecture and colours. You get to go all over the site and even visit the rooms where students stayed. Long corridors, beautiful mosaic, high ceilings, open spaces...the list goes on. Guided tours are possible but I always rather do my own thing. Don't miss out.

Beautiful historic building. This is well worth seeing and won't take up too much of your time - if you have an hour to spend walking about and can read a little about it first, this is definitely worth doing
Worth the Visit. Beautiful. Classic architecture with wonderful detailing A must see but do it early to beat the crowds and heat. Best 10DHS you will spend

Beautiful. I was happy to have been able to stop here to view this beautiful site. The interior and exterior designs were breathtaking. Also a great location for photo taking. One of the many gems Marrakech has to offer!
Ben Youssef Madrasa. it was a Koran school. the place is worth seeing but it is not kept in good state, it would need restoration.
wonderful architecture. Pleasent to walk around and look at the architecture, can take some good photos. Do not need to spend long here though

Lovely building: photographer's dream. This is a lovely building with very intricate work.
Plan to spend an hour here early in the morning.
It's not a koranic school anymore so non Muslims are allowed.
very close to main square. cheap to get in

Moroccans fix this place up!. So said that such a beautiful and historic building is in poor condition. Broken tiles and walls. For a top attraction, surprising at the poor condition. Moroccans restore this place!

Interesting study on a very beautiful Islamic school / not to be missed!. We spent over an hour to visit this former Koranic school.
We took a local guide and we were not disappointed, because even if it is possible to make the visit itself with a good book, nothing beats the very precise explanations about the place of life and study this great very well preserved university / Marrakesh Originality / highlight

A beautiful monument. Only a few blocks from the main square (if you know where you are going) the Medersa is beautiful and a lovely place to spend an hour or two. Get there early! Lots of tour groups. Also the Photo museum is nearby but it is pricey at $4.

execellant. this was a beautiful building, glad we found it, very intricatley decorated, could imagine all the kids studying and running around in this place afew hundred years ago. much bigger on the inside then you would think.
Little to see.... There is little to see and do at this site, although the price for entry is so low that it is hard to complain. Expect to see a beautiful central courtyard but little else.
Beautiful example of Islamic architecture. Beautiful building, with very small entrance fee, makes this well worth a visit. No facilities except for a WC.

Beautiful but brief. This is a lovely building, and well worth visiting to take in the wonderful restoration work, which is stunning. It only costs 10 or 20D to get in as well. However, you can get round the whole thing in half an hour or less. Also, there are barely any signs/explanations of what the building was used for or what different rooms were for - this is a bit frustrating. Still worth a visit though.Keep an eye out for the graffiti street signs to get there.

really.....cooling your feet in the holy pool. less than a pound to visit, but this govt run site is clearly in dire need of building work to stop it falling down further. A significant part of the building is suffering from rising damp and plaster and brickwork is falling down. Nobody seems to care, nor about the heavy tourist traffic now seriously damaging the floors and stairs. See this whilst its still intact, and still has the lovely carvings and atmosphere.

Incredible. Ben Youssef Madersa, formerly an Islamic college, is the largest madrasa in Morocco. It is an incredible place to visit, especially if you are lucky enough to be the only one there (get there early in the morning, Dh10 entry). Unfortunately there was no water in the central fountain, however the atmosphere within the madrasa is still very peaceful. The wood carving both on the ground floor and upstairs in the dormitories, is so precise and intricate. There are many doorways and arches that inspire interesting photography.

A little piece of history. A truly beautiful building , once a college and so interesting to see all the dormitories , the detail in the decoration is spectacular and with an entrance fee of less than a pound you have nothing to lose. Visit the café next door for a drink and snack a real oasis. So glad we managed to see this.
Beautiful. A beautiful building but would recommend hiring a guide as there is nothing to give you information within the museum, it's always nice to know what you're looking at!
Beautiful!!!. Can't miss this visit!!! Beautiful place!We hire a local guide for the morning tour of the souks and Madrasa. They dont have any information on the buildings..must hire a guide!!

Beautiful but too crowded. The madrasa is gorgeous with incredible detailing. Sadly, you have to share it with hundreds of people. It's not a large building, which makes it difficult to enjoy without being in someone else's holiday photos. There isn't a long queue to get in so enforcing a limit on the number of visitors would not be impossible.

Amazing! Must see!. One of the most beautiful buildings I have ever been in! So detailed in every aspect of its design. The history and culture is great! Take a good wander around there is tons to see!

A piece of history. The Ben Youssef Madrasa was an Islamic college in Marrakesh, Morocco. It is the largest Medrasa in all of Morocco.The college was founded during the 14th century. It has 130 student dormitory cells cluster around a courtyard carved in cedar, marble and stucco. This madrasa was one of the largest theological colleges in North Africa and may have housed as many as 900 students. It was closed down in 1960. The building was refurbished and reopened to the public as an historical site in 1982. It seems that no further maintenance works have been done since the re-opening.Some small/short written notes, on the main parts of the building, could have add a lot to tourists who have no previous knowledge on that kind of sites.

Lovely and cheap. A lovely place to see and for such a cheap price, why not. Perhaps not the most exciting tourist attraction I've ever been to, but beautiful and traditional so well worth a quick look.
Soak it up. Doesn't take a lot of time but definitely worth it. The craftsmanship is not to be missed. Bring your camera but make sure to see it with the naked eye as well.

Interesting cultural experience.. We thought this the best of the sights we went to. The palaces are interesting, but don't offer a tremendous amount of cultural insight, since they are mostly playthings for the rich. This, however, was truly interesting; helping you to understand something (or at least imagine something) of the culture of the country. A beautiful, large courtyard surrounded by a warren of tiny rooms for the students. The rough guide claims it's 50dh to get in here, but it's actually only 10dh now, in line with almost of all the sites (presumably they're all state-run).
really beautiful. this koranic school waas a hightlihght of our historical tour -amazing sculpted plasterwork. definitely worth a visit.

nice place. A must to visit, especially at 10DH each for tickets - but although lovely to look at, there is nothing by way of explanation to give you some context behind what you're seeing. I guess this is because a handful of people can make some money as a tour guide, but really what this place needs are some simple explanatory panels about the history and function of the building. The end result is that people read the very limited text in their own guidebooks, take a few pics, and leave after about 15-20 minutes

An oasis of calm in a stunning building. Worth the quest to find this place. Beautiful building that brings a sense of calm. It would be lovely if the water feature had water but I guess water is at a premium in Morocco . I have been twice & loved it both times. I think the entrance fee was 20dh & it closes at 5 pm

Must see!. The Ben Youssef Medersa is a fine example of traditional moroccan Architecture. In the heart of the medina it is a little tricky to find, but it is worth visiting it. Beautiful colorful mosaic tiles, fine wood carvings and calligraphic stucco as far as you can see.

Don’t miss it if you love architecture. This was a beautiful old school and had a slightly disheveled sense about it, but that did not detract from it’s grace. I wish there had been more written explanations about the various rooms, in English or French or Italian, but I’m sure I could have found a guide if I really wanted one.

Insight into schooling for imams. This is in the heart of the Medina and can be difficult to find even with the best map but worth a visit. You can visit courtyard and rooms where students were trained to become imams. You can admire most beautiful carvings and tilework. This is a very peaceful location in the middle of the hussle and bustle of the souk.

Interesting cultural visit.. We engaged the services of a tour guide who brought us here and gave us some good information on this building. Maybe not a great deal to see, but the entry fee is cheap and worth visiting for the history and cultural aspects.
wonderful space. go early to avoid the crowds - then you get to experience the place on different levels without fighting through people

Just stop and stare!. Very close to the Photography Museum, and a very popular attraction. Despite the numbers visiting, the Madrasa still retains a calm tranquil an atmosphere. There is no printed material to distract your eye from the wonderful tilework, stucco, central courtyard, and cool interiors. Definately a place to just stare and absorb.
Stunning. Really worth finding. The architecture is stunning and pottering round the building a joy. The courtyard in particular is beautiful with lovely carving and colourful tiles.
Beautiful architecture and free of charge!. I definitely recommend to go there. The place is really nice, its architecture is fabulous and also is free of charge which is quite hardy in Morocco.
Beautiful Artwork on building. Tile, wood and stone art work is stunning. A look into the past. A good place for visiting. Worth the trip

Well worth a visit. A beautiful building, with examples of the stucco work and painted ceilings that make Islamic architecture so stunning. Cool and shady out of the heat and noise of the medina. Interesting insight into a madrasah and the lives that the students might have lived there.

Travel in time. Walking through the beautiful architecture, I couldn't help reflecting how knowledge and learning was essential in Morocco. So much details were given to the school and wondered who was there and how did this school became part of history instead of still being within the present.
Nice place to visit. This is quite small, so you can enjoy it quite quickly. There are people who will ask for money to give you a guided tour. our guide was not very good nor was his English
It takes you back to the past. Brilliant architect, It takes you back to the past when people went to study . It is the largest Madrasa in the whole of Morocco.
A must see in Marrakech. An amazing place, that shows rich ornamented islamic building culture. Easy to find, it will give you the 1001 nights impressions that the arab countries are known for.

Best thing we saw in Medina. By far the most interesting place we visited of all the sights in the Medina. Amazing architecture and real insight into the past lives of the students who lives there. However like allThe other place we visitedIn Marrakech - about 20mims and you have seen it all. Still well worth the trek through the the souks to get there.

Beautiful and Worth A Visit. The medersa is large, so make sure you see the courtyard and head upstairs to the student housing. It was pretty crowded, but as you wander the halls you can enjoy it in relative peace. The craftsmanship is beautiful, and you feel like you have stepped back in time.
Marvellous Madrasa. A cool and peaceful retreat from the hurly burley of the Medina. A visual feast of pattern and workmanship. We loved the boys rooms still partitioned.

"Classical and Impressive". A gem in the old narrow streets. If u visit the place and try to just imagine how students live their and how they study there then you feel more fascinating rather than just looking at the amaizing architecture classical wood work and beautiful mosaic tiles.
Empty building in need of TLC. Entry is cheap at 10 dirham each, but the building beyond its tiled walls is empty. What there is to be seen can be viewed in under an hour.
Place to grab some shade. Popped in, worth a look. Very cheap at 10dir. Interesting architecture and lovely mosaics. Did not spend long.
Facinating. I liked interesting facts about this place. It was amazing to know where the students slept and learned.
Koranic School. A glimpse into the past. Fascinating residence rooms, and beautiful courtyard. Graceful Islamic architecture.

A haven in the Souks. You enter this just near the Ben Yousef Mederasa archway, we nearly missed it! Costs 10 dirhams each. Very ornate courtyard with tile, stone and woodwork dating back many centuries. A guide helps to put things in perspective. Aim to spend about an hour there. Great coupled with the nearby photographic museum.

Ornate and fascinating building. 10 Dirhams entry - about 70p- is well worth the price for a fascinating insight into a place where scholar used to study the Koran. It only takes a short amount of time to visit and view. If you want more detail you'll need a guide.

A delightful busing for a few pennies. . As with many old buildings in Marrakech, this is one for people who appreciate craftsmanship, decor and history. It is easy to imagine what it must have been like for scholars who spent many years studying here and living in cramped conditions. Some nice photo opportunities, especially from upstairs. Worth the tiny entrance fee if you are wandering the streets of Marrakech.
Beutiful place. Madrassa Ben Youssef very beautiful, with the old beautiful architecture i have realy enjoy my visit there not to be missed.
Beautiful. Only ten dirhams to get in and the place was stunning. Definitely a must-see in Morocco. We loved the stone and woodwork and how quiet it was despite being in the middle of the medina.

Beautiful Madrasa. This is a beautiful piece of architecture. Stunning artwork on the walls and also the wooden structure inside. I was one of the first two to visit it on that day so it was like the entire Madrasa was only for us. Could take beautiful pictures without any other tourists in it :-) This beautiful place reminded me of the Nazarid Palaces in Granada Spain. In the summer time this closes at 5 PM. So make sure to visit between 9 AM and 5 PM. A must while in Marrakech.

One of the best in Morocco. We had the opportunity of touring Morocco and found that this Madersa represents one of Morocco's best. The architecture and level of detail is astonishing and not to be missed.
Touring. This was actually very beautiful. So impressed with the architecture. Lovely to wander around. get the double ticket
A beautiful building. The building is lovely. There isn't much to see in terms of it being a 'museum' and nothing in English. It's worth coming just for the nice building though.

Breathtaking architecture. Visited this on the last day of our holiday. I would have been so sad to get home a realise what I'd missed...definitely worth a visit. Amazing workmanship on show, and some great photo opportunities. Beautiful.Also only 10 dh each - bargain!
Unmissable. A tranquil haven but get there early to avoid the crowds. The architecture and craftsmanship is stunning. A very worthwhile detour down the busy streets

Great piece of history. It was lovely to see this boarding school of quran.I didn't take a guide which I now regret as I would probably find out much more about it. Nevertheless I was happy to see the little rooms where the students were sleeping and the lovely main square.Fee was 10 dirhams.
Beautiful carvings. Beautiful carvings and mosaic. It is a bit difficult to find, but that end of the souk has some different and nice artisans. I wish is was better taken care of...

Interesting place to visit. At on 10 DH to visit this is a definite bargain and a must see on you visit to Marrakech.It is amazing how many rooms there are, the place is huge, it is also quite well maintained and the carvings really ornate and intricate.The main courtyard is great as is the rest of the building, lots of brilliant photo opportunities.
Very interesting. A maze of small rooms and intricate architecture in the middle of the medina. It would have been nice to have a little more info about what we were seeing
Fascinating piece of Marrakech History. Very busy but good value and a real piece of history. Main courtyard is brilliant and the bedrooms are all individual

Beautiful Moorish building. Only 10 Dhirams (about 70p!) to get into this beautiful old Moorish building, (previously a residential school for students of Islam) is an amazing bargain. It has been well maintained and has much amazing Islamic carving, architecture and woodwork. You MUST visit if you are in Marrakech.

An unbelievable place of peace and beauty in an unlikely spot!. This was an awe inspiring masterpiece. It was undoubtedly the highlight of our time in Marrakech. The intricacy cannot be described in words and our camera could not do it justice. If you are getting too hot walking around the Medina, I suggest you make a bee line here as it is very cool inside.

Serenity. Fine architecture and decoration. Could do with either in-house guides or explanatory literature. Pity it is not possible to visit the associated Ben Youssef Mosque - if it is possible in Istanbul why not in Marrakech?

Magnificent architecture. Unlike the madrasas we visited in Fes, this one allows visitors to enter the areas where the students lived. You get a much better sense of the scale of the schools. Worth the higher entrance fee.
Well worth a visit. Beautifully preserved building with lots to see and wander around. At 10 dirhams it is superb value for money.
Beautiful. Only 10 Dirhams to enter and what a beautiful place. Just a shame that there were no descriptions of what you're seeing or an explanation of why it's no longer in use.

Spectacular carved walls. Do not miss this building as it's the only Islamic building open to the public in Marrakesh. The building is incredible and the carved wall breathtaking. I cannot imagine the time it took to carve all those walls in the central patio. I think the fee is 10 dirahm and on Fridays it's free entrance (but if you don't know about this and try to pay they will charge you anyway)

Ancient school. Lovely tiled floors and walls. Decorated ceilings. A step into Moroccan history. Good stop. 10 DHM entry fee (about 1 euro). The handcrafted doors, tiled, floors, painted, wood and tiled ceilings all worth a look

A very cheap little place to visit - stunning and definitely worth a visit!. I think we paid just 10 dirhams each to get inside the Ben Youssef Madrasa which is ridiculously cheap! The building's architecture and design are absolutely stunning, although the place can get a little crowded with tour groups.
Definitely worth a visit.
So very interesting. Amazing architectural carvings throughout the building which must have taken many crafts men literally years to complete and all look so perfectly formed.

No crowds, rather peaceful. My hubby and I went in Sept 2013 and enjoyed it. It doesn't have the pomp and circumstance that some of the similar ones in Souther Spain have (the Alhambra), which I enjoyed as it didn't seem like it was trying to be something greater than it is (hello, again, Alhambra). No real guides or information throughout, but still a great scene of artistry and detail that is essentially self-explanatory. The price was quite low (did we pay? I think so, but don’t really remember so obviously it wasn’t much). This was one of the few highlights of Marrakesh for us. I still cannot get over the sickly cats and kittens everywhere in Marrakesh, particularly around sites like these. Makes me sad and want to help, but there isn’t much you can do.

Must-see whilst in Marrakech. I was lucky enough to visit the Madrasa on a relatively quiet day, and with a guide who was very informative and told us interesting stories about this place. It is the kind of building that you can only see in arabic countries and I had the impression this one is extremelly well maintained. Don't miss it if you are goind to Marrakech.

You don't want to miss this one, you can go inside unlike the mosques.. You don't want to miss the opportunity to see the interior architecture of Morocco. Many of the beautiful mosques you can't see from the inside, only if they are ruins. So its a great opportunity to visit this college and get a feel of Moroccan interiors, their fountains, their arches and detailed floors.

Wonderful, must-see. Really beautiful place to visit, amazing amount of detail and skill in architecture and very well preserved despite no protection at all. Almost worried at how over time tourism may damage it without any precautions in place. 10 Drm each and not overly busy when we visited in March. Lots of small rooms over two floors around the main courtyard which is just perfect.

Beautiful. I really enjoyed my visit here. The stunning arches, the colorful tilework, and the little rooms on the second floor with windows that overlooked the great courtyard. It made my imagination feverish, wondering what it would have been like to study here. If I had the time, I would have stayed in the courtyard for hours, propped up against a pillar, with my face to blue sky above. 10 MAD entrance fee.
Beautiful design.. A definite on your tour of Marrakech. The craftsmanship that went into this structure is mind boggling.

Historical religious School. This is very quaint school that students used to seek to learn Quran.The mosaic and the arabesque windows create a good harmony with little quaint rooms. There isn't much to see but the architecture is well worth the visit. It costs 10 Dirhams per person which is under a quid and it's in medina so you will come across it anyway as you navigate around the different souks. well worth the money, don't expect any info in English though only French and Arabic so it's a good idea to have your Marrakesh booklet with you to know what the place is about and how far back it stretches
Amazing place. Rich in historical and architectural details, this plasce haiìs to be seen. Ticket is cheap and the visit is really astonishing.
Beautiful architecture. A must place to visit while you are in Marrakech. Great architecture and beautiful monument for Islam. A bit lost in the medina.

stunning architecture. Beautiful building with real sense of history. We were hassled by what looked like official guide to have guided tour which was not exactly informative and told us nothing we had not read before

Beautiful building and very serene.. A Lovely place to visit if you are interested in the history of Marrakech. Though as with all the historic places we visited very light on any explanation of what you are looking at and how the building was used. We had a guide with us and I have to say it was money well spent as he was able to explain all this to us as well as the history of the place, things like how the students moved up the building as they progressed with their studies, starting in the little dark cells at the bottom up to the more spacious and lighter rooms at the top of the building. We would also not have found it very easily without our guide. Whilst there we saw workmen making new tiles and lovely that he did not mind in the least my taking a photos of him at work.
Just another traditional building. Pretty but nothing spectacular, charges 30dh entry which is cheap but only enough inside to visit for around 20minutes

Wonderful place away from the craziness!. Go and visit this place, it's quite unique with a lovely, almost holy feel about it. At about 70p to visit why would you not go! Respite from the hustle and bustle, fascinating to look around.
Pleasant building. Lots of empty rooms but the main hall is decorated beautifully with mosaic tiles, like most of the tourist buildings.

An architectural pearl and history. An architectural and historical pearl. All though I have read some critical reviews before visiting Marakech we decided to go for a visit to Ben Youssef - and thank God we did. This is a highly worthy historical and cultural location which amazes with ist simplicity but richness of decorations and style.

Exquisite Visit. The place is peaceful and has a nice spiritual vibe. The architecture is amazing: sculpted wood and stone cover the walls of the central square. Only it were better preserved, it needs its original furniture to bring it back to life.

Fantastic design. Definitely worth seeing, amazing design of the building and full of history. The entrance ticket is very cheap, you can also have a guide if you are keen on more details of the school history.Is not very easy to find so if you can have someone to guide you it would definitely help.
Impressive. Beautifully preserved, fabulous architecture, fascinating history. An oasis of calm in the hustle and bustle of the Medina

The Wow Factor. Beautiful and well preserved, it's definitely worth going out of your way to see this. The tiles and architecture of this building is absolutely beautiful. One of the must sees in Marrakesh!

Well worth visiting. A lovely building that is well worth visiting. Make sure to wander around the little rooms to the sides of the building. It is a little hard to find but ignore anyone who tells you that it is closed, they are only trying to trick you into paying them money to bring you somewhere else.
What a fabulous building!. Loved it all, bit confusing as every corridor led onto another looking exactly the same and onto another. Fabulous.

mixed feelings. The madrasa is very nice. it has some gems to see but also it needs more restoration and conservation. You end the visit with a mixed feeling of incredible architecture and artisan work and loss as several parts are not well protected and they are being ruined

Very interesting!. We visited the Madrasa as part of our walking tour day and found it really interesting. We visited in February, so it wasn't at all crowded. It was so interesting to see the little rooms the students would have lived in and to find out more about the history of the place. The wood carving and decoration is so beautiful.

Well worth a visit. A really cheap attraction (1 euro) so its well worth a visit. Its not really that big but the architecture is beautiful. I recommend a guided tour if you want to know more about it.
Worth a visit. The fabric of this building is worth a visit and it is well- preserved. I do think there should be more details displayed of the building and it's history.
Acient and present worlds wonder. A master piece of art, architecture, beauty and details. True color explosion and magical work, a lot to admire.

Old school of learning. This is a relatively large school at the edge of the Jemaa al Fna souk and the Marrakech Museum. Well preserved historic building which was used predominantly for accommodation. Well worth the trip

Tall architecture and vivid detail. Took us ages to find it and not long to take it all in. Very good for pictures and a worthwhile visit while in Marrakech with an interesting history. Get a guide when you walk inside as there are no information boards on display. Very close to other tourist attractions too.
Fabulous, do not miss. One of the best things we saw in Marrakech. Do not miss it, and don't forget to explore the upper levels.
Gorgeous!. Beautiful building filled with history. Former university, gorgeous tile work and amazing architecture.
a unic place. very interesting special place actually a possibility to see,feel and touch the classic architecture from the golden period
Worth the effort. Amazing journey through souks to find, and.locals so helpful andguidedusthere, wouldn't have found it otherwise. Loved the intricate woodwork

Well worth visiting - use one of of the guides to be found there!. Fascinating! We only took a guide because one was there but so very glad we did. We would never have seen or understood a quarter of all the interesting aspects of the place without him. He only quoted 10 Dirhams but he was so nice we doubled it! Still an absolute bargain!

A must if visiting Marrakech. No trip to Marrakech would be complete without a visit here, the craftmanship is wonderful you can really picture what it must of been like to study there.
Provides wonderful pictures and memory's of Marrakech and only 10dh entrance fee.

Beautiful Building. Stunningly beautiful building, well worth a wander round to admire the art and architecture. We had no trouble finding it as we travelled there by horse and carriage as they were so cheap, it was fun and saved the worry of struggling to find the place as other tripadvisors suggested we might. On occassions during our trip when we did get lost the locals were so helpful and were always keen to offer assistance so never worry about not being able to find places in Marrakech. There is an admission fee but it was only a few pounds which I felt was worth it. On the way out we did get pounced on by a local who tried to lure us to the tanneries but politely said no and continued on our way which didn't seem to bother them. For film buffs it was the location for parts of Hideous Kinky. We went first thing in the morning and found it very quiet and had no trouble moving between rooms. I'd definitely recommend it for a visit.

beautiful. I would really recommend this. As a non-muslim you can't enter the mosques, so I really liked seeing this. Its old, wel kept and beautiful. Was a little hard to find (as is everything in Marrakech), so take your time.

Great Architecture. I really enjoyed the architecture. Worth the price of admission just for that. It is a learning experience too if you didn't Wikipedia everything before hand. I did that, yet still was glad I went as it is still very interesting. One fo the top attractions for sure. They opened most of it up so you can imagine going back in time and see what going to school there was like.Don't go to the tanneries. They are apparently nearby and you will get people outside trying to get you going there after your visit of the place.
Stunning architecture. Probably the finest architecture in Marrakech. Tour guides are available but you are free to wonder around on your own taking photos. Highly recommended.

Worth a look. Little or no restoration work is evident.
If you go to the Museum first you can buy a ticket which will cover a visit to the madrasa as well. The two are not worth the price of separate admission charges.
Very Interesting if you like to see how ..... Very interesting IF you like to see how the intellectuals lived in order to be able to get to the academic success they wanted to get to 400 years ago.

Amazing place full of history. Its amazing to think that it was not long ago still used as a school to learn not only the koran but also astronomy and other sciences. The carved wooden panels and ceilings are amazing to see and show the craftsmanship of the woodworkers at the time. Surrounding the inner courtyard are the tiny rooms in which the students lived and studied. Don't miss out on seeing this.

The 'Cherry' of our vacation. I fell in love with the beauty of the place. It made me appreciate more the Moroccan culture and heritage. Finding the place was a bit tricky, but we were able to follow the signages and with the help of the other tourists we found one great treasure.
Worth a visit. We had a private tour guide and this was a must go place on the list. The architecture was great, it was cheap to visit and had a great atmosphere

Amazing place!. Loved this place. Beautiful architecture and stone carving. Photos don't do it justice. And only 10 dirham's entry! Cheap when we were getting 14.69 dirham's to the Pound! A definite must see!

Hidden gem. well worth the 10 dhs to see the craftsmanship and intricate detail in this building. Sadly some areas aren't well maintained but overall an interesting visit especially when you realise the building was still being used in the 1960s.

Staff members running a scam with the tanneries. Was really looking forward to going to Ben Youssef Madrasa, unfortunately We never got to see it. We found it with no problem but upon trying to enter a member of staff told us we couldn't as it was closed until 2pm and we should go to the tanneries as it was a "special day" and not far. Not thinking to question it, he told us to follow a local worker on his way there.....total scam which ended up costing our group upwards 500dh.  I think people should be warned that some of the staff here are running a scam with the tanneries, and since returning from Marrakesh have seen that we were not the only ones fooled. Be warned!!

Important building – don’t miss it. Located in the medina district, shouldn’t be missed. This one of the biggest Koran colleges in North Africa building was founded in 14th century and was closed in 1960.It accommodated up to 900 students in only 1300 tiny bedrooms. So what you see is empty student rooms and a lovely decorated court yard with pool which served for ablutions before entering the prayer room. It is worth a visitBuy a combined ticket with the Museum of Marrakech (60Dh). They are close to each other.

fascinating insight. really fascinating to look inside this old madrassa, and see the tiny cells where the students would be learning their Koran.
very friendly staff, but no café.

Most beautiful building ever visited !. This old Quranic school is tucked away from the mosque with the same name and only costs one Euro to enter and then it is all mouths open, the mosaics, the colours, the architecture, the serenity of it all, just amazing !

Very Different. Like nothing I've ever seen! All the tiny bedroom for the scholars were fascinating and the courtyard was beautiful. It was cheap too! At the same time visit the Dar Bellarj foundation almost next door to see free exhibitions.
Beautiful. The Ali ibn Jusuf medresa is one of the most beautiful monuments I've ever seen. The decorations are amazing. And you can enter every room what's not so common in Marroco.

Stepping back into Islamic history. We've all read about radicalization of young Muslims. This trip to Morocco has really demonstrated the fact that most Muslims are devout, peaceful people. The Madrasa and Mosques were evidence of their piety, the people themselves evidence of their peacefulness. The Madrasa was beautiful and very open to the public. It is not functioning as a Madrasa any more but you could imagine when it was, what life was like for the young students.

Amazing. A well preserved piece of history showing how a school operated even up to the mid 20th Century. It's only 10 dirham to get in about .which is about a £1. Try the GPSmyCity app to get about its great.

Stunning. So glad we made time to see this beautiful and historical building. Well worth the 10 dirhams/person we paid to get in. Would've paid FAR more. The architecture is beautiful, the colors are stunning, and it was a nice respite from the bustling streets of the souks. Can't wait to visit again.

Awesome. Truly stunning architectural treasure in the heart of Marrakesh. Every part of this building is almost achingly beautiful. That you can get up close and touch it feels like a rare privilege, and the lack of people trying to sell you things is a blessed relief.
best architectural piece of marrakesh. exeptionell, a masterpiece of architecture. unique atmosphere. entrance really cheap. just worth to see it

An experience worth going!. One of the highlights of our trip..its worth a visit for only 10Dh. Located on a nondescript entrance..the detail of the building is stunning and its a perfect location for selfies and photography. You are free to walk around and touch everything!
Beautiful architecture. For 10Dhs this is a bargain, the building is lovely and you are free to walk around and explore all the rooms on the ground and upper floors.

Must visit. Worth a visit. you get a feel of the architecture and culture of the country. Only disadvantage is the lack of information in English so you are left to guess the origin of some work because your travel guide books do not necessarily have a description of every piece of work in a place

Beautiful, well worth a vist. The beautiful arabesque stucco, zillij mosaics and cedar wood carving on the walls of the huge courtyard are amazing in themsleves. But the whole of the Medersa is beautiful and truly worth a visit.

insight into the past !!!!!!!!!!!. We quite literally stumbled upon the madrassa and investigated well worth half an hour of anybody's time - the architecture is sublime and it provides an insight in a world we westerners seldom see, the tile work is sublime and contrasts with the starkness of the living experience - whilst there walk on to the jewish cemetary and if you can bear it walk back through the jewish quarter - beware it is grim beyond grim - but serves as a reminder of how lucky we are !!!!!!!

A fascinating piece of history. Beautiful plasterwork and tiles dating back a long way. The tiny dormitories are dark and slightly creepy - it must have been an unpleasant place for young boys to sleep. Overall very interesting although, as with all popular attractions, there were large numbers of people. All with their cameras!

Step into the Methodical World of Ancient Scribes. When entering monuments such as the Ben Youssef Madrasa, the initial feeling is often linked to the grandness of it all but once you are past that stage it can become a surprisingly intimate visit. Focus on the architectural detailing rather than the volume of the impressive patio and step into the precise, methodical world of the ancient scribes. This 14th century college offers some of the most remarkable Moroccan carvings including magnificent naturalistic patterns that undoubtedly inspired 20th Century European Art Nouveau. Reopened to the public in 1982 after being closed down for a decade, the Madrasa is a must see monument for anyone travelling to Marrakech and the Medina.
Beautiful. Absolutely worth a visit for the beautiful architecture very impressive. There is a calming, relaxing atmosphere.
Ok. Nice to look around, great craftsmanship to see but nothing much I found interesting. The guide showed us around and explained the history but it just didn't really do much for me.
Morning time. We visited the madrasa, but with more people, they recommended us the visit in the morning. It's not far from Jam el Fnaa.

Spend half an hour here... really great. This building was a Koranic school, and is notable for its magnificent architecture.... I defy you not to be impressed by the intricate carving, tiling and décor...You don't need long, and the place is very accessible on foot from the Souk area (and even signposted - a rarity) and I would suggest that you haven't been to Marrakech until you have been there... :)

Wonderful surprise. Fairly tricky to find but worth the effort. Behind a nondescript door lie the most amazing sights - mosaics, wooden carving, intricate stuccos and so very peaceful. We managed to avoid the tour groups thankfully - worth going early or at lunchtime.
An impressive piece of history. Ben Youssef Madrasa is absolutely worth a visit although I imagine in the summer it is mobbed and therefore less pleasant. Beautiful architecture.

Beautiful Building. Nicely decorated, shows the importance of religious education at its time in Marrakesh. The second floor is worth visiting. There is a caligraphist on site with beautiful work in arab.

Must see for fans or Arabic architecture . It's a beautiful place reminiscent of the andalus architecture of southern Spain, with beautiful stuccos and mosaics, around a gorgeous patio. A visit will take you an hour at max, with plenty of details to gaze at, and photo opportunities thanks to the great perspectives. Go ahead and peek in the rooms of the former students, it wil make you wonder what it must have been to have studied in such a place...

no adult supervision!. This place is beautiful! I would have loved to have been a student here...wait a minute, after exploring each and every student room unsupervised, climbing unmarked ladders to second level sleeping quarters, maybe I like my 21st century comforts a little more. But boy is this place beautiful. Plenty of photo opts. I'd say get there early as there are less tourists and you get the feeling like you own the place, which I must say is pretty awesome. the pool was drained when I visited and I climbed in and stood in the middle for a great photo opt. The space is just amazing. Because you get to roam the madrasa without any security guards or workers (the only 2 I saw were the guy that takes your money and the other one that offers to write your name in arabic for a few dirham), it really gives you a chance to take your time and just take in the experience of being there, immersed in the history. The place isn't really preserved, nothing is roped off and I could not recommend it more. Especially if you have somehow grown tired of the medina (which can be a feat in and of itself)

Worth the effort. I knew immediately upn entering that this was a special place. it was crowded but very quite and peaceful. I found the whole experince very interesting and having settled into one of the many student rooms, tried to imagine what it must be like to live and study here.Hint - buy the combined ticket for the museum for €6 (its only next door and will fill in another hour or so.

A magical architectural pearl behind a nondescript wall. Like many beautiful buildings in Marrakesh (and all over Morocco as we were told) we discovered a magical building behind a nondescript wall. Our guide explained to us the wonderful history of this building, with its beautiful patio where the teachers taught various subject matters to the boys who attended this Koranic school. We visited the rooms where the boys slept, of which a number has a view of the patio. A wonderful experience.
Worth Seeing. Nice history for an hour, information in english around the area.No facilities, no sellers of goods, just a bit of history.
the Koranic school.. A fascinating place with wonderful architecture. Didn't, get the best out of it as we should have had a guide. Would strongly recommend people took a guide to this

Worth a visit. This is not easy to find but worth a visit. Get a double ticket and visit the Marrakesh Museum at the same time. This is inexpensive and has some beautiful architectural features. A quite haven in the middle of madness.

Stunning Architecture tucked away!. If there is one attraction you do visit, then make it this one! Again a place of calm &tranquillity close to the souiks with a fantastic courtyard, roof and plenty to keep your mesmerized and photograph happy!

Worth the entry fee. some great examples of stucco, and wood carvings from many years ago. Unfortunately, the Morrocans are not particularly careful in preserving history and I fear that more of this will be lost unless they pay more attention to the artefacts

Must see. Great to visit this well restored building. Could have used a bit more interior decoration, but the building is stunning.
Still a must see when you visit marrakech.

Amazing!. This place was a 5 min walk from our Riad. Even on a wet Feb morning it was amazing.... the architecture and history... the dormitories were just about big enough for our 8 year old son... who found the place to be like a maze and we spent ages there without him getting bored!
A must see in Marrakech!

Absolutely stunning. Just happened upon this place by getting a combined ticket with the nearby museum. But this was the star attraction - the internal decoration is amazing and on a scale I've never seen before. Even on a wet February morning it looked stunning.

Beautiful example of medieval Moroccan architecture.. This was the most impressive building we visited in Marrakech that dated to the middle ages. The intricate tile work, carved plaster work, and cedar architectural elements are trademarks of a style of Moorish architecture that is much admired and copied. The building was for centuries a college, and you can visit the small dormitory rooms in which students lived. Worth a visit.

Must see when in the Medina. Too bad some parts of the interior of the Medersa already need a restauration but the Medersa gives a good overview on how quran-students lived and learned for centuries. Just a few steps away from the Maison de la photografie so it makes a good combination.
Beautiful. The craftsmanship and elegance of the design is inspiring. This place has some of the best examples of Moroccan design in Marrakech.

A must see. Architectural details and atmosphere of koranic school are sufficient reasons to visit. It's unique and together with city museum nearby (you can buy ticket for both at reduced price) it gives some understanding of what is this Marrakesh buzz all about.
Impressive. Very impressive. Lacks something rather than only the structure and architecture. But still spent nice 10 minutes there

Worth a visit. Despite the best efforts of a local chap to divert us to the tanneries, we visited the Medersa on a combined ticket with the Museum of Marrakech (60Dh each, approx £4.30). For fans of Moroccan architecture it's a must see and if you're lucky you can time your visits between coaches! As with most places in the medina the signs are a bit random and it took us a few goes to actually find the place. The Medersa, a former religious school, is filled with intricate plaster carvings and wooden ceilings and you have access to the cells previously inhabited by the students.

Amazing Place!. Cool Architecture and you can imagine it as an academy for scholars. Carvings and the intricacy of the handiwork are amazing. Worth a visit and take a peek in the tiny studio rooms! Museum next door also worth seeing!
Beautiful architecture. This structure is beautifully designed with a lovely center court/pool. It's very interesting to see the tiny dark rooms the students lived in. It's well worth a visit.

Excellent . Amazing architecture, a must see in your travels around Marrakech.It was a shame there was no history/notices in English but we checked out on the Internet before and after.Some of the rooms were amazing and small. The carvings and size of the place leaves you in awe. A very cool place in the hot sun but cold on a night I would think !Cheap to get in and I hope they are spending it on renovation as the walls were peeling away.

The most beautiful place in the city. Absolutely amazing, an old islamic school restored to its former glory. A must-see. The entry fee is 50 dh. Nearby is also the Marrakech museum, also interesting, as well as the Ben Youssef Mosque, the Almoravid Qubba and Chrob Fountain, all worth a detour.

Interesting but not much to see. It took us a while to find this as we were 'misguided' by a young man who wanted money for this service. Someone else then told us that it was closed for cleaning! But we persisted, and found an old building that is beautiful but with limited ( and I say this as someone who is very interested in history). Things to do/ see. Basically there is the entrance, a courtyard and the plain rooms around and over looking the courtyard. Entrance in 50 dirham, or 60 if you want to go to the museum as well.
A stunning building. Brilliantly sums up the characteristics of high Arabic architecture. It is easy to visualise what it would have been like to be a pupil there!
Awestruck. What a building! We bought a bundled admission with the Musée de Marrakech, and enjoyed this stop more by far. The craftsmanship is simply astounding.
Boring. There was no information in English and it was a waste of time. All you see is empty rooms and a court yard. It was a total waste of time.
interesting. had a good time here find it ok. taxi took us via his uncles shop but all part of the fun.lots of people there so best to get there early. cheap and interesting

There is no similar to this place. Very old . Architucture and the handcraft are beautiful. When you walk in you feel as if you are going to your own school. It reminds you with your childhood and gets you the memories of your old school days.
Spectacular art on the walls. The building is amazing The details of the mosaic are awesome. The building itself is old but has been maintained to show case its magnificence. It is like a maze.

College in Marrakech. Very interesting to see how the boys lived while studying at the Islamic college. Very well preserved 130 dormitories. Cedar wood ceilings with intricate carvings. Tiles with Islamic inscriptions on the walls. Worth a visit.
Great architecture. This is a beautiful example of moorish tiles int he traditional blue, yellow, cream tile colours. There is fantastic cedar designs and the study cells are awe inspiring.
Interesting. This Madrasa is a museum having been closed in 1961. Interesting to see how the students lived and something of the lives they led

Nice architecture, small place. It was only 10 dirham more to visit this place if you bought the ticket in conjunction with the Museum de Marrakech, and for 10 dirham more it's worth it. The architecture is interesting and the top floor was fun to take pictures in (i.e. looking out the window while someone else takes your picture from below).Overall the place is small, and you can be in and out in 15 minutes, really. There's not a whole lot to see, but I recommend it. Nothing negative to say about the place, so I rate it an excellent.
More to see than the other sites. Having visited a number of sites around Marrakesh this was by far the best . Beautiful and very interesting

Interesting not a wow site. The madrassa is a good historical site with wonderful tile and wood work inside. You can also get a ticket to the museum for 10dh more and is located nearby. The path from the square thru the souk to the Madersa is a small challenge, good luck.
One of the great sights of Marrakech. The Madrasa has been beautifully restored and is a reminder of Marrakech's great past, evoking the Alhambra in Grenada.

nice introduction to Moroccan architecture. We bought entrance to both the Madrasa and the museum nearby. Wonderful examples of mosaic and plaster work and painted ceilings. Much of it very well restored. Worth the fee and 45 minutes.
Lovely Architecture. Worth a visit ... lots of tourists there whereas we hadn't seen many around Marrakech so maybe they go there on trips.

History of Love. That miracle object remind in excellent state with beautiful garden, colours inside and furniture, windows etc. Very qalificated guide told us interesting story about love from that time. The visit was on november 2004

Great building full of history. Nice architecture, interesting history, cheap entry.
Lots of photo opportunities. Gets busy so early in day best.

Nice building. Large very ornate building with intricate carvings. Previously a school, has lots of student very basic rooms. It would have been nice and helpful if there was an information leaflet. Even if some of the wall information was in English, that would have helped.
interesting and well preserved. very interesting and relaxing, well preserved, keeps it ancient atmosphere, nice decoration in the ceilings and in the arches around the pool

Nice Medersa, nice details. Nice place, full of details, very well conservated. It is worth a visit.
Do not miss the upper flor with the rooms where you have a nice view from the building.
An insight. Not much info on site but worth the entry fee. It is included in a ticket for the museum near by. A real eye opener as the life in an old religious school. Great architecture.

Fantastic.. Simply breathtaking from the moment you turn into the main courtyard. The building is amazing. This was for me the best site we visited in Marrakech. Cheap cheap to get in, just the 10Dh. No guide needed just stroll about, have a lazy sit down in the sunshine. A must must visit.

Beautiful architecture, go early. We arrived shortly before 11am and pretty much had the place to ourselves, but within 20-30mins, we had several tour groups and it got very crowded (and it was during low season).
Very nice courtyard with a lot of beautiful detailed carving work, and can visit the little rooms upstairs as well, but the total visit can be 30-45mins.
Stunning. Great insight to historic Islamic academia. Amazing art work - so intricate and detailed. Did not dislike anything - thought it a privilege to be there.
Nice. Not knowing anything about this place we walked in. Some great photos here. That's about it. Would have been better Ada tour with a guide.

very nice and interesting. possibly visit it with a guided tour- we have seen similar building in the south of Spain so it looked quite similar- still beautiful but definately for someone that has never seen this type of architecture its a must see

Jewel of Marrakech. As the fat tyre man says, this wonderful building makes the journey worthwhile in itself. It's quite old (16th-century) and well preserved. It's also in an interesting area with both souks and more open streets. The museum is worth a visit on the joint ticket and has a nice cafe but looks gaudy and restored when compared with the madrassa.

Intricate Inspiration. So many of the monuments in Morocco seem similar, yet each has its own rewards. You almost need to be a student of Islamic architecture and décor to understand the subtle difference between periods.Rebuilt in 1564 to show his devotion to Allah and re-establish Marrakech as a center of Islamic study, Moulay Abdallah spared no expense renovating this koranic school to house 900 hundred students. We found the stark simplicity of the students’ dorms overlooking the intricately decorated courtyard very interesting to explore and could see how their studies could be inspired by such beauty created by man in tribute to Allah.

Interesting building. The carvings are interesting and the building is a pleasant place to be. The students accommodation is extensive and was interesting but there was very little information about the Madrasa or who was educated there
Great architecture!. The tile work, carved cedar wool and plaster work is beautiful. Very fascinating to see how the school was run. Worth a visit, not too time consuming.

wonderful insight. There is a joint entry ticket with Museum of Marrakech, which is in close proximity. The madrassa has interesting architecture and it is amazing how small the class rooms are. There was a young student practicing the very basics of Arabic calligraphy, which was an adorable sight.
Gives interesting insight. Huge building which has had some restoration. Close to the Museum of Marrakech and a joint ticket is good value
Stunning Architecture. Definitely worth a visit most beautiful architecture I have seen in Marrakech and that is saying something. Also great place to take time out from the souks
It's worth a visit.. The architecture is stunning. Very interesting, going with a guide would be better. If you go to Marrakech you cant' miss it.
High entry fee and not too much to see. Entry fee is much higher (50MAD) than for other sites (free or 10MAD). The building has nice architecture but fully empty
Truly Enlightening!. To know this place is to know Classical Civilization. Art, Science, Mathematics, Fashion, Medicine, Architecture.
Beautiful and interesting building !. This is well worth a look. Very near the Museum of Marrakech and you get a joint entry ticket for both. Beautiful tiled surfaces everywhere.
Architecture jewel. It is the best example of the architectural style of old Marrakech, with cedar carving and tile and plasterwork carving.
Must see in Marrakesh. By far the most beautiful place to see inside Marrakesh. The architecture of the interiors displaying mixture of intricate plaster and wood work were amazing.

Wonderful carvings but little on what life in the Madrasa would have been like. The carvings are outstanding no doubt but you are going to see a lot of carving in Marrakech. The students accommodation was interesting in terms of its small size and sometimes lack of windows. I would have liked some information on what life in the Madrasa was like for the students - who was educated there; at what age did they join; when and how did they leave, to do what; was there a hierarchy for the rooms, etc? It seems to me over the ages many religions have taken young people, often from poorer back grounds and educated them in their doctrine - certainly the Catholic Church did this in Ireland and often they left once they could with their qualifications, often as teachers. I would like to have known more about the people who lived here.
Great building, but couldn't find the museum. Definitely worth a visit, but don't bother paying the extra 10D for the museum, we couldn't find it!

A moment to reflect.... A curious insight into what's behind the walls within the medina.Ornate and intricate facades greet you within the Central courtyard.Student bedrooms are many and basic, a reminder of what they are truly there for.Purchase a combined ticket with the Museum of Marrakech for maximum value, located but 50 metres away.A pleasant venue for escaping the rigours of the souk and taking a moment to reflect.

The jewel of Marrakech. This is the 'must see' in Marrakech. It ranks with the greatest expressions of Muslim art and the whole place is a fascinating insight into the life of a quranic school. Met a couple just leaving Marrakech who hadn't been. Thought it sounded dull. Foolish, now they will have to return!!

Fabulous interiors. This was well worth a visit, looks nothing from the outside, but like so many buildings in Marrakech was fabulous inside. Beautiful intricate plaster and woodwork, lovely interior courtyard with a pool that sadly was empty when we visited.

Clean uncluttered history.. this is a beautifully preserved school for Islamic students. The bedrooms are spartan whilst the craftsmanship shown in the fabric of the building id breathtaking. It costs little to enter especially when coupled with entry to the Marrakesh Museum. I'm not sure of the function of the pool in the centre of the courtyard, perhaps to be used in the summer. Really worth a visit.
very average. Worth a visit, the family and kids loved it. Architecture good to look and explore, not a lot else more to do. I was a bit bored in all honesty.

Wonderful architecture. Overall I would recommend this highly on a trip to Marrakesh. The ancient university / college is set around a courtyard and you can wander around all the student accommodation. I would recommend you bring a guide book or a tour guide as there is very limited information to read.

A Wonder To Behold. A beautiful stunning monument just walk around the main courtyard, the prayer hall, look into the student cells and take in the Ablutions Basin. If you love looking at Moroccan designs this is the place for you, also 60dh for both monuments this one and Marrakech museum what a great deal.

Exquisite Islamic art. If asked beforehand whether I wished to visit a Koranic school I might have declined but this building, hidden behind plain walls, is a superb example of the intricacies and delicacy of Islamic art. Although it is beautiful to wander round by yourself it is much improved by having a local guide to explain the history and symbolism of what you are seeing.

Fabulous! A must see!. Wow! what architecture. Definitely go there! The tiles carvings and plaster work are amazing. you can roam the building and see the dormitory rooms upstairs and enjoy the lovely views

Place Exudes Calm. What a beauty this site! A concern of incredible detail, everything is carved so fine so it's hard to look away! The place exudes calm ... a nice relaxing time that invites reflection. The place is under renovation, but the work is done very gradually and do not affect the beauty of the place. We did not have a guide.
As beautiful as expected. There are not so many things to do in Marrakech.This is definitly one of the things one HAS to visit. Period.
Special. Lovely place to visit. Takes you back in time. Very ornate plaster and wood detail. Gives you an idea of he history in Marrakech.

Beautiful building but I was left wanting. When in Marrakech....this was on of the short stay, tick list of things to do in Marrakech and, while I was impressed by the architecture, I was left wanting in terms of interpretation and visitor experience. There is little in the way of explanation, and the architectural features such as the pools and fountains are not shown off to their full glory. All in all, slightly disappointing.
Beautiful surprise. We weren't planning to visit this But is was a lovely surprise to find this beautiful piece of Maroccon history.
Worth the visit. Impressive building full of history. I would have enjoyed a bit more insight information but it was still very interesting.
Unique . Visit this colleague to appreciate Islamic education and architecture. Very quiet setting but beautiful art work to witness.

Always amazing to visit and relax!. Places of historical importance such as this college seem to be well looked after by the Moroccan government. The ex college has dozens of hallways and 130 student dormitory cells clustered around a courtyard richly carved in cedar, marble and stucco. The details in the carvings are just beyond words, the effort put in is amazing, even the wooden ceiling has intricate patterns painted in the most out of sight places! I'm sure it wasn't nice to live in the college at the time but I wouldn't mind staying there if they were ever turned into a type of hostel!
Beautiful old building. This old Koranic school in the Medina is simply gorgeous, the wood carvings are exceptional and a visit is definitely worth it.
nothing special. i was a bit disappointed with this building, very plain, no water running.The building lacks colour and should be kept more alive

Worth seeing. Beautifully carved plasterwork and woodwork, also lovely tiled patterns. An interesting historical monument showing where Koranic theology students lived and studied for several centuries.

Interesting place to visit. This school/university is right next to the museum. The architecture and carving on the walls etc are an amazing display of Moroccan culture, and well worth the visit. Doesn't take long to stroll through the main courtyard and through the dorm rooms.It only costs 10 dh. You can get a package ticket to visit the museum next door but I don't really think its worthwhile unless you have time to spare. Just visit this place and go to the Souks
interesting. visit to a madrasa ... good photo opportunity with lots of angles and light falling... interesting to see the accommodation for scholars of the past
Beautiful example of a Madrasa. Although tricky to find (like the Museum of Marrakech) the Ben Youssef Madrasa is a charming well preserved building with countless unique rooms to explore.
Inspiring. Everything to like. Much as been written. Very much a part of the history of the Badii and Bahai palaces and the tombs. Do it!

Must place to understand Muslim education. Its architecture is amazing and in my opinion it's a necessary step to understand moroccan culture. Inside you would easily imagine how the student lived in this "schools". There are some areas closed to the public but in general you can see almost all rooms.Specially indicated if you have some free time in your travel and you want to do something cultural.

Extraordinary architecture. The madrasa is one of three sites close by (Marrakech Museum and Koubba being the other two).The woodwork, carving and stonework is amazing. If you don't like history and architecture this is not for you, but if you are into the way people lived in the past there will be enough ghosts to keep you happy.The madrasa is on two floors and consists of a major courtyard surrounded by a never ending series of rooms which once housed some 900 students aged between 12 and 18.The workmanship is extraordinary. Zoom in close with your camera for some stunning photos.Toilets are available and 'western' and clean.The rooms are similar, but have fun trying to work out which ones the rich lived in and which ones the poor.lGet a combi ticket to cover the other sites as well.By the Koubba there is a small cafe to get some mint tea.
Intricate tile work and interesting architecture. This is an old school, which is now empty except for the building which we enjoyed looking at, especially the the tile and the elaborate arches.
Incredible architecture. We stumbled upon this place and we weren't planning to go but we did and we're glad we did, it's beautiful and full of history, worth a visit.

Peaceful amazing architecture . The beauty of this place is in the intricate details. The architecture is stunning. The delicate carvings and colourful tiles. We came here as part of a guided tour through the medina and as with many places here it is well hidden and what greets you on the other side of an all but inconspicuous door is breathtaking.

Interesting but preferred the Palais el Bahais. Beautiful architecture and craftsmanship albeit all neutral colours. It boasts there are 132 cells/bedrooms but once you have seen one you have seen them all. Not a lot to see to be honest and charging 50Dh is overpriced compared to the experience of visiting Palais el Bahia which again has stunning morrocan design but much more of it to see and in glorious colours. Bit disappointed.
Interesting.... An interesting enough place - worth a stroll around - buy the combination ticket with the museum - you can get around both in half a day.
a must see!. beautiful, a must see. The architecture with all the detailed tiles and craftsmanship was incredible.
quite spectacular. very much worth visiting, it gives you an idea of also what has been lost over the centuries. a beautifully decorated space.

Interesting visit. This is a great place to visit, especially because it's so cheap and so beautiful. You can pick up a local tour guide inside for 20dhs who is very educational but just make sure they speak English as many only speak French/Arabic!
Must see!. Absolutely stunning interiors, very well preserved. Gives you an excellent glimpse of student life several centuries ago.
very good place. suggestive place, all small rooms are really singular. the atrio is a piece of typical architecture. do not miss

Most beautiful place. I loved the Ben Youssef Madrasa so much I came twice during my 6-day trip to Marrakech. One of the most beautiful things I've ever seen. Recommend coming early or later in the day to avoid huge crowds. The history, the architecture, the colorful mosaics, cannot say enough. A must-see.
very beautiful building. pity they do not offer any sort of audio guide. It would be nice to understand better the life syle of the students in that building.

Beautiful and interesting. We visited the Madrasa on a rainy Sunday morning on a combined ticket with the Marrakech Museum. The Museum was not as interesting as we thought and we enjoyed this building much more. It was getting busy but with the downstairs and upstairs area there was plenty of space for people to spread out. The student rooms upstairs with their little windows and interesting layouts were a great hit with out little boy. Overall a bit of Marrakech history you should not miss

Well worth a visit. The architecture of this ancient Quran school is amazing. Lots of steps to climb (so not suitable for wheelchairs), but a lovely way to spend a couple of hours wandering around here and the nearby Marrakesh Museum.
One of the few 'must sees' in Marrakech. Probably the only accessible complete madrassa in Morocco and a sublime example of 16th century Saadian architecture.
Nice architecture. Nice place but it's difficult to appreciate it as there is not any furniture anymore and no guides who can tell you "some secrets" of the place

Great architectural experience. The Madrasa is an excellent example of Moroccan architecture and is fully accessible compare to many other places that we visited during our trip. Amazing to see the quality and design of a building conceived about five centuries ago. I loved the design of the dorms.
Turn back time. I loved going from room to room. The beautiful tiles, the architecture is mind blowing. I loved it. You won't be disappointed with this place. A visit is a must.
just another mosque like structure. This red bricked structure is located in the medina . I don't think non muslims are allowed inside so cant say much more.

Really nice place. This site was a really nice stop over whilst sight seeing in Marrakech. Seeing the rooms where the individual students would have stayed gave you a great sense of the history of the sight. Definitely recommended.
