Nice house. Very cheap at 60 MAD to get into this plus the place next door. Lovely and intricate brickwork and lots of wee rooms to have a look around. A wee cafe at the entrance is good for a quick mint tea before going next door to the other museum.

A must see. Our family really enjoyed this visit, amazing building. Well worth the ticket price. We took some lovely pics here especially from the upper floor windows.
Had daughter's name written in Arabic.
Great architecture. Interesting to see how the students were accommodated and the fantastic architecture and amazing detail and skill of the decoration

Historically very interesting. We had a guide from the city who didn't elaborate more than you could read in a guidebook. A good nose around the building is a must and it is fascinating. Well worth a visit.
Madrasa marvel!. Really nice school visit. This was a beautiful visit and well worth the visit for the overwhelming sense of history of the place. Perfect place to get some nice photos.

Don't miss it. This was probably the most interesting place we visited in Marrakech, full of history. The building is absoutely facinating, lovely Moroccan architecture - make sure you take your camera. Go as early as you can, as it isn't a huge place and it is popular. It is also round the corner from the Musee de Marrakech and you can buy a joint ticket to get you into both, which is a good idea.

An interesting place to admire stucco work. Don't expected to see a palace as the Morocco concept of museum is not the same people have in Europe or North America. Anyway, it is worth a visit for the intricate stucco works and glaze tiles.
Historical & Insightful. Well worth a visit. Maybe get a guide so you can learn more about the history. It really gave us an insight on what life was like.
Must see architectural gem!. excellent place - worth the ticket price and few hours of exploring - if only we built schools and universities as beautiful as this these days!

A brief oasis. Stopped here while in souks, I highly recommend a 30-60 minute walk through to counteract the diesel fumes, noise, and mercantilism of the souks. It is peaceful here and one can see how others lived and studied ( no actual materials here) years ago.n

Beautiful architecture. Interesting view into Islamic study.. beautiful mosaics and carvings throughout the complex. Could be better maintained, but is nonetheless charming in its current state. Definitely worth a visit!

Must-see Quranic School. A beautiful school with a famous courtyard. The courtyard can be captured from many different angles including the first floor windows so make sure you take your camera. The central pool was being refurbished when we visited in Dec 2014 but it looked like it would be finished soon.
Must see in Marrakech. You really must see this madrasa. It is full of history and interesting architecture. Go with a local guide if possible.
A jewel. Beautiful decoration, architecture. If all schools looked like this it would be a pleasure...at least for the eyes.

Surprise hit of the tour!. Really beautiful example of Islamic architecture in Marrakech. A great place to wander around and explore at leisure. This was part of our guided tour and we were given 30 minutes which was nowhere near enough time to explore! A real maze of rooms with beautiful carvings and geometric window designs. A spontaneous game of "Hide and Seek" ensued, and this was the perfect location for it.This is a visit not to be missed!

Fabulous. Worth a visit, but did lack any information or explanations, a good guide book needed. Very beautiful mosaics and carvings but I found it quite disturbing that 900 students studied here - the small "cells" made it feel almost prison like! I found the entrance fee quite expensive compared to the palaces and Saadian tombs.

great for a half day visit. wonderful well preserved or restored historic Quranic teaching school set in the old town Medina of Marrakesh . Definitely worth the 4 pounds or so to see the very ornate fountains and court yards dating back from centuries aswell as to walk through the small corridors into the various preserved class rooms.
A must see. This is one of the best places to visit - don't expect lots of furniture and a museum feel but do expect to soak in the amazing architecture and atmosphere.
Beautiful Details. Paying a visit to this madrasa is definitely worth it. The tickets also allow you access to a famous Riad.
Stunningly beautiful. One of the must see sights in Marrakesh. The architecture and decoration are breathtaking. It only takes about half an hour to look round, so you won't lose much shopping time.
Great. Great historic house - excellent for photos and exploring at your own pace a good way to escape from being hassled!
Wonderful building. Amazing architecture and architectural detail. Interesting insight into conditions for students. Contains a very ordinary museum.
A definite to visit when in Marrakech. Interiors are amazing, bit of walk to get to as cars cannot easily access, my third visit and if I return to marrakech again, I'll visit again!
very interesting. This had once been a college and although it is in the process of being restored it is very interesting and you get a feel for how the students would have lived.

Excellent if you can find it. Situated 50 metres from the Marrakech Museum and access is via a combined ticket with the museum MAD60 or just MAD50 for the museum. Great site to appreciate the local history.

Fascinating building well worth a visit. Having seen similar examples in Iran, Syria and Libya this is a beautifully preserved example. Some lovely carvings and stonework. A peacefull escape in middle of Marrakech
A must see in Marrakesh. If you want to experience part of Morroco's history you have to visit. A very well preserved medersa, which can be even more interesting if you have a guide to explain...

Overrated. It's worth seeing, but don't buy into the hype that it's the most important thing to see in Marrakesh. There's little / no signage and or information about the place, and it has an abandoned, spooky vibe.
beautiful. beautiful place and a nice quiet break from the busy streets! worth a look around and isn't expensive
An outstanding gem!. The best part of the medina is this gem, tucked away amongst the alleys. Beautifully preserved and maintained this is a must for anyone visiting Marrakech
A stunning building. Don't expect National Trust style preservation, supervision and information (or tea rooms) - but do visit this stunning building. Try and get there early before the crowds...
The best attraction in Marrakech. We liked the Medersa the most, much more than the Palaces and the Tombs. Intricate mosaic, and a wonderful atmosphere, in this place of learning.

Worth a visit.. Did not know what to expect but spent over an hour an a half looking around. The architecture and mosaics around the building were just breath taking. Very cheap to get into and worth every penny.
Beautiful. This is a lovely, quiet spot to explore. The artwork is stunning - floor to ceiling designs and gorgeous internal views from the upstairs windows. It's a nice glimpse into the past.

STUNNING BEAUTY!!. What a spectacular place: its cedar carvings are breathtaking; its peaceful atmosphere is inspiring..and it is HUGE!! We visited each cell, room, stair and kept being astonished by their beauty and simplicity!!! We bought combined tickets for the Medersa and the Marrakesh Museum for 60 Dh per adult. Highly recommended!!!!

A place of tranquil beauty. This madrasa is a place of beauty; a wonderful showpiece for the intricacies of Islamic mosaic art and carving. The skill and artistry is breathtaking and the calmness that we experienced in each of the scholarly cells, seven on each level, surrounding a light filled atrium, was very relaxing. My only reason for not giving it four stars is the lack of signage and information.
Beautiful. We were told that this is the closest that non-Muslims get to seeing the inside of a mosque. It has beautiful architecture and is very atmospheric
Koranic School. Was worth seeing, large property with lots of small rooms for the students. Kept wondering how many they put in each room. Nice tile work in the traditional style.

Definitely go to Ben Youssef!!. Visited Ben Yousef Madrassa last week whilst in Marrakesh. Well worth the visit and it is coupled with the Marrakesh Museum, so you can buy one ticket to cover both sites (60 dirhams per person). The building is just exquisite and the stucco carvings on the walls is some of the best I have seen. If you visit the city make sure you allocate an hour or two to visit this site...you will not be disappointed.
amazing. its an amazing place to visit, the architecture is breathtaking, make sure you visit the museum as well,
Beautiful and interesting. For those with imagination, the daily life for the Koran students comes alive here. Many beautiful mosaics as well.
Glorious past. Rather expensive entry fees. Worth to see the old style buildings and life style of students in the old days. The accompanying museum is not worthy.
This was an interesting site.. Ease of access. Beauty of site. Cultural value.Intriguing situation.proximity to other landmarks.There was not much information.

What a place. Believe 900 young studens were learning Koran in this Koran-school living in tiny cells. The tilings are beautiful and well kept and stucco-carvings amazing. You must visit the Marrakech museum nest door with the combined ticket.
Interesting if you have a guide.. Without someone to explain the history and the regime within the Madrasa it is a fairly meaningless experience
Amazing. Very nice place in the middle of souq u will be amazed by the architecture and the way of building with very similar to Andalusia style of architecture

Had a glimpse...beautiful!. We saw only the outside as we were a little short on cash, but we had a glimpse on the entrance and it looked really beautiful; the exterior was really nice also. The entrance fee was 40 dirhams (€4) and 60 dirham if you wanted to visit the Marrakech museum, I think it would have been worth it.

Unbelievable architecture. This lovely building is in the center of the souk and not so easy to find but definitely worth your time. The building has lots of little rooms for the students and a lovely central courtyard.
Fascinating. Well worth the visit - and wonderful wood carvings... and it is amazing to know that it was still in use up to the 1960s...

Should be a must visit. This madrasa (school) is a splendid example of Moorish architecture. It was a school of theology with about 900 students studying the Quran. The main hall and courtyard is simply stunning no matter which direction you look. There is tile work, carved cedar, carved stucco, calligraphy, brass lights, and the list goes on...all stunning. There is a small pool in the center of the courtyard. There is access to the dorms on the second floor and some have windows where you can look across the courtyard. Dorms are very small and very plain as well. I would really recommend going through this facility with a guide. They will provide information about the age of the building, the purpose of the building, the various modes of architecture, as well as explanations about the calligraphy present on the walls and pillars. If you are stuck as to how to hire a guide, I would recommend talking to the owners of the riad or hotel where you are staying. Some stairs are involved if you wish to visit the dorms so if you have health or physical limitations, just visit the main floor.
must go. excellebt design n architect, and bought handwritten calighraphy, connected is art musem go there too

Well worth the effort to find this madrasa - gorgeous building !. Located in the heart of the Medina this old Koranic school is a gorgeous example of Islamic Morrocan archetecture.There is a large central open space with a shallow pool in the middle - the lower section of the walls are covered in glazed tiles, above these gorgeous carved koranic scripts.We visited Madrassas in Fez and one could only visit the middle space - here one has the opportunity to see the small rooms the students occupied - there are some reasonable sized rooms with views onto the centeral courtyard area and others more akin to cells ! Fascinating to wander around the corridors and rooms.Our favourite attraction in Marrakesh.

A very very nice architectural site!. A very very nice architectural site! I went here with a friend back in 2006 while touring Marrakech ... I still have wonderful pictures of the reliefs and architecture. Very beautiful and a wonderful insight into the way Moroccans lived in the past.
lovely place to visit. A definite must on your to visit list. Well worth the few Dirham they charged to enter, how wonderful to get some idea of how they lived.

Be in & out before 11am. Quite interesting walking round this building which was built in 1570 & founded in the 14th century.Some interesting architecture to take pictures of if that sort of thing floats your boat. It stopped being a Koranic school in 1960.Might have had a loo but we could not find it. loo's are few & far between (be warned).We had seen what there was of interest in 30 minutes.Not one of the most riveting places in the world.Be in & out before 11am as it get too crowded after that time.

Impressive yet , no information . Visited here during a week in December. Saw some good reviews do gave it a go. The building itself was very impressive, and clearly an effective, quit, monastery like place of study for young Muslims through the centuries. Thus said, with no guides, no English material (though little French or Arabic either) as a tourist attraction it is under performing. Such a shame, as such an impressive building with impressive history is an easy sell.
Turn back time. I loved going from room to room. The beautiful tiles, the architecture is mind blowing. I loved it. You won't be disappointed with this place. A visit is a must.

A wonderful place to visit in Marrakech. A wonderful place to visit in Marrakech is the Madrasa youssef ibn Tachfine, is is actually well maintained and recently fixed up. While there isnt much in the way of signage, the space is quite beautiful to pass up! Definitely worth the trip. Near the Photo museum and Le Foundouk restaurant. Medina of Marrakesh
Fantastic tiles and rooms. I pretended I was a college student 800 years ago! I was organizing parties and gatherings as we went from room to room! LOL
Fascinating. Fascinating insight into Moroccan history. Lovely mosaics, and good value when linked with the museum ticket.

Worth the Search. Impressive architecture and great insight into life of scholars. Took a taxi which dropped us where the road ended and passageways began. The signposting was erratic and we got lost. Think only way to avoid this might be to hire a caleche (horse-drawn carriage) which can pass down most passageways. Quite busy. Doesn't take long to look around. Cheap, especially on a joint ticket for the Marrakech Museum

Fantastic bit of history. You really need to travel with a guide to get the most out of this place, really good to see how people studies, their rooms, eating facilities - really awesome of your into that kind of thing!

back in time. we went to this attraction on a recommendation. it was reasonably priced to get in. the visit was immensely enjoyable .The architecture was incredible. it is a place of reflection and a reminder of an era long gone and I think much missed.if you can get there through the souks, you wont be disapointed
Lovely. Really nice architecture. Underrated. Romantic. I could have just sat there for a long while. Lots of little detail and design. Quite fabulous!
Elegant seat of learning. A chance to see inside an ancient seat of learning Muslim-style. Beautiful decor and an interesting historic building.
Very interesting. Not always sure what we were looking at but wandering about and sticking our noses into rooms was fun. Building was fascinating.

Very pretty. Went with the thompson tour guide azizzi think I spelt his name right. He was awesome. So good at explaining the history. The patterns were beautiful. It was a mosque but later became a school.
Beautiful place. It's packed with tourists but the architecture was lovely to see. Very elegant. Go with a guide to get the history behind it.
Steeped in history. You can feel how old this place is! Well worth a visit when you're tired of the bustle of the medina!

Interesting visit. Visted here as a must see attraction of Marrakech. It's worth a visit and the dual ticket with the museum make it more of an interesting day. unique building and there's guides offering services (for a fee of course!) If you require more information.

An interesting stylish building. It is plain but also has beautiful wood carved decorations and a nice court yard. Try to get there when there is a lull in the number of tourists. There are stairs and the corridors are narrow, but definitely worth a visit. I believe it was in active use as dorms till the 1970s

Worth a visit. An interesting visit to this school, well preserved. Lovely architectural sights. Seen as part of a Discovering Marrakech tour. The school was in use until 1962. You can see the rooms occupied by teachers and students studying the Koran

A Step Back In Time. Was stunning to see a former 'school' in such great condition.
It gave you a true feeling of what it was like to be taught and to teach there.
The building's interior is stunning.

Beautiful Space, Worth a visit. Unlike many 'museums' and 'cultural sites' in Marrakech the Madrasa is actually well maintained and recently fixed up. While there isnt much in the way of signage, the space is too beautiful to pass up! Definitely worth the trip. Near the Photo museum and Le Foundouk restaurant.
Fine site to visit. I tend to not like to go to such old sites/museums but it was definitely worth seeing. I stayed about 10 minutes.
Amazing architecture. Able to explore at length. Lots of architecture to look at and get lost in, not pressurised to be told about it from the teachers who are on hand for a guided tour.

Beautiful and fascinating.. Although the Ali Ben Youssef mosque is (understandably) closed to non-Muslim visitors, the old Koranic school is an interesting site to visit. Beautifully decorated with Zelij tiling, and also thankfully not too crowded as we visited in November; it was good looking around the old students' 'cells' as well. Definitely worth a visit.

This came as an add on visit to the museum. Whilst visiting the museum as this was near by and at a slight additional cost we visited here but there is not that much to see really although it has been nicely restored and is a cool and calm place to hang out for a short while

Not much to see but well worth the visit. . Seeing the old Koranic school was nice, the architecture is wonderful, however, the rooms are all the same so once you've seen one, you've seen them all!! Paid extra to get into the museum, which in itself was worth it, saying that we nearly missed the entrance to this part! Another example of the hand crafted workmanship I came to love about the place. Fair warning - avoid the 'guides' at all costs, they sit outside this place to trap you into going to the tanneries.

Worth searching for.. Not easy to find as it is deep within the Medina but well worth the hunt. This old Koranic school is built around a splendid courtyard with the scholars dormitories above all of which can be visited. Even though the dormitories are empty, apart from the odd bed, you do get a sense of what it would have been like to be a student there. I got lost after my visit and had to pay a local lad to get me back on track so worth making sure you remember the route.

Stunning building. The madrasa is a beautiful building which will surprise you step by step, an architectural wonder which is worth visiting while in Marrakech. Very fairly priced, also ideal for a large group.

Stunning architecture. I visited the Al-Attarine Madrasa in Fez, but enjoyed this one more for it's architecture and ability to explore the former dorm rooms upstairs. The Moorish architecture is stunning to photograph in the relfection of the inner pool.
A definite Must See. A little hard to find, but fun walking through the souks! Wonderful architecture. next best thing to visiting the Alhambra!

Amazing architecture.. The architecture here is fantastic. Beautiful fretwork walls and porticoes. Well worth a visit when combined with the nearby museum for 60Dh. A must see for any culture vulture visiting Marrakech.
classic Moroccain. beautiful and well worth a visit as well as the Museum which is about 2 minutes away. the mosaic tiling was fantastic

Nice , bit not mind blowing. The Madrassa wasnoe of the few places we really wanted to visit. The entry price was good and it was interesting to see the design and the old student rooms. However we weren't blown away. Perhaps our lack of knowledge of Islamic culture is to blame.

Beautiful, interesting - a work of art!. Totally absorbing! The architectural monument was a work of art and so interesting to be able to visit the students dormitories. Definitely worth taking a couple of hours to visit especially with one of the guides for a total explanation and understanding. To be recommended.
Something you wouldn't normally see. Worth the visit - a real insight into another era and religion - good if not great restoration however an amazing space in the middle of the city!

Madrasah. is the name of the educational institution in Islamic countries, to study of the Islamic religion. This particular in Marrakesh is a wonderful place, the largest Medrasa in all of Morocco.It's a beautiful example of the art and architecture. When entering the main courtyard, you will see the wonderful jade green tiled pool. Go very early, so you and have the best shots of the shining marble, carved cedar wood, lace-like stucco pillars/columns that look like marble.
another world. magnificent inner courtyard with beautiful architecture and design. impressive were all these tiny little rooms, where the students had to live.
Beautiful Medersa. We have seen other medersa's as well (in Fes), but this one was definitely the nicest! So if you don't have much time in Marrakech, you must surely visit this Medersa.

Beautiful inside. What a great place architecturally inside - worth having alook but won't take up much time and you can get a combined ticket to see the museum next door which a again is a quick visit in my view.
Amazing design and architecture. Wow what a surprise to walk into! I was blown away at the intricate designs on the walls, doors and more! It was quiet and definitely worth a visit when in Marrakech.

Impressively decorated place of Ali Ben Youssef. The joint ticket for this palace and the Marrakech museum were very good value at 60DH (6€), and only 50m apart. Loved the intricate mosaics and carvings - amazing place.

a real highlight of our visit. Set in the midst of the souk and market area, this historically important madrassa, centuries old and now a major tourist attraction, is a very beautiful, peaceful place to visit. It gives only a tiny glimpse of life in these traditional koranic schools. The building is ornate and the architecture is very beautiful, offering a sense of the spiritual. It stands out even more juxtaposed against the busy, narrow lanes, markets and souks nearby. Do visit, but buy your coffee elsewhere, the little coffee shop at the entrance/exit charges over £2 per cup!
beautiful building. stunning mosaics and carving in this school. Typical roof designs that will take your breathe away. Well worth the visit.

Interesting but not entirely sure why so much fuss?. this was an interesting place (50Dh each to visit - ie five times what we were charged to visit Saadian Tombs and Bahia Palace respectively, seems odd) but can't quite understand why so much fuss was made of it as it is an unused religious school for Muslim boys / men with very little of the history explained or set out, while it has examples of lovely craftsmanship, there are clearly better examples around the city ( and elsewhere in the Islamic world - visit Uzbekistan for some incredible hidden gems for example). If there is a significance I have missed, please enlighten me....

An Architectural Gem. One of the most beautiful Islamic buildings I have ever seen. The carving is exquisite and if you can get in before the crowds it is a really serene experience. A must see if you are in Marrakesh, but get there soon after opening.

Big place, no information, guides hustling for business. Just about worth a visit, but poor museum by world standards. Once you have a couple of small rooms then you have seen the place. Handy toilet. Bahia Palace a better and cheaper place to see good mosaics and woodwork

Not much to see. It's a beautiful building and it's fun to see but I missed some signs/texts in english that told a bit about the rooms which made it a quick visit, but it's not expensive which makes it okay that the visit is short.
we loved this place really amazing architecture you must visit. we loved this place really amazing architecture you must visit. so much detail in the plaster work quite incredible

Beautiful building but little information. This is one of the camera worthy building in Marrakech. The only challenge is that there are no signs describing what anything is. I know there is so much more to this building than just the views.

The most stunning display of Islamic art outside the Alhambra. The largest of all Morocco's medersas (Koranic colleges) is simply breathtaking. Outside you have no idea of what will hit you when you get to the end of the long entrance corridor - cupolas of carved cedar, exquisite stucco workings and fabulous mosaic patterns in tiles. The central courtyard - similar to Patio of the Lions in the Alhambra - is one of best examples, if not THE best example, of Saadian art and architecture. Fantastically photogenic place - it's also great for taking photos of you and your friends appearing at the little windows of the students' cells giving onto the court.
Worth visiting. Thsi is a great example of the architecture and way of life in Marrakech, would certianly recommend a visit but not necessarily to the museum as well.
Amazing. Well worth a visit you will not be disappointed. Beautiful carvings, interesting history. A peaceful place in the heart of the medina.

Peaceful and beautiful.. After getting lost in the hustle and bustle of the souks this attraction was much welcomed. I found this history fascinating and it was nice to be able to fully explore an Islamic building. The mosiacs were beautiful and I could not believe how small the students rooms were. The atmosphere is so calm and peaceful and I highly recommend a visit.
A souk is a souk. We spent a couple of hours there. Colorful market and locals very nice and friendly, but nothing exceptional for me,
A lesson in history. A must visit for all. A religious school of the past with some amazing architecture and mosaic walls and floors.
Peaceful. Getting here through the souk rewarded us with some peace and quiet away from everything. Excellent opportunity for pictures.
Beautiful. To see the ancient rooms of the students was breath taking and it doesn't even look 100 years old! Cheap and a real pleasure in a bustling city! Highly recommended

A Surprising little gem!. We went here as an add on to our ticket to the Musee de Marrakech but enjoyed seeing this intriguing site more than the museum. The ornate details, inner courtyard and seeing all the tiny rooms where the students were housed was so interesting. The mosaics and ornately carved woodwork is very beautiful and the structure has been nicely restored.
medersa. this building was an old university. a place were you walk around for hours, peaceful harbour!area around is worth exploring too!
Interesting visit. Interesting insight into the local culture. Could have done more by way of explaining how the place worked.
Visit to to the museum. Definitely a must but if only there was some information in English. Visually stunning. Felt privileged at being able to visit such a wonderful building.
Beautiful. Well worth a visit, a beautiful place to have a break from the medina, tickets for the this and the museum get a discount
Stunning Moorish architecture. Definitely worth a visit for the stunning tiles, marble, cedar wood, stucco in a former Islamic college.
Beautiful building. I liked the building and the decorations. If you buy a ticket for the Medersa and the Museum you will get a discount.

Average. Found this Madrasa quite average, just like most historical monuments in Marrakech. Probably because I have seen similar but better monuments in India. Anyhow, if you are in the city, not a bad option to spend some time here while walking through the Medina.

Beautiful but crowded!. We eventually found this place it is very very beautiful with ornate decoration blah blah blah ,but thats it...there is nothing else in it to see. Upstairs are just a maze of small corridors and the place was packed so you cant enjoy it or get a decent photo without zillions of other tourists in it!! they pour you in and get you out!! Ticket gets you into another waste of time place..the museum of Marrakech! 60 euros each including over age 12 kids! No info...guide at extra cost!! OF COURSE..THIS IS MOROCCO!!
a real jewel. Wonderful architecture and detail. a very interesting visit. it is a window into the great culture that developed in Morroco.
Impressive architecture. Beautiful and interesting. Used to be a theological school until the 1960s. The courtyard is stunning but the cells the boy slept in are not. Great photo opportunities!
Interesting. Fantasic detail inside this Madrasa - mosaic and details on doors and walls. Worth a visit to see what it would have been like for those studying at that time

Fantastic Architecture..Mosaics And Plasterwork..A Must See. Visited the medrassa yesterday and was NOT disappointed at all. For the combined entrance price of 60 dhiram for here and the Marrakech Museum you are treated to excellence! From the decoration over the entrance portico you are dazzled with colour..mosaic and calligraphy. The colours..patterns and craftsmanship are to be seen. Go upstairs and visit one or all of the 132 students rooms...some different than others. Even the landings and passage ways are interesting. The window arches are a work of art...overlooking the courtyard. Careful of the stairs...they tilt forward on the way down...off putting. You can easily wander round in 20-30 mins...longer if you want to sit and drink it in. Certainly worth the visit....go see!!!
Stunning. Another brilliant example of architecture and mosaics combined with a rich history. I visited twice in my 4 day stay.
Amazing Buildings. This was an old Islamic college. The architecture is beautiful and its carved ceilings archways are amazing. Well worth seeing

Fascinating.. Looking at the students rooms was interesting but the central courtyard was beautiful. It takes about half hour to see it all then go on to the Marrakech museum (with a combined ticket) to enjoy more beautifully decorated walls and enormous Moroccan style chandeliers.

Beautiful building and fantastic history. For 60 MDM you will find yourself surrounded by beautiful mosaics and intricate carving within a cool atmosphere only downside is if you go late when the tour buses have arrived and it becomes packed with all of us tourists. Take the time to climb the stairs and see where the students lived and enjoy the spectacular views of the pool.You will also be able to enter the museum area which has some beautiful artefacts from the Berber and Jewish traditions. The is also oddly a lovely courtyard area with some really interesting modern art to balance it all out. Yes there's a toilet too for 3 mdh. It is a little hard t find and its more likely that you will just happen upon it whilst wandering in the souk - take the opportunity and go in for a spectacular surprise.

Stunning, magical, you feel the history. The Madrasa was on my list while staying in Marrakech and I was surprised positively. But I am fascinated ancient history and my feelings were based on the film "Medicus". Definitely worth to see and walk around inside.
Great Architecture. The journey to the place is fun - in the middle of the souk..its a relatively small location but very beautiful architecture with intricate carvings and inscriptions
Beautiful carvings. What a great place to spend an hour or two. The architecture is fantastic, definitely worth the hassle of finding it.
Combine with Museum. Stunning art and design work decorating the walls and floor. Like a Tardis through a small door into a massive building as is common in Marrakech. Museum next door.

A Beautiful Building. Even after two weeks of beautiful Moroccan buildings, this one was a standout. We came with a tour guide (khalidamor@gmail.com--expensive, but worth it), which is a big help for imagining what life was like for the 900-odd Koranic scholars, ages 16 and up, packed into this building.

awesome, neck breaking art work. Loved this place, think it was my favourite out of all the places we visited.
Beautiful architecture and interiors together with the tranquility of the place
Beautiful Architecture. Really lovely space with beautiful architecture and worthwhile with the combo ticket with the Museum of Marrakech for Dh60.
Stunning.. Get a guide to take you around this old Koran school. The architecture is stunning and the history is interesting.

worth a visit. beautiful architecture and interiors together with the tranquility of the place is what you will find there. we enjoyed our visit although it wasn't as big as we excepted and didn't contain any exhibitions.

Beautiful but not the best. I guess people in Marrakech will see all the old buildings on show. This one is good but not the best. Although I personally think the palaces, medersa etc are better in Marrakech than Fes. That said I wouldn't miss any of them at 10dh entry fee!!
Lovely building. Almost no information in english about building/rooms. Easy to combine with visit to the Marrakech Museum.
Intresting. Another place well worth a visit. Historical interest, gives an insight into the history of the city, next door to the Museum of Marrakesh so easy to do both in a day.

Not a Comprehensive. Fascinating insight into a religious teaching institute, with it's Spartan accommodation cells of the students contrasting harshly with the beauty & craftsmanship of the finishings of the buildings interior. In contrast to UK schools, there was little apparent graffiti or damage. Save money by getting a ticket for both the Madrassa & the adjacent Museum of Marrakech at the same time (60 MDR instead of 50 each)

Beautiful break from the endless mace of Souks. Simply put: the Madrassa is stunning. Located in the North-Eastern end of the ever-confusing net of Souks in Marrakech (ask a Shop-owner from who you bought something for directions, DO NOT ask an unknown strangers as they might ask you for money for their services or follow the smell of the tanners which are in the same directions).The Madrassa is well preserved, beautifully intricate but lacks a certain depth. The lack of furniture makes it difficult to imagine what life must have been like for students in times gone past, but nevertheless, it conveys a sense of grand standing that one would associate with a place of religious teaching and learning. Definitely worth the time.

Back to the Scholars days. This beautiful Madrasa o Medersa will trasmport you back to the days when Morocco was one of he most prestigious places for students. Is very well preserved and is a geat journey back in time. A little difficult to find, but nothing that a good walking GPS cannot find. Dont miss this place.

Breathtaking. The decoration will knock you out. The size of the cells where the poor Islamic students were housed will bring tears to the eyes of anyone used to student accommodation at home. Always busy but well worth a visit you wont be disappointed
Impressive Islamic architecture. One of many beautiful buildings in Marrakesh. Worth going upstairs. Very tranquil. Try & visit when not too crowded.

this is one of my top choices. If i only had time to see one historical site, i would choose this one; the architecture is great, the space is great, for the curious, it's cool to investigate the student quarters, you get nice pictures here.You can get a joint ticket with the museum, which is good value,we walked up through the souk in the morning, visited the madrasa and the museum and checked out the jardin marjorelle in the afternoon, we walked up from the museum to get a taxi and the ride ws 30DH.

Wonderful site to visit. The best site we visited in Marrakech. I'm not usually one for sightseeing, but this was beautiful - gorgeous architecture. And its worth paying the extra to gain access to the Marrakech museum, partly for the architecture as the main hall is superb (less so the Pakistani modern art and random 20th century Moroccan artefacts).If you make one sightseeing visit in Marrakech, make it this one.

Not easy to find but worth a visit if you like Islamic Architecture.. We got a taxi here.It dropped us off at the end of an alleyway/souk and the driver pointed us in the general direction.There are signs but they aren't easy to follow.We ended up getting a 'local guide' who without asking took it upon himself to direct us and at the end of our journey asked us for a fee. In all honesty I don't think we would have found it ourselves,so good to take a map or familiarise yourself with the general area first. Once inside the Madrasa it was well worth the trip.You can also go upstairs and see where the students lived..Plenty of photo opportunities of this beautiful building.Plenty of crowds too.You can buy a joint ticket(which we did)to see the Museum of Marrakech nearby.The museum of Marrakech is easy to find from the Madrasa.For us the architecture & artwork was worth the visit.
Interesting Place. Not very big, but beautifully decorated, interesting to see. One can see how students used to live in those times

Well worth a visit. This is my favourite site to visit in Marrakech. It was under restoration for years but it is now completed and it is superb. The contrast in the beautiful courtyard between the zelige, cedar and marble is superb and each contain Arab calligraphy. The students ' cells' are fascinating and this is a 'must see' in Marrakech.
Faboulous. Worth every penny for the very small entrance fee! Created for students almost 500 years ago with 130 rooms
Must-see. Impressive decoration and architecture, nicely decorated, nicely refurbished, very quiet in the afternoon.

A Must Visit. If you only visit one site in marrakech then it has to be here. Stunning architecture and beautiful light for those who want to take photographs. Take some time to read up on the history too. Fascinating !!!
stunning architecture. The spiritual tranquillity and history & Islamic art oozed from the stunning carved plaster work and mosaics tiling.

beautiful. It's not the easiest to find but if you ask in the souk you will get directions, but keep asking along the way. We should have got a guide to explain the history behind this place, but nevertheless its really beautiful.

Great photo opportunities....nice place to while away a half hour. We purchased the double ticket to visit here and Marrakech museum. It was a nice place to while away a half hour. Great photo opportunities (send your partner upstairs to peep out of a window...it makes a great picture). They were holding a fashion photo shoot while we were here, complete with two stallions! A little crowded in the afternoon....perhaps arrive for opening to get better pictures (with fewer tourists).
excellent reconstruction of 14th cent madrasa. worth a visit. you can see the courtyard and the rooms where the students studied and lives. worth your time and it's 50 meters or so from the gardens

Simply Stunning. Visited this place on the recommendation of other Trip Advisor users and it was so worth it. The architecture is outstanding and a feast for the eyes. Not the easiest of places to find (along with the Museum of Marrakesh) which is practically next door but we just asked someone from the cafe were we had eaten lunch and they were very helpful. Stall holders will always try to misdirect you but just politely ignore them.

The nicest building we saw in Marrakech. In comparison to Paris and London there really isn't a great deal to see in Marrakech. However out of all of the sights we visited this was our favourite. A beautiful old building with intricate carvings/mouldings. The only downside was the lack of information in any other language than French. Luckily our guide book told us all we needed to know.
worth hiring a guide. The best feature of Marrakesh. The art and design are complemented by the history and culture. It helps one to understand the Islamic culture.

Beautiful building. The ceilings and the tile were simply amazing. There were many different designs. There were many beautiful frescoes. You need a guide so he can explain all about the building. Go early as it can get quite crowded. Well worth a visit.
NICE ARCHITECTURE!. Really nice architecture and good to see and know the history.I missed a guide, everything was in French...but other than that..i managed:-)
great architecture. great architecture , we went without guide, need English and Arabic commentary on displays. try to visit the museum as well

A beautiful gem in the heart of the city. Not easy to find. Our taxi driver dropped us off at the entrance of the souk and told us to walk straight for two minutes which turned into fifteen. However upon finding it, it was all worth it. Absolutely beautiful landmark, architecture and historical place of interest. A must see.

Fascinating - must go. The ascetic cell-like accommodation for the students of the madrasa was an eye-opener. This was a top seat of learning in its hey-day, yet its students lived in monastic austerity.
Spectacular. Try to go earlier...i was the first to enter and i got great pictures with no one.Great for kids to find all spaces and small rooms.
Very nice. This is a really nice find in the Medina... Very beautiful with amazing carvings and tiles. A bit difficult to find - down an alleyway.
Absolute must see. The most impressive architecture of the period and well restored.A very interesting excursion into the past history of Morocco.
Interesting. Lots of culture, Moroccan tiles, cheap to enter. Hard to find so ask someone. Worth visiting. Hot in the middle of the day but there are places to sit and rest and watch the world go by
Must see!. Good museum, great carving & tiles, Loved it. Not that easy to find but ask & someone will show you.

Fascinating. We visited the Madras on the recommendation of our Riad. It was fascinating and beautiful The architecture was interesting and gave my mother (the artist) an opportunity for some immediate sketching. Meanwhile we explored the many rooms where the up to 900 students used to be crammed in. In many ways this was like a european monastery, but with much more interesting decoration
Worthwhile history & architecture. The title says it all, but the lower courtyard and student rooms above are a lovely example of Moroccan architecture.

Islamic university open to all. I was taken here by my walking guide, who was very knowledgeable. It is adjacent to the Marrakech museum. You can see the dormitories that students shared, 3 to a room. There is much craftsmanship and the building is arranged around a rectangular pool. Hard to believe this lovely building is centuries old.

Amazing historical place to visit. The Medersa Ben Youssef is one of the most interesting monuments in Marrakech. Built in 1570, the médersa has been during more than four centuries an islamic student residence.
fabulous architecture. Peaceful, beautiful, very popular, so go as early as possible, when it's cooler and you have the place to yourselves.

Photographers' delight.... This is a lovely building that had relatively few visitors at the point we visited. As others have indicated, a little explanation in English would have been helpful. The unhindered access to all rooms is a plus, but be warned that many are very similar. It would be expensive to view in isolation, but the joint ticket with the Museum is workwhile and extends the visit to just over an hour.
Beautiful. Beautiful and historic place. It used to be a Medersa (Qu'ran school) and now it is a museum. Good location, right beside the Marrakech Museum.

Beautiful Medersa. For photographers, this truly is a real joy. The museum that is nearby is also worth visiting. You can get a joint ticket for 60dhm for the Museum and the Madrasa. It is fascinating to see how the school was laid out, and to explore all its corners and history. A real cultural experience in a beautiful building.

Beautiful. This old student dorm is near Jemma el fna and it's definately worth visiting with all the colors, mosaics and arhitecture. There is some entrance fee, but it's cheap and worth it. The history befind is is great.

Beautiful mosaics. You can see the main rooms where lessons took place plus go upstairs to see the various dormitory rooms. There is also a common washing area. It would have been more interesting to have one or 2 rooms staged to show a typical sleeping/ study area, provided with a sleeping roll perhaps and some books.

Interesting and photogenic. An interesting insight into Islamic teaching, although without any interpretation to help. In its unadorned state...no tarting up for the public...which is refreshing. For photographers, this is a real joy. Nearby museum is also worth a visit (joint ticket available) with plenty of rooms and soem good art. 1 hour for both.

A place to visit to discover what "islam" means. The Madrasa needs some work done in order to preserve the place or to turn it into a even more attractive place to visit. But, all in all, the Madrasa is a must-see because one is plunged into the spirit and architecture of islam and the precepts that are coming from a non-christian place to study the Q'ran and life.
Little expensive but ok. It's like all the madrassas but a llitle bigger and you can go up to see it from a windows. The ticket is a little expensive but it's ok....

Little bit let down.. I was let down by this attraction as I was told my so many people to visit it, however there was only 2 or 3 rooms, including the museum, worth looking at. Worth going to look at all the student rooms and for a bit of a photo op.

Expensive, but worth it. At 60DH it is not a cheap entry, and we were disappointed when we went around the museum section to find that all the descriptions of artefacts were only in Arabic and French. Surely enough English-speaking visitors go to make it worth their while adding a third language.Anyway, the exhibits are good and worth seeing, even if we couldn't make out what they were. However, when we went across to the school building, this made the entry fee worthwhile. It is fascinating to see how the school was laid out, and to explore all it's little corridors and corners. It would have been even better had there been explanations as to what everything was, but just wandering around was fun. A cultural experience.
Average - visit if you're passing. Liked the cells used by students moorish architecture.however, nothing special unless you're in to photography.

Beautiful building with interesting stories. A truely beautiful bulding and well worth a 15-30 minute visit even if your that interested. Would highly advise a guide or guide book to read more about the history of the place.
Breathtaking architecture. The architecture, the fountains, mosaics, arches, tiles, painted walls and wood work make the detail and the scale of this building truly impressive.
Smaller than i expected. Gives an interesting insight in to the history of such a place but there were no artefacts or pictures or furniture, just bare rooms

Get the museum or it's not worth it.. The other sights nearby like the two palaces were only 10dh, so a bit surprised that this was 50. 60 with the museum. It's a pretty place, but not a lot for the money, if you get the museum included though, it's really great, as the Madrasa itself is just a lot of empty rooms.There is absolutely no information in English here, just French and Arabic, so we had to look up what it actually was we had just seen after, that was a bit disappointing.
Very Authentic. It is great to see such amazing architecture, how student used to live in the school, where and how the studied.

If you've not yet visited a madrasa. In Morocco, non-Muslims aren't allowed in mosques (excepting Hassan II in Casa) so Madrasas are the way to go to see the gorgeous craftsmanship in religious buildings. This one is impressive for sure. That being said, if you've already been to Fes and seen the madrasas there, you've probably seen most of what you are likely to see here and are justified in skipping.
Beautiful building. And we read in our guide book that they had 900 students living in here! It would have been a tough life!

Interesting way of spending a few hours. Relatively cheap entry and some good photography possiblePaid the extra 10MAD for the combined ticket to visit the Marrakesh museum nearby which had not much in the way of displays, but the building itself is beautiful, relaxing and very peaceful

Worth a visit. It was OK and interesting to see a bit of Marrakech history but was not overwhelmed by the place. We stumbled on it as we were walking around city so did not have any great expectations.

Schooled!!!. We think we have it all worked out in the West but this incredible place which housed and educated 900 boys is a real humility lesson. The architecture and tangible simple way of life here when the school was open offer much to be admired.
Beautiful place. Hard to find and do not fall for scam on the way that it is closed. Really beautiful palace. Only 10DH to visit. Beautiful colours and architecture

Cultural hotspot in heart of Medina. We visited this place as part of a Souk tour so our entry fee was already arranged, however I think it only costs less than £5 to enter for adults. It's a really old school from the 1100s and it's kept in excellent condition. You can explore all of the old rooms upstairs where the boys used to sleep (as it was a boarding school) and the old architecture (Moorish, etc) has been excellently preserved.The only thing I would suggest is to have a bit more information dotted around about the Ben Youssef's history- we were lucky enough to have a guide with us but we could see people gravitating to him for information.

koranicschool. nice to see, but a little bit from all the same.
You see a lot of little rooms where the students work, study and sleep and that's it.
So after 20 rooms there comes another 20 rooms and thats for me too much.
But I'm glad that I have see it, for to understand this way of living

Absolutely stunning architecture. This medieval Koranic school is one of the best places to experience some of the architecture Morocco has to offer. The tile work is absolutely stunning, and it's nice to get off the street and explore this calm structure. If you pay 10 dirham, you can also get into the Marrakech Museum, which is worth seeing as well.
Must-see in Marrakech!. The best place to explore the amazing Moroccan architecture and intricate design features. I would rate this as the top attraction and a 'must-see' for any visitor.

Beautiful!. The decorations are almost everywhere and are absolutely fantastic! A place to be seen. There is a cumulative ticket that includes the medersa and the museum of marrakech. The complete visit takes about 2 hours. Both sites close at 6 p.m. so be sure to be there on time.

A beautiful wall-tiled haven. This is well worth visiting for half an hour or so, as you can duck out of the dusty streets and experience the calm coolness of its beautiful interior. Get a guide to take you if you can as the history of the place is interesting.

Well worth a visit. This former religious school has wonderful tiled courtyards, arches, and a 132-room dormitory that offers a view of how advanced education for the select few took place in the past. Takes a bit of exploring to find, but well worth taking an hour out to see.

stunning. stunning architecture, beautiful muslim school.its no longer open as a school, just a tourist attraction nowadays. the inside of the building is quite thought provoking with its many bedrooms some are so small and dark some have wooden shuttered windows overlooking the stunningly ornate central square with its pool and seating area surrounde by intricate stonework, carvings and tile work. one of the great sites of marrakech

Beautiful Moroccan architecture. We loved this place, the architecture was fantastic, great examples of the intricate Moroccan stone work and carvings. It created a great impression of what studying in such a bustling must have been like.

Gorgeous tiles, though a bit repetitive. A beautiful building, a lovely little piece of history. Worth the 50 dirhams just for the main courtyard. It's not big and the explanatory plaques are far and far between, but it's a lovely place to see and well worth it.

I like this place. The place ois located in the old part of Merrakech. To reach that, you have to go through some narrow streets. It is advisable to be there tomorrow as it gets a bit scary in the evening. Avoid the guides. They just want to take your money.
Beautiful architecture. The madrasa has beautiful architecture and historical significance. It is not big and you don't need to spend too much time here.

Impressive. I was not sure if this is the correct place when I got to the entrance. You can't tell the fantastic building is waiting for you inside. Just go inside and enjoy the beautiful architecture.

Great place to explore. Get the pass that includes the museum nearby. The museum is not as great but worth it in my opinion. The Madrasa is one of the best things I saw in Marrakech, and really just fun to wander. Make sure you see the upstairs. I could just imagine the place bustling with student. Very photogenic.
Tile-tastic. Breathtaking Medersa in the heart of the medina. Calm, tranquil and a treasure trove of islamic design. Beautiful and well worth the entrance fee.

Simple but lovely, most intricate detail of any attraction I saw. Get the pass that includes Marrakech Museum (just around corner), the Madrasa is basically a school for Muslims which dates back almost 1000 years rebuilt in 1500's and disused as a school for 50 years. The religious status probably protected it better than the palaces you see around Marrakech which have been stripped of anything beautiful. The Madrasa is an empty building at the end of the day but the carvings and detail of it is a real sight to be seen, its cheap enough, just do it !

Do not miss!!!. The Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa is an absolute must in Marrakesh! Situated in the heart of the medina, Soak in the beauty and peace of this old theological college, with sculpted walls and ceilings, and beautiful floors. Take the time to notice the Intricate motifs and different materials used, fall in love with the beautiful artwork. If you miss this visit, you will regret it!
Exxcellent place. it was just awsome to see that old school with its beautiful architecture, and beutiful building, very inspiring..

Must visit in Marrakesh. Don't miss Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa. If you a photographer this is a must. They have guides $$ if you wish, but just roaming the complete Madrasa was enough for me. Read up a little about the history if you can.
A must see.. Well worth the maze of streets attempting to find it, an absolute hidden gem . A token gesture of admission fee similar to all buildings of interest in the area.

A good chance to understand a historic Madrassa. Most of the "standard" comments have been well made by others so a couple of "hints" about local issues may be more helpful from me;While Marrakech is a friendly and safe city, be aware of fairly constant approaches from those enquiring about where you are going/looking for. Given a tiny chance, you will find yourselves being "guided" for which even a short piece of advice will lead to a request for payment.THERE IS PROBABLY NOT A SPECIAL EVENT IN THE TANNERIES ON THE DAY OF YOUR VISIT - WE did not go but I suspect any visit would be more trouble than it is worth!Tourism in Marrakech is still fairly "young". As others have noted, the standard and use of even formal guides does vary so choose with a little care.ps The Medrassa is worth a visit!

Inside view of a madrassa. A hard to find gem but worth searching out. Great photo opportunities. It was interesting for us to compare the architecture with similar types of architecture we were seeing in Southern Spain. It's a unique place to spend an hour wandering around and imagining what it must have been like to be a student.

Strange. Serene.. The Madrasa is beautiful but sparse--the ones in Fez are grander and better restored, I think. But the guides that hang out within the Madrassa were strange. They promised us a tour, and five minutes into the tour, ours disappeared--only to return as we were leaving expecting payment. The city should have a better handle on how museums are run! I would not rehire any of them, and instead read up on it before you go, and just give yourself your own tour.
Culture Must. If you travel for culture, you must visit this historical educational institute. It's really invaluable, the artwork on the walls, the living conditions, the entire atmosphere.

Expensive but a nice building . I would only advise visiting if you have plenty of time. This place is also very hard to find as it's in the Souk area. It has nice carvings in the wood but it's nothing you won't see elsewhere in Marrakech.Do not venture into the Souks area unless you know where your going as everyone tries to send you the WRONG way and then you end up lost at their "tannery". Do not follow anyone.

Interesting if a little little repetitive. Over 900 students would study the Qu'ran in the many dark, stone-build rooms around the Medersa's main courtyard. Covered in ornamental wooden cladding, the bedrooms and studies are an excellent way to imagine times gone by in the Medina. However, the building was in regular use as often as 75 years ago. There is a large number of internal Riad-like courtyards which have bedrooms coming off -- so many, in fact, that they become irritatingly repetitive. They do look so very similar. My advice would be to visit two of the internal sets and then venture outside to the main yard, which is beautifully covered in Moroccan tiling. Near the entrance to the courtyard you have the opportunity to buy (expensive) bottled drinks from a refrigerator and have your name written in Arabic for c.DH30 MAD. Much of the fun in this place is actually getting to it. Because of the Medina's narrow streets, only a few cars venture down and certainly no taxis. Your driver will drop you off by the entrance to a souk street. Keep walking for about five minutes straight (ignore any guides who offer you tours -- they will end up taking you to their family stalls rather than the Medersa, or will demand high payments) and then turn left when you see the sign. Signposts (or 'plaques' in French) are few and rare, but they are there. If you need directions, ask someone in a restaurant rather than a Moroccan sitting outside their stand. You will also be followed a lot down here by Moroccan 'guides', so just keep your valuables covered and secure and say 'non, merci' when they offer you assistance. After a winding section of streets you'll come to the Medersa (entrance is c.DH10 MAD) and the Marrakech Museum is nearby. You can buy joint entry in the Medersa. The Maison de la Photographie is nearby, so you could do all three in a morning/early-afternoon and then return down the souks for lunch. I'd recommend avoiding any restaurants in the streets as they are rarely hygienic and many tourists contract food-poisoning from them. You are also likely to get better deals on Moroccan souvenirs here as the shops are less-frequented than by the Djemaa El-Fna.

Certainly worth a visit. This (former) madrassa is a two-storey building, with dormitory rooms upstairs and a main courtyard and prayer hall downstairs.The courtyard itself is the main draw here, with its mosaic tiling of floral and geometric motifs, its scalloped arches, and its small central pond.I thought it was quite nice, but for some reason ended up comparing it to parts of the Alhambra - there is no comparison.

An beautiful old university in Marrakech. The Medersa Ben Youssef is a beautiful old university in Marrakech very close the souks.The architecture is lovely and the history fascinating. Go with a guide to truly understand how the system worked.Takes about 1 hour to visit.Also close by is the Museum of Morocco.Hint - just outside there is a Moroccan pharmacy with lots of plans and spices outside. Get your guide to take you in and someone will give you a short talk. So interesting how everything is used and works. You can buy argan oil etc which is better to buy here than on the souk.
Alhambra, but far smaller. If you want to have a good example of how the Alhambra looks like, but you can't reach Granada, go to this school.
Great Landmark. Beautiful architecture. Great visit for history buffs and even regular visitors. The attached museum is certainly worth visiting.
Beautiful. The Medersa is a beautiful place with lots of nice architectural detail. I especially liked the patterned tiles.
Worth a visit. A very impressive Mosque and Medersa in Marrakech - one of the only that "infidels" can enter. Beautiful tilework and carvings.
Beautiful and atmospheric. Lovely place but no information about it readily available, although unoffical guides approach you we declined. Great for photos

Great place for some interesting photography. This place is great for photography. Lots of rooms and windows for framing your photos. We had a great time exploring the rooms and shooting through different levels and windows. When a big group of tourist come in however it can get busy, otherwise when its quiet, you can get some lovely photos with reflections at the central square.

Well worth your time. This is a spectacular, ornate building that is comparable to the Alcazar in Sevilla. It is more elaborate than the Saadian Tombs and contains spectacular tile work and very interesting functional layout. It is hard to figure out when it opens -- we went by every day for three days before it opened (perhaps because it was Ramadan?) -- but your persistence will be richly rewarded. Do not miss.
Amazing Building. The decoration, the originality and size of the students rooms. The calligraphy writing on the walls

Beautiful. You wouldn't know it from the outside, but the Madrasa is SO beautiful. The architecture is amazing. The combined ticket for the Madrasa and the Marrakech Museum gives good value for money.

worth a visit. Don't let them tell you it closes at 4pm because it closes at 4.30pm. A wonderful piece of architecture, so many small rooms and delightful views into the courtyard. Easy to picture the boys living in this madrasa 500 years ago.

Beautiful . This was a great visit, for just £1/10 dirham. The history was fascinating and the building filled with intricate carvings and details. Do alongside the museum, which is only about 1/2 hours worth. Get there early.

finding it. this is quite tricky to find, look out for the marrakech museum and its next to that. surrounded by fake tour guides. worth visiting but only if you have the time, as it takes ages to find and isnt that big.

Wonderful. Amazing place for a look around and you get to see everything. Nice clean toilets. You can buy a joint ticket which also gets you into the national museum up the street at a discounted rate.. Recommended.

Better than Expected. You wouldn't know it from the modest exterior but the interior is stunning. Gorgeous tiling, woodwork and an incredible courtyard, all very well preserved. A wonderful place to spend some time, exploring the various dormitories and rooms across multiple levels.A very pleasant surprise and a particularly good place to go if the heat gets too much. Entry is 50 dirhams (less than £4) or 60 dirhams including entry to the Marrakech Museum. A must.

Islamic school. Beautiful building that was in fact a school for the teaching of the Koran. You can visit the little rooms where the students stayed during their education. Nice inner court with water and mosaïc ornaments.

Magnificent architecture and atmospheric surroundings. This was tipped as a must-visit sight in Marrakech and it really is worth the detour, especially if you're looking for a break from the souks nearby. A fairly unassuming exterior leads you in and gradually grows in majesty until you reach the courtyard which is very lovely - beautifully tiled and extremely well preserved. The prayer hall is also impressive and the students' rooms are very interesting. All in all a great place to explore for an hour or two and a fascinating insight into a different way of life.

Loved this place. A really nice historic building away from the hustle and bustle of the street markets and shops. Definitely worth checking out if only for the beauty of the Islamic calligraphy style art on the walls. I found it quiet serene walking through the hallways away from the intense summer heat.

great to explore. If you like to take architectural photogaphs or explore buildings do not miss Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa. Start with endless line (or circles) of small rooms to explore and than finish your visit with beautiful courtyart with walls decoratet with amazing details. It`s very close to Jemaa el-Fnaa square, under 10 minutes walk, if you know your way htrough the souks.

A historical building.. We visited Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa as part of a Discover Marrakesh trip through Thomson. It was part o 6 different locations on the tour.The Oldest University in the city and region.When you enter the building you walk down a magical corridor tiled, highly ornate walls , floors & beautiful carved wooded ceiling. Turn to the right and out into the courtyard you are presented with a wonderfully tiled pool in the centre. You can also go upstairs and look around & out of the small windows over the pool area.If you have time listen to your tour guide but also explore the upstairs to experience the cramped yet personal rooms used for teaching.There was a small amount of restoration works underway but this didn't detract from the history & sense of yesteryear we experienced during our visit.I've added some images taken with a Fisheye lens to capture the beauty and architecture of the venue.

Stunningly beautiful place. We spent hours here wondering the rooms - it is the most stunning place - everywhere you looked there was ornate carvings, little alcoves, beautiful marble. I just loved it and we had some fun taking photos from various windows.Well worth a visit.

Do not miss. The Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa is one of the Architectural gems of Marrakech and should not be missed. A fascinating glimpse into religious life from the 14th century onwards.Both beautifully constructed and detailed, the traditional layout of central fountain and colonnaded courtyard reminds you of the sophistication of the past life of Marrakech. It has many comparisons with religious life in monastic Europe. The small museum is equally interesting
A Must-See. Beautiful, peaceful oasis in the middle of Marrakech. A real piece of history from the 14th century.

A great heritage place to visit while in Marrakech. We had a guide take us the the Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa. The guide gave us great insight regarding the construction and the the craftsmanship that went into the initial building and the restoration. The museum section shows great antiquities that are quite beautiful. I highly recommend visiting this site. Inexpensive to enter and the overall experience is wonderful. Lots to see including the classrooms, the section where scholars answered the call to prayer. It was a great learning experience.

A magical building!. As soon as you walk into the courtyard you immediately feel plummeted back in time. The building is so beautiful and the Islamic detailing is truly splendid. The tiny dorms are hard to believe children stayed in there, but give you a spooky feeling of what life was like. As the sun sets the building looks even more beautiful and you can get fantastic pictures here. Be aware of "locals" trying to trick you outside and guide you- they want money off you and will take you to 10 other shops on the way.Also we turned up very late here, but there is a double ticket for this and a museum so do give yourself enough time to enjoy both.

A splendid building!. Unfortunately, this is the only one of the many religious buildings in the city that non Muslims can enter but it is absolutely beautiful!The madrasa was founded in the 14th Century and was one of the largest in North Africa, accommodating up to 900 students in its heyday. From the hall where you enter the building with its intricately carved wooden ceiling to the central courtyard with gushing fountain surrounded by colonnades with beautiful mosaic tile work and incredible stucco plasterwork, it is just amazing.The student accommodation is very plain by comparison, with sleeping quarters up rickety looking ladders and many of the rooms don't even have any natural light! One room is furnished in a spartan style to show how the students lived, with the barest minimum of furniture and only a sleeping mat to rest on.This building definitely has the "wow" factor and should not be missed on your visit to Marrakech!
wonderful architecture and caligraphy. The wood carving is a must to see. Simply a wonderful place to visit. A place where students used to learnt the Quran. Would definitely recommend it to anybody
Most beautiful building in Marrakech. I liked this the most from all touristic attractions. The mosaic and the wooden details are amazing.

Stunning part of history. We had a guide for the day that took us to this stunning part of history. The building is full of amazing elaborately detailed carvings and beautiful architecture. The history of the building, schooling at once 900 students in the 132 cosy dormitories is also very interesting to learn about. I would definitely recommend a trip to see this wonderful place.

Interesting architecture. I didn't know if non muslims were allowed to enter and so only saw this from the outside. It's definitely worth having a walk around. It's near to the big square too so you don't have to go out of your way to visit.
A photographers dream. A lovely place to spend time. You will need a guide or a good guidebook to truly appreciate all that you will see. Well worth the time spent.
Beautiful!!!. Really well kept! Amazing architecture!!! Can be difficult to find in the middle of the streets and alleys of Marrakech, but worth the visit. Check near there the museum, beautiful too.

WOW beautiful. I'd definitely recommend you take a few hours and visit here. stunning, very photographic and interesting history. Plan your trip with plenty of time as you may 'need' to walk through loads of souks to get here.....very time consuming!

Beautiful architecture. We had hired a guide to take us through the souks and also to this Koran school. It was founded in the 14th century and rebuilt in the 16th century. For four centuries this was a focal place to worship. There were 900 boys who stayed in over 130 small rooms to study the Koran. The walls are decorated with zellij tile. There is a pool in the middle of the courtyard. The keystone arches are exquisite as well as the different tile around the courtyard. It is a photographer's dream to capture the unique tile work, woodwork and architecture. Go upstairs and see where the older boys stayed and take pictures of the courtyard below. There is a person who will write your name in Arabic for 3 euros. The cost of the museum is 50 dirhams but pay 60 dirhams for the museum next door as a combined ticket.
Stunning. We hired a guide who took us here and it was a wonderful experience. The decorations and carved stonework is truly testament to the culture of Morocco. Highly recommended.
Pretty place. The stone work and the mosaics in this place are very beautiful. Spent about 30 min wandering through this place. Nice place to spend a little bit of time,,,,
Amazing!. Amazing place! Very beautiful place and the surrounding old town of marrakech was wonderful to explore. If you're in marrakech you have to visit.
Beautiful place. Beautiful place - but very hard to find! Great for budding photographers, so many nice shots to take!

Great example of a Koranic School. Beautifully restaured and kept - this elaborate Medersa is a place of peace and refined elegance. Take your time to enjoy the beatiful zelije tile work and the stucco carvings.

Interesting authentic Moroccan Madrasa /School-Marrakesh. As you approach this authentic Moroccan Madrasa /School through Marrakech's dusty streets , there's not much to suggest what you will find behind its plain wooden doors. Maybe the ornately tiled series of horseshoe arches across the street will give you a hint - they aren't that common in the city. It's a school that taught the Koran for over half a millennium. The courtyard, built around a shallow reflecting pool, is contained by four ornately decorated walls. From the zillij tiled floor, pilasters rise up to meet great cornices carved from ancient cedar wood. Two doors, pitched beneath overlapping arches, lead you to the two dormitories, which you can visit for framed views of the courtyard below. The dormitories are plain by comparison to the courtyard !!
Stunning mosaics and plaster work. One of the more incredible examples of Islamic decoration we visited. Highly recommended, esp. combo ticket with Musee de Marrakech which is equally beautiful.

Beautiful motifs all around. One of the most beautiful and popular madrasa in Morocco is a holder of some of the beautiful works I have ever seen. The motifs on the wall are rich, intricate and stunning. This is where young minds join together to learn Quran and a visit to the dorms are also available. Along with the Madrasa the combined ticket will also give you access to the museum which is also another must visit. Get early as the place can get crowded quickly.
beautifull medersa. a little bit to find but worth to visit ita former coranic school, lovely architecture and big variety of zelligesdo not hesitate to visit all the floors and the basement too
Worth a visit. Amazing place. Don't forget to visit the students' "dorms" on the second floor. Be sure to buy the combined ticket and visit the Marrakech museum.
Wow!. The architecture and wooden carvings are amazing. Loved the little windows overlooking the central fountain.

this theological college is richily decorated!. this is one of the most oldest Koranic Schools of Marrakech is dating back to the 14th century, but was almost totally rebuilt in 1565 by the Saadian Sultan Moulay Abdellah. It became the biggest and most beautiful ‘medersa’ of Morocco and Northern Africa. Ben Youssef Medersa is named after Sultan Ali ibn Yusuf. In 1950 the building was restored and reopened as a kind of museum in 1982.The Ben Youssef Medersa has two faces. After entering the building through a more or less dark passageway, we reached the large central courtyard with the ablution pool. This is the really rich decorated part of this former koranic school with beautiful stuccowork, carved cedar wood, marble and (of course) zellij mosaics of tiles. The reflections of the massive bronze door and the decorated wall in the water were just stunning.Opposite this entrance is a prayer room beautifully decorated with palm motifs and Islamic calligraphy. The tiny ‘rooms’ of the students are in sharp contrast with these richly decorated parts of the Medersa. Most of these 130 cells are on the first floor and housed the 900 students, which means in these tiny and basic cells six people had to live and sleep; almost incredible. Most of these sleeping quarters are formed around seven smaller courtyards; some of them had windows and a couple even to the roads outside the building (a rarity in this kind of buildings). A couple of these student rooms do have some furniture and other (student) belongings. Don’t forget to take a look through one of the windows with a great view of the courtyard. Ben Youssef Medersa is not too big, but we got a nice impression of this well-preserved religious school and the beautiful Moroccan (Saadian) architecture; one of the highlights of our Marrakech visit.

Not to be missed. We all really enjoyed this space, beautiful mosaics and a very nice little courtyard cafe. Do not miss the museum, it has some lovely ceilings and is a pleasure to wonder around and discover hidden corners.

Nice architecture, wonderful courtyard. You for a little more money you can get entry into the Madrasa when you go to the Musee de Marrakech.You get to see the nice architecture and tile work. The interior courtyard with pond is very calming. Behind it is the class area. Nice tilework there.The living quarters are very spartan.

Well worth a visit. The owner of our Riad pointed us in the direction of this fabulous museum, steeped with history, and amazing mosaics, well worth a visit, and not overly busy. Hard to imagine that over 900 students of the Islamic faith once studied and slept in the building.
Interesting worth a look. Again doesn't take long to look around and I recommend paying a guide for 15 min tour as no signs with information. Interesting pretty building.
Very beautiful. Whilst visiting Marrakesh opted to go her on an excursion, we where not disappointed, beautiful architecture and lots of photo opportunities, a must see.

Most amazing tile work. Having travelled in the "middle east" we found the tile, wood, and marble work here to rival that of all others we've seen. Absolutely stunning in detail and color without being gaudy. Take time to explore all the corners and rooms of the Madrasa. Nearly every surface is covered with craftsmanship of a high caliber.

Do not miss it. In the middle of the noisy but fantastic marrakesh souk, the old madersa has to bee seen. Very nice architecture, boiserie, ceilings... Do not miss it between all the fondouks and shops nearby.
A beautiful haven. A fantastic haven of tranquility at the top of the souks. Beautiful architecture and very much worth a visit. The source of some of my best Marrakesh pics.

Check this out, won't take long. This beautiful madersa, filled with history, architecture, and asthetic delights is worth your time in Marrakech--especially if you want a break from the hustle and bustle of the souks.

Beautiful architecture . My friend and I took a walk around the souks and stumbled into this madrasa. Didn't know what to expect but bought the tickets along with the Marrakech museum (cheaper if combined and place is next door of madrasa).I was quite when inside.
