Although the area was not big, but the building certainly has a beautiful architecture. I got to enjoy and appreciate lots of wood carving in details.Worth a visit when in Marrakech.

A Jewel of Islamic Architecture. This is a sublime piece of architecture, with all the stunning intricacy of design, decoration and traditional skills in tiles, plasterwork and woodcarving that have given building, with its equivalents in Fez and Sale / Rabat their place as wonders of the world.
Stunning. Amazing place - words cannot do the architecture justice. Peaceful, beautiful and breathtaking, even for the non religious. A must see.

Beautiful Architecutre. The Madrasa has lots of history and is a very beautiful place adorned with traditional elements of architecture and design. If you really want to enjoy it here, come as soon as they open as there are opportunities to really appreciate the architecture when there are not crowds of tourists around.

amazing!. amazing architecture and design. so peaceful. spent hours sat there taking it all in and enjoy the tanqulity.impressive to see the rooms and understand how the medrasa was used once upon a time.

Probably better with a guide. I didn't have a guide and after day 4 in Marrakesh I was finding it less charming, as the hassle factor was high trying to get to the Madrasa (there was actually a group of guys that were hanging out right outside the front door to pounce on you). Anyway, the Madrasa was beautiful, but without a guide and if you do not speak French, you'll need to just read about it online and enjoy looking around while you are there.

Cool and beautiful. Its not a big place...only takes about half to three quarters of an hour to see. Once you've seen one pupil's room upstairs there's not much point in seeing the others ....they're all the same!Combined with the museum next door it is a great introduction to Marrakech on your first morning.
Beautiful Architechture. It's a beautiful building. Worth the visit. You can get a bundled ticket and see the Marrakech Museum too (right next door).

Cool Sight Tucked Away Behind the Souks. The Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa was a cool sight tucked away behind the souks in Marrakech. It was one of our favorite sights in the city as it wasn't too crowded and it has a lot to offer. The building is very beautiful and has a lot of history tied to it too. I would recommend a visit to the Madrasa for anyone visiting Marrakech, you won't be disappointed.
Ben youssef. Stunning building steeped in history. Amazing to think people studied there. Beautiful craftsmanship.

A beautiful building. For those of us who are not Muslims most of the mosques of Morocco are off-limits, with maybe just a glimpse through an open door to tantalise. In Marrakech this is as close as one can get, and it is well worth a visit, being a place of great beauty. The entrance fee is small.
worth a visit. Beautiful place - but very hard to find! Great for budding photographers, so many nice shots to take!

Like a tale from one hundred and one tales. Small study rooms, b pavillon is more beatiful than the other side of Madresa. And of course these fresks and mozaiks aroun the pool in Madrase is fantastic. It is much more diffrent from the other medrasas that I saw in arabic countries.

Pretty, boring. I'm not sure how unique it is but it survives on tourist curiosity which goes on unfulfilled due to very little signage to help understand its purpose, significance or history. Combing a trip with the museum is something many people do, but frankly both offer little to help you understand Moroccan heritage - however they do help squeeze more Dh out of you.

Enlightening madrassa. Nice open court with a bassinNice photos to be made inside the buildingIt lacks though information regarding the history of the place and the daily life of students at the time...

Interesting Koranic school. A must if you travel for the first time to Marrakech. interesting to visit the students room, it was still in use until not long ago. The tourist toilet is still the original one... that's a bit scary since the building would need some restouration

Enjoyable, impressive & nicely maintained but lacking in information. This is certainly worth a visit, however, combine it with your trip to the museum - 60dh for both and cheaper to do this too. It's beautiful inside and very impressive. However, there's absolutely no information anywhere about what any of the rooms were or how they were originally used. We saw what seemed like cells for prisoners but I know it was a school and as I don't speak great French, I was unable to ask the man selling the tickets - who is the only person working there from what I could see. With this in mind, it doesn't take long to see everything but it is a nice relief from looking at the souk!

Fantastic handiwork. This place is an example of the heights Arab art achieved - the details on the plaster and the tiling are beautiful, definitely worth a visit. A guide would probably make you appreciate it more...
Nice architecture.. Not overly busy. Nice tiling, good insight into the school and how the pupils lived. Very well preserved and easy to locate.

A must see in Marrakesh but be careful getting there!!!!. The museum and Madrasa is a must see if you are visiting Marrakesh (they are right next to each other and it is best to buy tickets to both together). I wanted to write a quick review to also offer some advice to other tourists. You have to get here on foot, as it is very complicated if not impossible to get to by car. There are signs leading you through the market to get there, but they are often hard to see. DO NOT ask anyone just standing around for directions. We tried this and got told by a local 20 something year old that the Madrasa was just around the corner and that he could take us. He immediately got on the phone. After walking for about 5 minutes in what appeared to be the wrong direction I asked him if this was really the way to the Madrasa, he said yes but that the Madrasa was closed. He told us he was taking us somewhere better. I decided to ask a shop keeper instead who informed me we were in fact going in the wrong direction. I thanked our makeshift tour guide and explained to him that we wouldn't require any more of his services. Lesson: Ask only shop keepers or even other tourists (you will know if they are tourists or not) for directions. DO NOT allow anyone not from an agency to be your "tour guide" especially in the markets. And DO NOT follow anybody. Who know's what or where this guy was planning on taking us.
Fascinating glimpse into the Muslim world. Since non-Muslims can't enter the mosques in Marrakech, this is as close as you'll get to seeing the interior beauty of houses of religious study.
Great sight to see. This is a beautiful school and I loved exploring all the rooms and intricate detailing. If you like this madrasa, go to Fes and check out the other ones!

Worth a visit. More expensive than other attractions at 60 dirham entry but this allows you in the museo de Marrakech also, both a beautiful place, cafe just inside museum a bit expensive at £5 for 2 cokes, but there's a wee shop just outside
Stunning Building but pricey. Beautiful building but thought the entry fee was a bit on the high side as there is not that much to see
Amazing. I did not like the begger hanging around outside hassling for money, but on the other hand who could blame her. The Madrasa itself was amazing and this is one visit I certainly recommened.

Architecturally impressive and allows for a respite from heat and noise. The dry heat climate has enabled the wood elements of the Madrasa to remain in excellent shape. Lots of courtyards, pillars, tiles, carved wood. Unfortunately there is not one iota of original furniture so the place has an empty, pillaged feel to some of it. However for 10 Dirham you can't go wrong.
20 min tops. not much to see but still a must do in Marrakesh if you already are bored of souks and loudly people.
Must See!. One of the most beautiful places I have ever seen. If you are a lover of architecture, it's a must see.
Fun site to explore. There are a number of areas to explore and to gaze at the interesting architecture. It is well worth a visit.

Lovely building. Beautiful building The walk back to the Jemaa el fna following the signs that are on the buildings was long and we got hassle on the way from people telling us that places were closed and trying to be our guides. We went up a different way, no idea what way we went but it was interesting as we went through interesting parts of the souks.
superb!. beautiful lacework like carvings, beautiful tile work, very historic place, easy to find, good value

Beautifully restored. Nice courtyard and beautiful mosaics. Calming atmosphere and great escape from noisy souks outside. Although exposition is not much to see of, the building is in it self worthwhile the visit.
Beautiful architecture. A must see. The architecture is so beautiful and a great place to take photos. It is also located in a neat area of Marrakesh, so worth the walk to get there.
Worth a short visit. Not a great deal of information provided about its history and purpose but worth visiting. The architecture and decorations are interesting but some restoration work is needed.
Interesting building. It would be beneficial if there was some explanation in English. Interesting building but I had many questions that remain unanswered.

Interesting place.. The Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa was a school for the learning of the Koran. There are many chambers which students used as their quarters whilst there and it is amazing at just how many students it held (around 900). The buildings themselves are beautiful and certainly a great place for the budding (or professional photographer). Literally wall to wall mosaic and never-ending ornate wood carvings and architecture. Whilst we were there a young guy was making Arabic name plates for about 3 euros each. We bought 2 for our children and paid a little extra for a Wedding present (two names entwined) - back home and mounted in a frame it is simply stunning and was definitely a unique wedding gift. Overall, a lovely place to visit.

long walk. Once you get there it's very interesting, and there are basic toilets!We got a bit lost in the souks on the way so it took a while but showed us parts we would have missed otherwise.Stallholders are helpful if you just ask the way. The museum is just next door and that has a wee cafe as well as toilets. It's also worth a visit so makes a good morning trip. You go back through the main souk into the square where you can have lunch.

Beautiful location in the centre of the old town. Visited here as part of a Marrakech highlights day trip. The architecture and mosaics are beautiful and therefore are some great photo opportunities. Well worth a visit.
Coranic school. Very nice place it deservs a visit after all Souq. Nice place very peaceful. You can understand how people was studing in this school

Lovely place to visit. Wander through the old student rooms and look at the beautiful mosaic, wooden carvings and seat down near the pool to enjoy this place.Great place for amateur photographers as you will be able to take great pictures.We didn´t have a guide but if you have one i am sure he will make it a lot more interesting!Entry is about 5 euro but for an extra euro u get access to the Marrakech museum around the corner:Definitely worth visiting

Lovely place. It was very busy when we visited but we enjoyed walking through the chambers and the rooms where students used to live. It's a great place and you'll get some good photos here too. When you purchase the tickets pay for the museum too. For an extra euro (or 10 dirhams) you'll get access to the Marrakech museum which is next door.
Beautiful place. Beautiful place where you feel the history behind.But too much visitors late in the morning, should choose an early morning visit.

Highly recommended. It was quite a walk to get there from the parking area but was well worth it. It gave a good idea of how student were living then. The architecture and details wer so beautiful. Truly Moroccan.
Excellent. Great architecture and well worth a visit, the tiny rooms make you wonder how they ever got 900 students in there!
Amazing architecture. We loved this museum, it is really interesting and we loved the laberynth of rooms, it is worth the visit, i have never seen anything like it before
Beautiful building. Nice to walk around and admire the architectual beauties of this place.You can also visit the rooms upstairs and it's best not to be claustrophobic for this... ;)
Beautiful, traditional, tranquil.. Beautiful example of Moroccan architecture, & even though busy when we visited still very peaceful & tranquil escape from the hectic streets.

The Most Beautiful Islamic Building in Marrakech. Totally restored, this ancient Koranic University is now a museum. Wander through the rooms and marvel at the architecture and decoration. Incredibly gorgeous!
Easter Visit. Beautiful architecture and design and plenty of space despite many visitors. Not being allowed entry to mosques, this was the next best thing
Beautiful architecture. Worth going to for the beautiful architecture and to take a few snaps of the intricate patterns. Try tagging along with a tour group to fully appreciate the experience.
With a visit. Typical Moroccan architecture. Beautiful tile work. Interesting to see the conditions the students lived in.
Marrakech tour. This guy is unreal. He will tell you the where's and whereabouts of Marrakech. I love him, will definatley book this guy again.
bare shell. not furnished ie just the standard tiled floor, courtyard, carved doorways and walls so didn't give much insight into lifestyle

Beautiful Architecture and Great Photo Ops. I wish I knew more about the Madrasa. All of the information about it was in French and, sadly, I don't speak or read it! But just wandering around in there was lovely. There is a beautiful open courtyard with a lovely shallow tiled pool. The rooms of the college are all open and you can wander inside. There are also fantastically ornate walls. doors and arches and it really is quite beautiful. The building dates to the 14th century and it just oozes history and majesty. Also, as one of the few places of this kind that you can enter as a non-Muslim (it is no longer in use as an Islamic college), it should be high on your list of things to see! Just wish they had the info in more languages!

Interesting and lovely tiling. It was interesting to see this Madrasa - the place of learning that is attached to the mosque. The cells in which the students would have studied were very small but the views out their windows into the internal courtyards were wonderful. There was some wonderful tiling and decorative motifs to be seen here. Worth a visit.
Worth a visit. Beautiful place in an easy location to reach. A break from the busy streets of the souks and hustle of the city.
Interesting. I read French anyone who doesn't will struggle with the information provided in the Museum. Amazing courtyard with carved panels and a cool clear pool
well worth a visit. Stunning, peaceful space. Great photo opportunity. Beautiful architecture. The central courtyard is stunning.

Humbled by the ornamental work. This place is incredible! You will discover so many beautiful nooks and corners, I could've spent a day only in here! It is also remarkable to think of it as a school, it really shows how important education has been from a very early time on (and should you try to compare this to what was going on in europe at the same time, you'll have to bow before the muslims)! A must see! It' sonly a pity that we didn't get more background information, I'm not sure whether they have guides or a booklet, but that would have completed our visit!
Nice place!. Beautiful place, nice history and a calm atmosphere. If you have the time: visit! You dont have to have a lot of time here, but it is worth the visit.

Madrassa hot. We visited Madrassa and museum on a very hot day in April (35c). It was amazing how cool parts of the building were despite the heat - the layout was interesting but student rooms were bare.

An historical gem.. This fascinating place of beautiful architecture and decoration is well worth a visit. It was a school for Muslim boys and has many small rooms for teaching and sleeping, all with incredible architectural detail. We really enjoyed our visit, but unfortunatley our French isn't good enough for us to be able to read the signs and explanations, so we had to read up afterwards about what we had seen.

Carved wood and tile interiors. The small rooms for students who studied here flanked by open, tiled courtyards and terraces...it's a couple of dollars per entry and well worth it, combined with the Marrakech Museum a few blocks away
Beautiful architecture. Well worth a visit, the craftsmanship here is absolutely beautiful, allow at least an hour for a good look around the place.

Beautiful traditional carved walls and ceilings. Such gorgeous central courtyard and cloister. And remember to look up! Best to have a guide to bring the past to life and fill the spaces with your imaginations.

Best Marrakech sight. What an amazing place! Beautiful, tranquil and really interesting. Spent a long time here marvelling at the stunning Islamic art on the walls, ceilings and floors. If you only do one sight in Marrakech, make it this one. Really worth visiting. And if you get the combined ticket for this and the Museum of Marrakech, make the museum the first thing you see as otherwise it's a bit of a let flown after the madrasah!
Nice view. Nice atmosphere, nice cultural place to see, 60 dirhams to get in but overall a pleasure to visit. There was a man making arabic calligraphy which was nice. would visit again

Only beautiful courtyard. I expected more from the medersa. I've read about it in books and on internet. But I found it disappointing. The only thing worth a visit is the beautifully decorated courtyard of the medersa. The student rooms are all empty and look like a prison. And there are a lot of them! We actually expected that we would see a real school. With classrooms etc. But the only things open for visit are the empty student 'rooms' and the courtyard.
Nice to see a school like this different than in holland. No children at the moment but very nice buildings to wonder along the allyways. It was hot outside but cool inside
Don't miss. Very beautiful, worth a visit. Perhaps a little tricky to find if you'r on your own, but persevere! A bit more expensive at 50 mod than some of the other places.

Worthwhile seeing. Our guide took us here and thus he provided the context and the information we needed to appreciate Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa. The architecture was impressive, I loved the carving, it was amazing how cooler it is inside, the design really works. Also welcome clean comfort stop.
Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa. absolute must on your visit to Marrakesh - beautifully decorated interior, well worth the time ccccccccc cdcc

Exquisite work. We hired a private guide and he took us to this beautiful place and the museum next door. His explanations of the designs, texts, history and architecture were necessary to understand the significance of this structure.

Beautiful architecture - get the joint madrasa/museum ticket. I loved the architecture here, very good craft work and a very peacful place. Unfortunately, there isn't much text/information or history about the place in English, so maybe a guide would have made it a more enjoyable experience.

Fascinating history and architecture. For a historical landmark, the Madrasa is more expensive than the others in Marrakesh, but definitely worth seeing. It's interesting to take note of how identical rooms are all designed to be unique. Make sure to get a guide to explain what you are seeing if you are interested in its history, although just gazing at it's intricate designs is worth it alone.

Most interesting site. This is a fascinating building and gives a fascinating insight into the lives of students and teachers alike. Note there is a combined ticket with the Musee de Marrakesch (see my review about this)

Impossible to Find Entrance. This is my Marrakech regret-- my friend and I could not find the entrance, no matter how hard we tried. I wish we had read the TripAdvisor reviews more closely before setting out. Apparently, the real entrance is completely unmarked and across the way from the huge wooden door that IS marked as "Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa." Go figure.The pictures look stunning, though-- I really wish we'd been able to tour the inside, not just for the amazing architecture but for the history contained within these walls. Don't make our mistake-- from all accounts, this is a Moroccan must-see-- especially as a lot of beautiful architecture is often off-limits to non-Muslims!

worth popping in for a quick look. We came here as part of a day tour around marrakech we stayed for about 45mins, it was just the right amount of time as there is not a great deal to see, but its worth a look. It was good we had a guide to tell us about the place as there was no information around about what you were looking at, again like alot of places in marrakech if stairs are not your friend you will struggle to get a look around the whole of this site,
It was OK. Average, I wasn't too keen to go there but the Mrs wanted to so we went. There's better places in Marrakech
Great architecture. As a first introduction to Islamic architecture in Marrakech, we found this place fascinating. The architecture is very special and it is certainly worth spending time here.

Interesting architecture!. A very interesting building with some very talented sculpting of wood, stone and mosaic tiling.
We probably would have benefited from taking up the opportunity of having a tour guide. I think we might have understood the historic importance a little more as there are no information boards as you go round.
Very peaceful place.

Hmmm...rated as one of the top 10 attractions?!. We expected this building to be something comparable to the Alhambra in Granada or the beautiful medina in Seville. It was far from it. It was small, with one quite mediocre courtyard, on the first floor were lots of little rooms with nothing in them. All quite boring and poor value for money.

Do not miss the Madrasa!. Fascinating visit and a great insight into this Islamic college which was built in the mid 16th Century. I would strongly advise a good guide book or printing off some info from the internet before you go as there is little signage in English. My 20 year old son at University with an en-suite room in halls really ought to see this to appreciate how lucky he is!

Relaxing, interesting, beautiful. Firstly, buy the combined ticket for the museum and the madrasa. The saving is worth it, and the museum is great too.The architecture here is stunning, the tiled walls and floor really bring home the feeling of being inside 'traditional' Marrakech. Wandering in and out of the old classrooms and dorms is fun. The little amount of signage inside is in French and Arabic, so hire a guide if you want information and explanations (we got by with our fairly basic French). The photographic opportunities are great too.It's definitely worth an hour of your time.

One of Marrakech's top 10 places to visit. The entrance kiosk offers a joint ticket for the madrasa and the neighbouring Museum of Marrakech. Although the museum is not as spectacular as the madrasa, the minimal extra cost involved is good value and the museum is also well worth seeing.The main courtyard of the madrasa has a large, central, peaceful pool, and exquisite tiling, woodwork and plaster work.

Beautiful but worth getting a guide. I really enjoyed wondering around this beautiful building but with little information on display anywhere it's probably worth getting a guided tour. With stunning architecture, intricate and colourful designs this is an integral part of Marrakech's history and worth a visit.
Worth a visit. Great fun exploring all the tiny student dormitories. Interesting architecture and lovely courtyard. Had an interesting trip there by caleche down narrow streets!

Nice Building. Building in good order and history well documented visiting affords a quiet hour from the Souks. The students rooms are bare but in good order, the communal rooms give a good idea of the history.
Fascinating. I cannot imagine what it would have been like with 900 children living in here. The stucco work is amazing.

Interesting place, worth a visit.. We went here on our last day in Marrakech, architecture was stunning and the museum was interesting. We had a local guide with us that had been arranged via our hotel which was very useful considering there isn't really any other information available when you are there and we were offered a lot more insight than we would have gained going by ourselves. One of the best parts of visiting Ben Youssef is getting there, you need to walk through the souks and we went in from the north part of the medina which took us through some of the less touristic streets. This was great for me as I love photography and it provided some amazing photo opportunities. An experience of the real Marrakech not to be missed.
Stunning architecture. This is worth a visit for it's beautiful architecture and cultural interest, even if I wish it was better maintained.

Stunning!. it is stunning! Not to be missed.The architecture is so ornate and lavish - worth getting the joint ticket for the museum next door which is also very interesting (50 dirhams for each or 60 for a joint ticket - no-brainer!)
Interesting and beautiful. One of the grandest houses in Marrakech preserved for cultural interest, beautiful carved wooden doors and mosaic tiling. Very popular and close to the riad star
An old school building. No information provided to make this plain building come alive with history. A sign or two in French and none in English.

Visit the first thing in the morning. Edwina from House of fusion, with whom I did a wonderful cooking class, recommended that I should visit first thing in the morning before the tourist groups arrive, to see the building reflected on the pool. So that is what I did. I had the whole building for myself for a while. Beautiful quiet experience.

Traditional Moorish Architecture. This is one of the more impressive and well-preserved Moorish buildings in Marrakech, with a myriad of interesting side rooms set around an impressive central courtyard. Not in the same league as the Moorish buildings in Seville, Spain but definitely worth a visit during a stay in Marrakech.

The soul of Moroccan culture.. If you like Moroccan architecture, you can’t miss this place, it’s the most classic and the top of the Moroccan architecture and art form. The wood carving, plaster, mosaic, the details, intensive labor…. it’s just stunning!! The Madrasa was built in 14th century; it’s one of the largest in Morocco. They used to host up to 900 students here. People in Marrakech are very proud of this madrasa, and they did a great job preserve the buildings. Madrasas are the soul of the culture.We had a very knowledgeable tour guide who told us the history and stories about this madrasa, we also learned how to appreciate it even more!
Interesting. Very interesting and the building was very ornate. It was quite reminiscent to the Alhambra in Granada. Half an hour to visit and we payed 60 d for this and the museum.

600 years old!. To think this is around 600 years old is amazing! Check out the students rooms, the tiled staircase to the student's classrooms, and look from the ground floor upward at the wooden stairwell winding upwards, it's beautiful!

One of the best preserved buildings in Marrakesh. The Medersa Ben Youssef provides one of the best preserved buildings in Marrakesh and the fine wood carvings and historical architecture provides prime examples of their period. The light in the small courtyards on the first floor provide also excellent photo opportunities.

Beautiful but lacking information.... It is worth a visit as the building is beautiful, however there are no information signs detailing what everything is. We paid 50DH to enter, and I assume they want you to hire a guide to explain everything. My guidebook did a good job, but more information would have been better. Great place to have a wander round to get away from the busy city.

History. Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa is the best attaractions we visited in Marrakech , it's history and beauty make us spend a lof of time and ask so many questions , the best place to visit in Marrakech and the most beautiful attraction .
Beautiful. Well worth wandering through the souks to find this gem. Amazing tilework and carving. An oasis of calm within the city
How many ways can you spell Medrasa. Architectural gem and the ultimate solution to adolescence- just lock up all the males between 12 and 19 in school- all the girls are already locked up at home.

Almost unseen treasure. This was a religious school and would have been closed to non-Muslims and women of any denomination until it was closed a few years ago. It is a truly fascination insight into Islamic art and culture.

Fantastic Place!. Visited here to look at the architecture and interior design and I was not disappointed! This place is beautiful in the middle of all the hussle and bussle of Marrakech, hidden gem! Entry to here and the museum for 60dir so very cheap as well. A must see in the city.
Beautiful. Really beautiful tiles and carvings, well worth a visit. You can spend half an hour to an hour here and then go on the museum, which is not to be missed.
Very much worth a visit!. Beautiful mosaics but no furniture. Rooms of the students upstairs are interesting. If you buy a combined ticket ,you can also visit the museum, almost next door.

My favourite place in Marrakech. I loved this place. The central courtyard reminded me of the Alcazar in Seville. Beautiful decor, stunning architecture, wonderful craftsmanship and amazing detail everywhere you look. It's truly spectacular. You can also visit the cells where the students would stay. Buy a combined ticket and for an extra 10 dirhams you can also visit the Marrakech museum just 50 metres up the road.
Interesting visit. I loved the courtyard and all the tiles around...inside is quite simple, nothing special but the Museum is spectacular...buy the combined tickets!

Must see. This was my favourite "palace"...indoor with gardens thing. It easy to find if you follow the guidebook instructions. It can be busy but get a good guide book and don't go in a tour group. I would have liked to have wondered alone around the rooms and the courtyards. You can buy a ticket for the museum as well which has a nice café.

A jewel. This is a wonderful legacy that Marrakech has preserved and rightly ttreasures. Step inside the unpretentious entrance hall, and you are immediately in an atmosphere imbued with history and learning. Just pause a moment - think that up to 900 students used to live and study here in these tiny monastic cells. You can wander freely upstairs and you can see that although tiny each room is sufficient to sleep and study in. Students would have used that serene central courtyard where the shining pool reflects the sky. The decorative architecture is awesome, the spaces, columns, vistas all most elegant and beautiful. You are looking up at the sky, encouraged to think past yourself and concentrate on the wonders of God's creation. It is an uplifting place.

Do Go!...pay at the door 10dir only.. We bought this as part of a package ticket costing 60dir that included the rubbish so called Museum of Marrakech. The Madrasa was beautiful the museum rubbish. It would have been nice to see more English language explanations about the madrasa. It is quite serene and peaceful and kept in excellent order.
It is a place where Arabs used to learn and study Qur'an.. It has to be seen while staying in Marrakesh, a very touching and charming place that will surely enlighten many aspects of Arabic Culture.

Beautiful place of study. Fascinating building which was orginally a place for young scholars to learn about the Muslim faith. Stunning buildng with beautiful mosaics and central courtyard with pool. Interesting to see the rooms students lived in all set around their own internal courtyards similar to the riads. Get ricket to oth this and the museum - we found this much more interesting!

A stunning building with a calm atmosphere. Hailed as one of the most beautifully decorated buildings in Marrakesh I have to agree. I got the combined ticket and also went to the Museum of Marrakesh which is around the corner from this. I was lucky to be there with few other people, I think just the time of day really.Very interesting to see the former quarters where the students used to sleep. There is apparently one room dressed to showcase what it would have been like, I didn't find it though as there are many rooms as you can imagine as it used to house around 900 students. The main courtyard is the most impressive part with intricate patterns and designs.

a little bit of culture. great visit. history and culture,Don't need a guide .Small entrance fee not much info on exhibits it's all in French.But one is able to interpret visually.Some nuisance factor with being asked for money from locals outside but copeable with if ignored.

Amazing building. Many people rate this building as the most impressive in Marrakesh and I would agree. Courtyards, student cells, skylights, tiles, passages, complex woodwork. One is transported to another era. Not over-restored.
Worth a look!. Fab interior and great for interesting photography shots. It was nice to take time away from the hustle and bustle of the souks.

An unusual destination - an early city university. Most unusual opportunity to see lots of
F student rooms and wonder at how they coped! Beautiful central court reminding us of Granada.

Just beautiful.... Extraordinary and beautiful old centre of Islamic study, close to
Maison de Photographie and the Marrakech Museum. Well worth
a visit.

The best place of interest in Marrakech!. A magnificent building with many fascinating details and an interesting history. Apart from that: an oasis of silence and beauty within the madness of Marrakech's medina.
This is - by far - the most impressive site that we visited in the medina!
Beautiful. Loved the place and liked the visit. Well restored and beautiful example of local architecture. Worth the visit.
Ben Youssef. Nice patio and ceilings, many little rooms. Hard to find the room with the authentic fourniture. Combined ticket with the museum, which lies next door

Interesting historically. Interesting building to explore - was a place for residence for young men to study the Koran. Fascinating layout.
No English information available
Beautiful building. The building is very impressive, great carvings and tile work. Sadly not much to tell you about the life of the building.

Surprise find. We found this place on our last day having spent the rest of the week on guided tours round souks and mountains. We used a guide book to find it - admission was under £1 each and it was very worthwhile. As we were leaving, the attendant opened a locked door taking us into another area - highly recommended.
Well worth a visit.. Difficult to find without a taxi or by walking at the edge of the Souks from Jemaa El Fna Plaza. Take a double ticket to visit the Museum opposite as well.
This is the best historic place to visit. This is the best historic place to visit, the other palaces are just like castle ruins, but still interesting.

Beautiful and well worth a visit, our kids loved it, too. A beautiful place to visit. Our children loved the fact that it was a bit of a maze and they imagined being a student at the school all those years ago.

Worth a visit. A wise thing we did before coming to Marrakech, we had Riad Elizabeth, where we were staying, organize a tour guide for us. While this was not cheap, around €70 or $90, Mustafa guided us through the souk with expertise and showed us things we ordinarily wouldn't have found; I'm sure of that. This former university was one of those attractions. I think it was 50 MAD pp to get in but do spend that money! It is worth seeing the architecture, the old student rooms, cedar wookwork and the mosaics still in place. Also, right in the middle of all that bustling, this is a peaceful and quiet retreat.

Wonderful building and architecture. A MUST visit!. Stunning courtyard and very interesting architecture. Lovely to stroll around this building and see the small cells where students lived. Even a visit to the toilet is worth doing as it is in the old bathroom area! Can be difficult to find as it is in the souk area. Take a youth as a guide and give him a tip...worth the hassle of not struggling through the lanes to find it!
A must see !!!. I got lost trying to get there but ... well worth it ... amazing place .. get a 60DIR ticket and also go to the Marrakech Museum about 20 meters away... enjoy.

History lesson. A very good history lesson and amazingly preserved plaster, marble, wood and mosaic. Stunning given the agee. More needs to be done to make the madrasa come to life and give visitors the understanding and perspective of the student life. More needs to be done also to preserve the stunning craftsmanship.

Magnificent and atmospheric. This is not easy to find but worth it when you get there. You can buy one ticket for the Museum and the Madrasa for 60dh. They are next door to each other and there is a little outdoor café for snacks if you come over faint.

Worth a visit. Combined ticket for this place and the museum is 60MAD. It is an interesting site with loads of photo opportunities. Probably the best place to come to see examples of the architecture you can see at other sites in the city. Could have done with one or two of the rooms having beds etc in them to get more of a feel of how people lived and studied here.

Nice old koran school. Old building, needs some conservation Typical oriental style of architectureThere is no information in the building concerning his past, this is a pity if you want to know more (this is a general remark for all the buildings exept the Badii Palace in Marrakech that we have visited). Take a combined ticket (Medersa and the Marrakech museum), it will save you some money.Negative point: we were insulted by the security guide at the entrance, and we were not the only ones, When we left, he was arguing with other people. Don't know his problem, but definetively not at his place over there.

Beautiful Architecture. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit here, had fun exploring all of the rooms and of course the beautiful courtyard. It was a bit of a hassle to find the place on our own but we eventually managed.

Amazingly stunning place to visit. Gorgeous example of the craftsmanship that is so well known in morocco. The wood work is breathtaking when realising that it was all done by hand. This place is very well preserved and definitely worth a visit. thoroughly enjoyed this place.
Breathtaking.. The tiling and stonework is amazing. It was interesting to see the rooms the students would have lived in.
Beautiful!. Most beautiful building we visited in Marrakesh! Impressive craft works with tiles and wood. Also worth seeing the former rooms of the students.

Historic property north of the souk. The madrasa is a handsome example of late 16th century Moroccan architecture. It is hard to get to, as one must run the gauntlet of the souk (and all its vendors) to get there from Je Maa Fna.

beautifuly rstored. Expensive to enter at 60dm(compared with 10 dm for other cultural attractions) as it is privately owned
But it is beautifully restored and well worth it

stunning. well worth the few DH to have a look around. Bit of a hassle to find if you don't have a street map rather than the useless tourist one handed out. The details in the wood carvings is literally breath taking.We choose not to use the guides on offer, although they seemed useful and helpful, it was enough to wander around in awe
Never found it. Was told it was closed and taken by a very long route to a tannery for a berber market. Was a scam. There was no market. We were taken to a shop and shown leather goods and carpets.
Really worth a visit. Quite pricey by Marrakech standards but well worth a trip. Amazing architecture, tile and plaster work and interesting as a site. One of the must see sights here.
Beautiful architecture. Really beautiful architecture. Very interesting to see the students’ accommodation/residence quarters. One of the best sights in Marrakech!

Interesting visit. Very interesting place to look round and explore. The carvings in the main courtyard and prayer room off of it are particularly beautiful, and the student rooms give you some feel of what the place must have felt like. In common with nearly all the Moroccan sites we saw, there is a distinct lack of explanation about what you're looking at. Either a small booklet or some more signage would be very helpful. We were approached by someone claiming to be a guide after looking around for a while, but it was unclear whether it was legit. Strongly recommend reading the background about this and other sites before you visit them.

Splendid. The Ali Ben Youssef and Museum next door are twinned with one ticket. About £3 each so excellent value and an easy hour in beautiful, culturally interesting surroundings. Worth the time to relax after the assault on your senses of the near by Souks.

Wonderful old university. What's not to like? Ben, our guide, had inside knowledge of the Medersa, because his father attended there! It's a lovely, peaceful place, a real hidden gem. The fountain in the main courtyard provided us with an amazing photo opportunity which I cherish.

Stunning architecture. Well maintained and restored architecture. The history of the place itself is rich and looking at the detailed carvings and popping into all the different rooms (dorms) were fun. There are hardly any labeling explaining what is what in the building, but you can still enjoy the ambiance.

My favoutite in Marrakech. For me it was the most interesting visit in the city. Must see.
The ticket is 50 Dh, 60 Dh together with the museum 50 meters away which is also interesting.

Amazing University building!. Our guide took us here and explained the history. If you dont have a guide make sure to have a guide book,
It feels like stepping back in time and you can admire the mosaic and architechture for hours!
(Signs are only in french and arabic)
AN HISTORIC SPOT. Don't miss it. typical arabic style.....full of history. better with a guide, explaining details, as there is nothing written in the rooms
Fantastic architecture!. Interesting and intricate designs. Wonderful courtyard. Took some great photos from within the Student cells looking onto the courtyard.

Great place. It is very difficult to describe Madrasa in a few words. It is a magnificent place and a definite must see, I would pay appr. $5-10 for a 30-40 min excursion to learn more about this great Madrasa.

Spectacular. The central courtyard is surely one of the most wonderful buildings in all of N Africa. It is a magical version of the Bahia Place which is also in Marrakesh, encompassing all of that which is best in the architecture of this region. Do not miss it

worth a visit, great value for money. very beautiful, certainly worth a visit in the top 10 in marrakech, very beautiful, take a wide angle lens and flash if you can, setting white balance was impossible on site,
Don't miss this building!. One of the best buildings in Marrakech. However there's not a lot to see apart from the decoration and architecture.
Dont miss it . Without doubt one of the most beautiful buildings you will see in marrakech. Spend about 45 minutes taking in the adornments on the inside and appreciating this early university.
One of the best buildings in Marrakech. we arrived early morning as our riad was very close to that place. amazing! so beautyful colors and carving . a must see while in marrakech
Viewing religious life. While it is interesting to see the equivalent of an empty monastery there is not a lot to hold your attention apart from some of the architecture and decoration.

Not bad interesting building. I liked it , the building arches are great the mosaic is fantastic the most interesting place was the first floor, " the student rooms" it look like to me like little jails for bad boys , I would be stay in these student rooms.

Intimate tour of ancient Islamic School. We toured daily with a wonderful guide who saved us time and energy in planning and our trip to this beautiful and ancient building was no disappointment. We could feel the sacredness and respect throughout our visit. Seeing the tiny students rooms, of which there are just over 130 and which housed almost 900 students at a time was humbling. The amazing carved cedar wood, tiles and carved stucco were beautiful. This is the only morass a or Islamic Center of lLearning tourists can visit. It is well with the time. Located in the Medina it is a short walk to coffee or shopping.
Interesting place. Beautiful architecture, very quiet & calm place. Interesting students’ accommodation/residence quarters from architectural point of view, definitely worth a visit.

Moroccan Taj! :-). If you can visit only one interesting "monument" in Marrakech (for whatever reason), this is the place. Super, detailed artwork, beautiful layout, each nook and cranny has something of note. Entry costs 50 dirhams but is more than worth every bit of it. Charming and exquisite, it is bound to take your breath away. Photos don't do it enough justice. And mind you, I have visited the Taj Mahal too.

Interesting visit. It is one of the only madrasas in Morocco that you can actually visit, including the second floor where the students lived. The architecture is nice and its a quiet peaceful corner of Marrakech.
Wonderful place. The palace condition is not optimal. But the atmosphere is really worth a visit. The mosaics are breathtaking !

Nice. Not so easy to find, but Moroccans are Always willing to help. most times in Exchange to a small tip, ok, mas they seem really nice in general. Place is nice, but nothing astonishing. With a little extra you can include the museum in the ticket. Both can take around a couple of hours of your trip.

Brilliant architecture. Whilst this building is signed once you are quite close to it it is easy to walk past the entrance as there is no sign on the door (a small notice on the opposite wall is all). This Madrasa used to house 900 boys in the 130 tiny rooms and it is hard to imagine what the noise (not to mention the smell) must have been like. The rooms are tiny with some having shelving for sleeping and others having wooden rungs in the corners which permit a climb into an upper chamber. No lighting of course! Walking around this rabbit warren you do wonder how anyone knew where to find anyone else. The Central courtyard is amazing and very beautiful. It also has some of the best loos in Marrakesh!
Fascinating. A beautiful and surprisingly peaceful place. Our official guide made this University come to life through the art of scripts on the walls. Felt I learned something.

Great for a bit of history. I think it's worth the visit. Pay extra for the tour of the madrasa and museum. Really interesting to see how the learners lived and also the detail in the architecture is fascinating. There's a cafe outside you can chill at afterwards and take time to visit the museum with its interesting artworks. There's a man who does calligraphy as well - really beautiful. Pay 20dh to have your name done.
Beautiful building. Fantastic architecture and calming pool - facinating to see the tiny rooms where the students would sleep.
Interesting place. Old interesting place, where you can freely walk around and enjoy the old moroccan architecture. There is not much more to see, or explained inside. Yet, it is nice to see.

GOOD ARCHITECTURE. A good place to visit if you appreciate architecture (which was stunning). One criticism is that there was no information about what the building was used for on show. There are 132 rooms in the Madrasa and after a while it became a little repetetive. It would have been nice if some of the rooms could have been furnished to show the visitor how they would have looked when the students lived there.

A Marrakech schooling. This intricately decorated Koranic school is both beautiful and mysterious: the latter not least because one wonders how 800 boys fit into the dormitories above the classrooms. There is a kind of poignancy to visiting this venerable boarding school as a result. You're torn between admiring the fine carving and tiling, and trying to imagine daily life for the children squeezed into the routines of the past. Nevertheless, it's a must-see in the Medina, along with the splendid architecture and decoration of the Marrakech Museum; and they're on a combined ticket.

Beautiful architecture worth wandering the Medina for. We wandered through the Souks to find this place and were not disappointed. It is well maintained and has some beautiful elements and despite the crowds I find it quite relaxing gazing at the reflections of the palatial walls in the water pool between them. It does not take long to visit (max. 1 hour), and may be worth paying for a tour guide if you are eager to learn a bit of the history. In my opinion it was not worth paying for a combined ticket for the Marrakech Museum, as although this had a nice central hall it was not very interesting - so save yourself some cash and just pay for the Madrasa entrance.
Beautiful!. Well worth the visit! Beautiful architecture and design, close to that which can be seen in the Alhambra in Grenada but perhaps not as grandiose, but close nevertheless :) We enjoyed it!
Beautiful, interesting quick visit. Worth a stop for sure. Beautiful and interesting to see students' quarters. No English anywhere. We spent less than half hour but recommend it.

Interesting and beautiful. Definitely worth a visit. The central courtyard is beautiful classical Islamic architecture. It was very interesting to see all the little rooms where the students would have slept and studied. There is a joint ticket for this and the Marrakech museum. For the extra 10dirams you might as well do both, but the museum is of limited interest, almost to the point of being melancholy. But the madrasa is the most interesting and attractive historical site we saw in Marrakech.

If you only see one thing in town, make it this. Really the only thing that is a must see in Marrakech. The one single place that captures the spirit, history and essence of Marrakech like no other. The fact that you'll probably get lost trying to find it in the middle of the medina only adds to the mystique of the place. Some of the wood carvings of the Quran on the walls here are 500 years old. Highly recommend seeing with a personal guide. Arrange at your hotel for about 20 euros for a 1/4 day tour of the old town. Money well spent.

Nice school in the heart of the Medina. A fascinating place with amazing architecture. It was great to walk around and browse. Pretty cheap to get in. Would have liked more things to help self guide on a tour, but overall pretty interesting.
Beautiful old school. Lovely old school full of history. Better appreciated with no tour groups. We did not have a guide but could be useful. Difficult to find but worth the effort.
Ben Youssef Madrassa. Well worth the visit, we bought a combined ticket for this and the museum, good value. Beautiful architecture.

Mesmerising. I have visited this Madrasa 5 times over many years. Best to come when the doors open in the morning. Architecturally I regard it as the finest in Morocco ( having visited the ones in Fes and Meknes). I love the solitude of the rooms upstairs, and the fine designs carved in plaster (upstairs). On the ground-floor : well, feast your eyes on Moroccan carvings and tile-work that would be amongst the most exquisite in Morocco. The fountain is amazing. Refresh your spirit!

More of the same rundown tat. Honestly don't bother. If you're at the Marrakesh Musee don't buy the combined ticket. It's just another run down building. Same tile work. Same plaster and wood work. I might have got another star had it actually been restored to an acceptable standard.

Best stop in 'Kech. Just do a little research on the history to make the most of your time spent at this beautiful site. We did not hire a guide (maybe should have). Photogenic at its finest-- as far as man made structures go.
what a beautiful place!. Just go! it is an amazing place, wonder around it and just imagine learning there it's great, although the rooms are a bit small we're sure that didn't deter people.

Small but Gorgeous. This should be atop your list of sites to visit in Marrakech. The detailed carvings in the walls and the quant beauty of the courtyard really stood out. A combined ticket with the nearby museum of art only cost 10 Dirham extra and was well worth it.

A must-see in Marrakech - our favourite. The entrance fee is 50 dirham, but it is definitely worth paying just an extra 10 so that you can get a combined ticket for the museum just round the corner (also well worth a visit). We arrived fairly early in the day (I believe it opens at 9am) so it wasn't too busy. You will probably be approached by a guide, but with a simple no thank you they will leave you in peace. If you are walking here from the main square, the best way to approach is to enter the souks from the main entrance opposite the Cafe de France and keep walking straight up the main passage until you exit at the north, just in front of the museum.Of all the beautiful architecture we saw in Marrakech, this was the finest. The amazingly detailed carving and picturesque balconies makes it almost impossible not to come away with beautiful photos.

Don't miss it. This is a must see in Marrakesh. The interiors are fabulous. It has several rooms with interesting details and a gorgeous area with a pool.The entrance fee is 50 MAD. There is also a combined ticket: Marrakesh museum plus Madrasa for 60 MAD.
Historical and atmospheric. Well worth the visit, you can imagine how the boys lived in this place to learn and study the Quran. The mosaic and craftsmanship reminded me of the Alhambra.

Beautiful Space . We toured this place with our small group. It is a beautiful space and a nice open respit from the sometimes very tight souk. There are no exhibits aside from seeing the space. Though the space is impressive. Read up or ask your guide about the history. You can almost see the boys studying all those years ago. Dont miss going upstairs to see all the small 'dorm' rooms where people stayed. The bathroom was ok, not great.

Incredible architecture. Come here with one of the official guides…it makes a major difference. The architecture is absolutely amazing, especially multi-century woodwork. It is one of the relatively fewer places from that era with a religious background but is open to non-Muslims. Being able to step into the residence areas is truly like stepping back into earlier Morocco.

Old choranic school wonderfully renovated. As many historical sites in Marrakech, the Madrasa gains interest when you have information about it. Since most of these places does not have good information, the visit could become useless. So it's much better if you get information in advance (not those travel guides summaries that might be helpful but say almost nothing) or hire a good guide.
One of the best Marrakech sites. BEAUTIFUL. Absolutely amazing site, well worth seeking out no matter how short your visit to the city.
Beautiful!. This place is gorgeous. If you want really nice pictures, go in the late afternoon when the sun is starting to set.

Well worth a visit.... Breathtaking Islamic art... well worth going to but IGNORE helpful men who tell you that "it is the last day of the Berber leather fair" and drag you off to the Tanneries instead.
not very exciting. lack of information, no furniture, just more and more of the same, although what you see it is pretty, the way to the madrasa could be sneaky

Rare insight into local historical Islamic interiors. As the local Mosques are not open to non-Muslims, this old madrasa for boys gives you a little insight into historic Islamic interiors and architecture.
Amazing!. unexpected exquisite stone and wood work, mosaic and details that were stunning. A must see! Worth going to if visiting the Marrakech Museum, which is next door.
Definitely go and visit Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa. Very intricate and detailed carvings. What a place to study. Go early in the morning before the rush begins to enjoy. Entrance fees are very nominal.
Excellent workmanship. This is a must to visit, as the craftsmanship is excellent. Be sure to go early as there always seems to be a huge waiting line to get in.

Magnificent!. The number of excellent/very good reviews say it all - definitely worth a visit for a welcome break from the hustle bustle of the souks! The architecture is quite intriguing and unlike anything I'd seen before, clearly a purpose built religious school designed to house students/scholars. The intricate carvings and detailing on the tiles is simply extraordinary! Some of the best I've ever seen in all my travels.Overall, highly enjoyable and thoroughly recommended!

Well worth a visit. A very interesting place to visit with exquisite craftsmanship in the traditional decor steeped in history. Buy the ticket in combination with ticket for Marrakech museum, also well worth a visit.

Very nice place. When in marrakech, you should go to Ben Yousself for a look. The buildings are interesting and nice and the entrance fee is cheap. Also it is right next to the Marrakesh Museum which you should also visit at the same time (it is just next door). Make sure to get the combine entrance ticket.

great Break in the medina. Great art and buildings of old palace and hamman, cost of 60 Dhr for both museum and palace is good value, good photo opportunity to show the real taste of Morocco. Only problem is that they don't have information in English only in French & Arabic, so take a guide book with you
great location. Is woth the long lasting drive - so, start early and take a hanky with you.should visit the film studios aswell.
A marvel. Completely dazzled by this beautiful building,. Well worth a visit. The carvings and tiles are simply awe inspiring and the place so atmospheric.

Definitely worth a visit. From the moment you step in you leave all the hussle and bussle on the street and enter a vibrant yet serene place. The architecture in here is exactly what you would imagine from Morrocco. The only downside is that there is no information in English on what this place was etc. For an extra 10 Dirham you can buy entry to the Museum, definately do this because the architecture in there is gorgeous as well.
Must visit if staying within 10mins!. This is a beautiful building with a great history. I went with an external guide that told us so much about the Madrasa. Great place for photos also.

Amazing place. It's definitely the most amazing building in the city. The entrance fee is only 50 dirhans (less than 5 euros) and if you pay 10 more, you can also go to Marrakech museum. I totally recommend visiting this place.

Reflection of artisans and lifestyle. We went with our well known guide Youssef. He eloquently explained the detail about the place and more importantly imparted knowledge of this school of Islam presenting it in a sweet and palatable way, sweeping away some less positive attitudes towards Muslims and the stereotypes of Koran schools.

Amazing architecture. I love this place the building and the carvings on the wall was amazing. Didn’t know a lot about the history and they have no information on display regarding this but the building itself was great, explored all the nooks and corner. Entering the court yard for the first time, the view was breath taken.Wish they will show how life was or who stayed in what room as some were larger than other and some were just like dungeons.

Best in early morning. Great place to visit first thing in the morning before other tourists appear. Fantastic Arabic decorative carvings and a real sense of peace and quiet. One of the few Madrasas you can visit as a non Muslim.

not to be missed. not a great deal to see but very interesting, the carving is so intricate its overwhelming. Its hard to believe this school was only closed in the 1960. Great to get out of the hustle and noise. Combine the visit with the Museum.
For architecture and Islamic calligraphy. If you're interested in Islamic architecture and or calligraphy, verses from the Quran then this place is worth a visit.
impressive mosaic work. the walls of the building were well decorated but there is not much else to see. Would recommend if you have nothing else to do
Brilliant architecture!. very beautiful and historical building. There was a small entry fee, it was allowed to rake pictures inside.

Insight into past Marrakech. A beautiful school where kids would study the Koran. The detail in the carvings, and tiles is amazing. Such a beautiful building. If you only see one, this should be the one to see in Marakech.
Interesting building. The building had some lovely stone and plasterwork and also some interesting timberwork, especially to the roof. A quiet haven in a bustling area of the city.

A place of beauty. Peaceful and quiet.. Very beautiful decorations throughout. Not really a lot to see other than the decorated walls and ceilings, but that was enough. We spent less than 1 hour here and I think we saw everything. Its a quick and easy stop to make, and very well worth the time.

Interesting, but essentially empty. A well kept and interesting building but essentially a large building with a few exhibits inside. Guides are on hand for a fee, but I'm not sure how long they will be able to talk to you about the location.

Amazing journey into the past. Not to be missed if only to see the students cells. Very ordinary externally but this hides an interesting interior with beautiful arcades courtyard with exquisite decoration.
Average, but nice building. Very beautiful building but not veyr intereting arts inside. If you are about to chose, go to the muslim school nearby

Beautiful building. Impressive architecture and decoration however a lack of information and guidance. Worth a visit if you are in the area. The combined ticket for the museum and the madrasa is a good deal.
Lacking in personal touches. An interesting place, but nothing to show how life was lived here. No beds, artefacts, clothing etc - what I think we expect from museums.
it's just an architect. I like the architect of this Madrasa, nothing else, where are some of students collectibles, also the mosque wall papers and furniture.

A treat of Islamic architecture and designs. The Madrasa was a kind of college where adolescents went to study the Koran among other things. You can buy a ticket to visit the Madrasa only or a slightly more expensive ticket to see the Marrakesh Museum of Islamic Art as well. We bought a combined ticket and loved both places. We went to the Madrasa as a family and had lots of fun taking pictures of each other from opposite sides of the courtyard. I'm sure the original occupants of this wonderful place would have objected to such frivolity! There are guided tours in various languages. It's worth every dirham!
Lovely Architecture. Its a lovely place and quite well preserved building. Worthwhile visiting especially those who love and appreciate the beautiful buildings.

''Thank you Morocco Countryside Tours Company''. This is one of the most beautiful buildings in Marrakesh and definitely worth visit. It takes you back in time. Some of our most beautiful photos were taken there.
it was recommend it by morocco countryside tours company after our 4 days trip to the desert with them
Value for money with the Marrakech Museum. Excellent examples of Moroccan architecture and some magnificent tiling! Worth paying 50Drh and then an extra 10DRH to get into the museum or vice versa.

Excessive entry fee. No signs with explanations or background informations. This kind of artwork can be seen throughout various buildings in Marakesh which is unfortunate given that the building has been described in guide books as the gem of marrakesh.
This was also the only time in marrakesh my father and I were hassled by beggars, the majority of whom were women.

Ok. As far as it goes. This does look like a wonderful building that has been, or is being, nicely restored. The problem is that without a guide or guidebook you are pretty much on your own. I am sure that this building has a rich history and can tell a few stories so why doesn't it? Without info on hand you'll get some nice pictures and a warm feeling of being terribly cultural but it's probably not worth a long trip, luckily it's right by the souks...
Interesting. Beautiful mosque, open to non Muslims. Beautiful architecture and interesting to see the college area and how the students lived.

Intricate Details. Visiting ta Madrasa is probably something every traveler should do in Morocco, whether it is here or in Fes or somewhere else. This one is easily accessible. The tickets only 40 dirhams (about $5) and for 10 dirhams more it includes access to the Marrakech Museum just a few steps away. Inside you'll be treated to elaborate carvings. A tour guide might be recommended, but there are a few signs posted in French which we were able to figure out.

Wonderful architecture and tiling. Tucked in the Medina up by the Musee de Marrakech the Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa is a must see sight of the city. Ornate panelled doors are matched by the highly picturesque and details ceramic tiles which cover the floors, walls and walkways.The student rooms are more like cells but those which have views over the courtyard with its huge central water feature are worth queing to get in to. Close you eyes and you can almost hear the rhythmic recitals of the students learning the Koran. A photographer's paradise as well with great angles and lights.
Beautiful architecture. Beautiful architecture, used to be a school for boys I think. Unfortunately on the day we visited there was a fashion shoot and select parts had been closed off. Disappointed.
GORGEOUS. As you can visit any mosque in Marrakech if you're not a muslim, this is a good way to look at very beautiful architecture. Its a gem in the city. Beautiful and quiet!
GORGEOUS. As you can visit any mosque in Marrakech if you're not a muslim, this is a good way to look at very beautiful architecture. Its a gem in the city. Beautiful and quiet!

Beautiful building. Well worth the 60dh entry fee, especially since you get into the museum next door for the same price. A lovely building the type of which you simply don't get in Europe. The mosaic patterns and the courtyard with the water feature are beautiful. Provides the backdrop to some great photos :-)
beautiful building. Truly recommended stop in Marrakesh. Amazing building, we took hundreds of photos. Difficult to put into words what you would see, so better see it for yourself.

Another Marrakech oasis. Though it took us a couple tries to find it, the Madrasa is beautiful with a running fountain and beautiful Islamic tiles and design. It's not very well preserved unfortunately. But it is a nice break from traversing e medina.

Beautiful experience in Marrakech. Definitely a must do in Marrakech....though be aware that you might get an impromptu guide who as with everyone in Marrakech will ask for some money for his time.....the guide we had didn't speak particularly good english, even so definitely worth a look!

Fantastic photo opportunities!. The Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa consists of a great deal of photo opportunities. There's a huge amount of handcrafted arabic architecture. A beautiful court yard with a pool offers a great view of the building from the inside.
Absolutely stunning.
Beautiful medersa. make sure you don't miss it unless you already saw medersas in Fes. It's difficult to get there so make sure you know your way before going.

Stunning. My first ever visit to a Madrasa and it was awesome. The whole place has the most stunning calligraphy, carvings, doorways and courtyard. The tiny rooms on the first floor around a passage and looking down over the courtyard make a great image.
Loved the architecture

Fantastic building, wonderful example of islamic architecture. The old school building, attached to the mosque next door, was founded in the 14th century. The building housed approx 150+ students and was their home as well as their place of study.The building is a great example of traditional islamic architecture... a beautiful courtyard, fantastic carvings, doorways, arches, wooden doors and cool pools.One of the highlights of Marrakech.

Beautiful picture spot. Finally a well taken care of Medersa! 5€ was an okay entrance fee. Not really much to do inside, but look around, take gorgeous pictures and be stunned by the silence within such a loud bustling city.

Very beautiful to explore for an hour or so. Gorgeously decorated, this is a very itneresting place to explore for an hour or so - we took dozens of pictures and had fun exploring the various rooms and the central courtyard. Well worth a visit.

Well worth a visit.. A former Islamic college in the heart of the Medina is worth a visit for the stunning decor and a glimpse of how students lived in tiny rooms surrounding the central courtyard. The stairs to the first floor are not the easiest to negotiate being different heights and the corridors are very narrow but, like the rest of the madrasa, are beautifully decorated with coloured tiles.

My favourite attraction in Marrakesh. Out of all the sites we visited in Marrakesh this was my favourite. The carvings are detail are simply stunning. It gets very busy in the mornings with tour groups but late afternoon it is much quieter and you are able to get better photos and have a more relaxing visit.
Worth a visit. Very interesting , super decor, the amazing architecture should not be missed, fascinating to walk around the tiny rooms used by the students not so long ago
Magnificent. Truly spectacular architecture and art, a testament to craftsmanship and devotion, tranquil and filled with an awe and beauty, baraka and grace.
Something other than souks. Courtyard was striking and insight into the conditions for medrassa students.Not much more than the courtyard and labyrinth of student quarters. No English interpretation.
Impressive. Great iopportunity to see the tile work and with a joint ticket with the museum a pleasant diversionj for an hour or two

A Little Overpriced. I enjoyed my visit to the Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa and opted to pay one euro more in order to gain access to the nearby museum. The historical building of the dormitory was beautiful and fun to explore, though not very complex so it did not take long to walk through it in its entirety. I was looking forward to a walk through the cultural museum but all the information placards were in either Arabic or French - we should have known this would be the case, but typically there are English descriptions in most major museums. Our mistake, but it did make for a quick and uneventful visit.
Favorite site in Marrakech. Very beautiful and photogenic. The details on the walls and doors are amazing. Highly recommend. Can be crowded.

Lots of history!. We came here after being recommended to do so by our hotel and it was a lovely place to spend some time one afternoon. Very cheap to get in and you could buy a combo ticket for the Marrakech museum too. The only problem is that if we hadn't have known a bit about it before going we would have been very confused. The signs and explanations were in French or Arabic and we ended up somehow with an unofficial guide who spoke very little english. The central pool and courtyard are beautiful and some inside areas are very ornate too. Definitely worth a visit and it doesn't take long to look round.
Worth a visit. Ok attraction. Impressive decoration but limited extras. Once you have seen the study rooms not much else to see. Failed to find the museum due to poor sign posting

Beautiful place. The exterior of the building does not let you suspect the beauty you will find inside. While the main attraction is the central courtyard, it is very interesting to see some of the rooms where the sleeping structures still stand. Well worth the visit.

This was our first public building visit in Marrakech, and the best. I'm hardly a "culture vulture", but I think it cost under £2 to visit this palace, and the colourful tiles, carvings, views of courtyards and from windows were superb. It doesn't have to take long , but it is fascinating, so don't give this place a miss.
The Coranic university of Marrakech. The Medersa was a boarding school for students from Morocco and elsewhere. It is possible to see rooms and imagine the atmosphere in old days.
Interesting history!. Interesting to have a guide take you around with explanation or it doesn't mean much. Hover around the cash desk and somebody will take you around - we tipped 10 dirham.

Worth a visit. This building is by far one of the most beautiful in Marrakech and worth a visit. The entrance fee is not much and it doesn't take long to see it all, but the tiles, carvings etc are just so lovely.

A Madrasa is a student prision?. According to the story that madrasa was a place for students lodgement, as for classrooms.The students bedrooms were so little that I realy doubt that they could not have anything in the room than a little bed.There was a structure like a patio, and the rooms oppen in the patio (4 rooms). At the visit I tried to be clarified where were the classrooms, but the local guide could not clarify that question.The architectonic structure was very interessant, and at the groundfloor there was a patio with a fountain, and the toilet room was interesting, for the open irrigation water for the students toilet.At the final, we asked ourselves : This was a student prision???
Where did all the artefacts go?. This intricately decorative shell would have been so much more inspiring with some retained furniture/artefacts. Seemed expensive viewing.

peaceful day. if you are looking for a peaceful day away from the madness of the medina just spend a few hours in this cool and calm place.would recommend a taxi there and back as we got very lost even with our maps.
Beautiful place. Beautifully decorated place, this old koran-school. A bit more information on the students' life would have been nice.
Don't miss it. The Madresa is a must - the building is still being restored but definitely worth a visit. There aren't many buildings this age in Marrakech that are in such a good state of repair.
Worth a visit. A beautiful building sadly the exhibitions appear to be a bit dusty and not updated. However enjoyed the architecture and position of the museum
Most amazing place in Marrakech. This old Koran school has amazing architecture. The carvings , mosaics - the whole setting is a paradise for photography. We spend hours walking around!

Beautiful Madrasa. The Ben Yousef Madrasa features some of the best plaster and wood carvings anywhere in Marrakech (the zellij tilework is nice as well). The size and scale of the school are impressive, with a spacious courtyard and numerous rooms where students once studied. Overall, it was worth seeing and worth the 50 dirhams per person entry fee (4.50 Euro, $6).

My favourite in Marrakech. The only way in Marrakesh to see the insides of a mosque without being a Muslim. Not only beautiful architecturally, but also interesting in terms of history and lots of exciting details

Tranquility from the medina!. Set in the north medina right next to the Museum of Marrakech.Tip: it costs 50 dirhams (just over £4) to enter each of the Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa and the Museum of Marrakech but if you can buy a ticket for both at the Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa for a total of 60 dirhams.Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa is good to wander through. The building is well preserved with beautiful carved walls, tiled floors. You can enter the dorms where the students lived. Can be done within half an hour. Nice respite from the souks and very cool temperature wise.

Oasis from the madness. Trying to find places in the medina is not an easy task. So when asked the taxi driver to drop us off near there, with no signage just people trying to guide you to make money off from you gets a bit...lets just say annoying. So after a while when we finally got to this place. The school was like an oasis of silence away from the madness of the medina. The architecture in the courtyard is amazing. Shame theres not more of it in the array of empty rooms on the upper level.

Complexity and elegance rolled into one beautiful building. This building must be the epitome of elegant Moroccan architecture. The building is relatively small but it creates a calm and cool atmosphere as soon as you cross its threshold.Much of the elegance stems from the mathematically precise proportions of each complex piece of design. The contrast with the adjacent souks intensifies the effect that the Madrasa has on the visitor.

Amazing Islamic Architecture. Awesome place to visit. Amazing architecture. I recommend this place highly. Entrance: 50 Dhm per person with additional 10 Dhm if you wish to enter the museum (round the corner). Museum worth going even for its architecture. To give you history of the Madrasa (religious school/college) I have taken a description from wikipedia. The Ben Youssef Madrasa was an Islamic college in Marrakech, Morocco, named after the Almoravid sultan Ali ibn Yusuf (reigned 1106–1142), who expanded the city and its influence considerably. It is the largest Medrasa in all of Morocco.The college was founded during the period of the Marinid (14th century) by the Marinid sultan Abu al-Hassan and allied to the neighbouring Ben Youssef Mosque. The building of the madrasa was re-constructed by the Saadian Sultan Abdallah al-Ghalib (1557–1574). In 1565 the works ordered by Abdallah al-Ghalib were finished, as confirmed by the inscription in the prayer room. Its 130 student dormitory cells cluster around a courtyard richly carved in cedar, marble and stucco. The carvings contain no representation of humans or animals as required by Islam, and consist entirely of inscriptions and geometric patterns. This madrasa was one of the largest theological colleges in North Africa and may have housed as many as 900 students. One of its best known teachers was Mohammed al-Ifrani (1670-1745).Closed down in 1960, the building was refurbished and reopened to the public as an historical site in 1982.Reference: Courtesy of Wikipedia.
Packs a lot in. Very interesting religious school. Enjoyed investing what seems like dozens of little rooms where the students must have spent hours refecting and praying..
Must see in Marakesh. yThis is one of the most beautiful buildings in Marrakesh and definitely worth visit. It takes you back in time. Some of our most beautiful photos were taken there.
