Brilliant!. Beautiful and peaceful. We enjoyed sitting in the courtyard, listening to the sound of the fountain. Well worth a visit, and a nice escape from the busy souks.

nice for decoration on walls. In my opinion, once you are there, it is nice to see even though what you can see is just a "school" but the artistic decorations and writings are beautiful. Take also a look to the near Museum.
Great spot for pictures. A place with lots of nooks and crannies and interesting natural light to capture photos...interesting ti imagine what it would have been like to be a student staying there.
Stunning. Fascinating and beautiful. A must see. Very peaceful respite after a morning in the souks. Certainly one of the best and most interesting of the historic attractions in Marrakech

Beautiful, but perhaps not exceptional. The Medersa's pretty interesting, and looks beautiful, but isn't varied enough to justify 50 dirhams. You could be in and out in about 15 minutes and see the whole thing - but it is gorgeous, and worth the trip. A good place to nip into to escape the souks.

Great photo opp. Very pretty surroundings
Entrance is 50dh, a little overpriced
Good for taking nice pictures
.......

Beautiful place. Not sure we would have found this place on our own but the driver we hired for the day took us to several places this being one of them.Such a beautiful place, you don't what to miss this well worth the admission fee.The architecture is amazing, to see how much detail was put into this place is breathtaking, just remember that this place is getting old now and if you think it's going to in pristine condition think again. But saying that it's still a very beautiful place.
MADRASI BEN YOUSSEF. The most interesting of all the sights in the medina, well preserved with artefacts and tourist information gives a fascinating glimpse into a religious school

One of the best landmarks in the Marrakech. This is well worth a visit, especially early in the morning or towards the end of the day when the light is great for taking photos. The building is beautifully detailed so take your time looking around it.
Beautiful architecture. A bit difficult to find in the souks, but definitely worth a visit. The architecture is just amazing, and the details on the wood/marble engravings mesmerising.
Amazing. Breathtaking, you don't want to miss that. Architectural pearl. You can get a combine ticket for this place and for the Musee de Marrakech
pooly preserved. By the times when the koranic school had activity, it could be an excellent place. But nowadays need of maintenance, for example the floor.

Beautiful history & architecture. My wife & I went there with a guide. So he explained to us about the humbling history of this madrasa (school). The madrasa is now defunct and only used for tourist attraction. The interior is really beatiful. Our guide explained to us the different materials used to build the madrasa. So get a guide to fully enjoy & appreciate the beauty of this place.

very nice building, take a lot of great pictures here!. amazing view from everywhere in this building.if you are into photography, you can take some amazing pictures.well maintained and you can purchase a ticket in joint to the museum which is close by from here.definitely recommend.
One of the main reasons to go to Marrakech. This is in my opinion the MUST see atrtaction in this city. Lovely architecture and very well maintained
Impressive architecture. Stunning whatever your belief. If you can get a local guide to fill in the background even better. Best visited early in the day or late in the evening.

An exquisite Medersa showing fine craftsmanship. This is one of the largest Koranic schools in the Maghreb. Its rebuilding dates from the 16th century. The tiles,woodwork and plaster work are wonderful.

Nice quiet escape from the souks. Although a tourist attraction.. the authenticity of this location is what makes it so nice. You are given the freedom to walk around each of the 132 little rooms used by the students at the school and also around the central courtyard. Its a welcome escape from the madness of the souks ..combine with a ticket to the marrakech museum (conbination ticket cost 60dhm pp)
Beautiful Architecture. A must to visit during your stay, great building adorned with beautiful carving and an interesting layout.

An interesting insight into the Madrasa. This was a good insight in the the life and times of the Madrasa and you got a good feel for what it would have been like to study there in the centuries leading up to its closure as a college in 1960
Just Okay. This place is difficult to find and just okay to look around. You get to see the rooms of the children and teachers etc. Worth a look if you have the time.
Beautiful. This building demonstrates mosaics and you can walk around the upstairs and see the small rooms where the scholers lived, it's A very tranquil setting

Beautiful architecture. The Madrasa used to be a Koranic school which housed over a hundred children in the olden days. The simple bedrooms say it all but the wooden carvings on the eaves of the courtyard are beautifully done considering they are all carved by hand, a skill not easy to master and certainly some appreciation should be afforded.
Surprising. Walking in from a grubby back alley the building reveals itself to be the most amazing place, fantastic architecture and details, Just lovely

Just Ok. You can buy a ticket (60 dirhams) to visit both Museé de Marrakech and Ben Youssef, however, if you go first to the Museé, the second one won't make a big impression on you.
Just Ok.

It was fine, nothing special, really.. This Madrasa was nice, the mosaic tiles were quite pretty, and it's one of the places you're "supposed" to visit in Marrakech. Compared to similar types of places in other countries, it was just average. It's pretty but well BELOW average, if you speak English and don't have a guide or guide book, because nothing's in English - it's all Arabic, French, and Spanish. It's just empty rooms, there's no furniture, so there's no real context for what you're looking at or what it was used for. Just OK.

Nothing Special - not cheap. The entry fee was 50 Dirham for an old building. Nothing special. No signs with explanations or background informations. This kind of artwork you can see everywhere in Marakesh. For me it was a waste of money.
Worth a visit. This is a beautiful house located within the souks of Marrakesh. Definitely worthwhile a visit. Entrance is 20 dir.
Photographers delite. There's no furniture of artifacts, but as a photographer you can have great fun taking pictures of carvings, through ornate windows, painted cedar ceilings etc
guided tour. brilliant place to visit, full of history. our guide was very good and full of local knowledge. please do not give tips to anyone when asked

great Marrakech. This is my erd visit to Marrakech. Everyting's fantastic, except the way they treat animals and some smelly spots. There are a lot to be visited and I hardly recommend the Majorelle Gardens. Wonderful place

Beautiful insight into the history of education in Morocco!. This school was beautiful to visit and I'm glad I made it just before I left Morocco. It was amazing to look at and see how beautiful the architecture was back a few hundred years ago. I couldn't believe this was a school, I've never seen such a pretty school, so I was fascinated, to know who studied there and how it all worked. You do need someone to explain and give you a tour around the building as all the signs are only in french and Arabic and you would not be able to guess the history! It was quite hard to find the school and in the sun you do get a bit frustrated as there are no signs or arrows so you just have to keep asking the locals, who were really friendly. It was worth the 60 dh entrance fee as it included a visit to the Marrakesh museum down the road from this 'madrassa'. You only need 2 hours to see both places as they're both not so big. This was a nice escape from the busy souk and the hot sun.. I would recommend this as a morning visit.

Unmissable for architects or architecture enthusiasts. This 16th century madrassa (school) is a must for architects, architecture students or architecture enthusiasts. The tile, marble and wood work of the coutyard, classroom, rooms, etc. are masterpieces in carving. One can easily spend over an hour exploring the school and observing the many details it offers. The school is no longer in use but its typology will take most on a journey to its thriving school day times.

Breathtaking. You have to see this. The architecture is gorgeous, the silence is magnificent... It's not a Quran school anymore, but it still feels like an intellectual respite in the middle of bustling Marrakesh.
Amazing. This Quran school is one of my favorite attractions in Marrakech. A definite must-see. Try to go when it's not packed with tourists though.
Very Beautiful. This place was stunning and a welcome break from the heat/crazyness of Marrakech. We walked around it for a while and enjoyed how beautiful it was. Lovely visit!
beautiful architecture. well worth a visit - simply stuning architecture. We had a guide with us and it was nice to have more in-depth background.

Must-see in Marrakech. This place is a must-see. Do take a guide if one is available. The place is beautiful and very detailed, Moroccan architecture is beautiful overall. This place is worth seeing if you appreciate architecture and history.
Hidden Gem. I've been to Marrakech 4 times now and only realised this place existed last trip but its by far one of the beauties of the medina and should not be missed.

very nicely presented. Beautiful mosaics and wood carvings. Only downside is that there is no English explanations anywhere so if you are not fluent in French or Arabic it can get a bit boring. You need 30 minutes tops.

Tile work worth the visit. We did not stay long, this was our last day in Maroc and we were on overload for such places. The tile work and gardens were very nice. A good place if you are just beginning your visit.

A reflection of the past. It was only towards the end of our adventure we discovered the Madrasa was a 10 minute walk from our Riad. This place is everything you expect it to be and more. The architecture, like the rest of Marrakech has been perfected to an exceptional standard. The Madrasa is well maintained and we enjoyed exploring this labyrinth of a building. Tour guides are available at an additional, small expense. You could easily spend a good few hours around here as it offers so much culture. As much as we loved the chaos of the Medina, it was insightful to reflect and try to comprehend school life here.A must see whilst in Marrakech!
if you like architecture and art this is for you. Amazing Islamic art with colourful symmetrical patterns - great pics taken and can be enlarged. Go late afternoon as it seemed to be much quieter.

Amazing architecture, peaceful inside. Brilliant crafted building, love to enjoy some time wandering about.Outside was like a maze. Local people were not that nice. Make sure taking photos on the way to remember. Don't go to the leather market, too far and you will get lost in the end.

Beautiful. You must go see this, if only just to admire the beautiful Maroc architecture... All my photos looked amazing. Go into one of the tiny rooms alone and imagine being one of the children back in the day. Really peaceful place and reasonable entry fee

Well worth a visit. This is near the Maison de la phoographie so it's worth visiting. The architecture is fantastic. There were not any guides around when we went but it would have been worth getting one to understand what all the little rooms are for!

Beautiful reflective place. A truly lovely place, tranquil and calm. Loads of lovely corridors, nooks and crannies to explore. beautifully designed with typically well detailed Maroc decoration. If you are in Marrakech you really need to go and explore this place! On entry get a joint ticket for the Madrasa and the museum as the museum is also well worth a look around! Tickets are not expensive either i think around 75MAD for a joint ticket.

Beautiful!. The courtyard is jaw droppingly beautiful. The islamic architecture makes it a must see when visiting Marrakech. Great for taking pictures. Side note: Be wary of people trying to take you to see the tannerys outside. They claim they will not charge you anything but the person they hand you over to will upon completion of the tour demand money. Don't pay ad say you will report them to the police.

Stunning. What an amazing site. Just so beautiful and tranquil. Seeing where the studentsd lived and learnt was great. Be sure to have your camera with you as you will want to catch the beautiful architecture.

Amazing Huge Madrasa. it only required 1 ticket for the Madrasa & Art museum next to it, its huge beautiful place, with amazing colors & artifacts,
it worth an hour of your time defiantly,

Beautiful architecture. The tiling and plaster work in the central courtyard is stunning. Better going very early or late afternoon as there were many tour groups that swamped the place. There is little else to see, despite being told some of the student rooms were furnished as they would have been. It is best to get the joint ticket for entry into the museum of Marrakech as it works out cheaper - there is no information in either in English so a guide book offers the best chance of information if you don't speak/read french.
Nothing Great. Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa is an average madrasa, nothing to talk about. I would have preferred to see a functioning madrasa.
WE ENJOYED THE TIME WE SPENT THERE. IT is really a oplace that is woth visiting: i recommend it to everyone.it is very interesting as the site is very original.

Amazing place. Our visit to the Madrasa was well worth it. Although it is quite small the architecture was amazing and it was great to experience the place were thousands of students have studied the Qur'an over hundreds of years.

Beautiful Moroccan architecture and an interesting history. Tucked away in a side street with admission 60DHM (£6) each for both the Medersa and the Musee de Marrakech combined this makes good value.The architecture is wonderful and you get a feel for life here. The student quarters are stark and when you think how many were housed here amazing.Interesting and beautiful, peaceful and a great photo opportunity.
I enjoyed looking around.. Was interesting to see the layout of all the bedrooms and the architecture was beautiful. Took loads of photos.

Beautiful Moroccan building. Worth admission price to see the extraordinary carving, plasterwork and stonework and get some feel for the civilisation that thrived here. For D60 get admission to the Madrasa and the Museum around the corner where you can see pottery, clothes and berber crafts.
Great Madressa. Very well restored and maintained Madressa. Interesting and one of the main interesting place to visit.Expensive ticket price (50 DH).

Lovely courtyard, not a lot to see. This historical building of Quranic study was the owner of a lovely courtyard but you could see it all (there are empty rooms of ex-students too) in ten minutes. For 50 dhirams entry fee, you don't get a lot of ding for your dhiram, and there is just one board of information for you to learn from.

beautiful. the tile work and carvings here are gorgeous. its hard to imagine it use to be a school. you can go into the rooms where the students use to stay and imagine what it must have been like. like any other spot in morocco you will want to visit with a certified guide who can tell you about the history and all the specifics of each of the rooms.

Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa, Marrakesh. In the medina, this madrasa, or theological college, built by the Sa’adians, c. 1565 used to house hundreds of Koranic students and it’s easy to imagine their presence in the cells on the upper floors. The contrast of small, plain cells with the intricate decoration of the public, shared spaces is stunning. Like other Moroccan Andalusian buildings, the lush detail of plaster carving, zellij (mosaic tile), painted and carved wood of the public spaces combine to create a harmonious and meditative space. Cool, dark private rooms open unexpectedly to sun drenched, blue sky lit courts or shafts and the dramatic contrast makes this recently renovated building strikingly beautiful, definitely worth a visit.

A bit dull. It doesn't seem that this place is that well organised for visitors. There wasn't a great deal of information available to describe and enlighten - I think it would have been a fascinating place, but I didn't feel I got the full picture...

Just great. For someone who has never been to Spain, Ben Youssef Medrasa is shrouded in mystery and the architecture is just fabulous. It was not easy to find but once you are there you become haunted with mysterious history.
Worth a visit. Interesting to look at how things were and until quite recently too.'Cells' are good, especially the furnished ones.

a great experiance!. The architecture was amazing, the calmness as you walked in was also very nice. Everything we saw was just so detailed but it also showed the culture which was lovely. This place is perfect for taking pictures of the amazing buliding! I recomend this place if you like tranquil places! I really enjoyed this experiance. I was suprised by how much i found this place so interesting! But remeber if you do go to the building its also worth while to go to the art museum for only another 10dr which is not far at all from the Ben Youseff building. Remeber to bring a camera with you!!
Beautiful. In my opinion, the most beautiful building of Marrakech! And located in the city center so easy to reach.

Beautiful!. Although it was a bit tricky to get here (due to the streets being swarmed with con artists), once we had arrived it was worth it. The architecture was stunning. Definitely worth a visit if you're interested in Moroccan heritage and traditional architecture.

Educational Visit. Very interesting - it is worth the small 'thank you' for a local guide to tell you about the building, it's heritage and previous occupants, we were luck to have a retired teacher who had excellent English (certainly better than either my French or Arabic) who helped us get the most out of our visit.
Beautiful school. Amazing decor and history, well worth a visit, interesting background to each type of student study room, as some where designed with more light than other

Madrassa. Wonderful old Islamic school/hostel with incredible carving in wood and stone. In the back streets of the old town so cannot get taxi to the door, be careful of touts who want to misdirect you
Wonderful. Beautiful buildings and very tranquil, admission to here and the Museum of Marrakech can be bought on a combined ticked as they are virtually next door to each other.
Ben Youssef. A very interesting place to visit with very interesting architecture and see if you can work out which part of the pool is the deepest
Well worth the visit. Well worth seeing the ornate architecture how the students studied in their rooms and surroundings. Excellent value

Beautiful Historical Dormitory. The interior of the dormitory was so ornate and beautiful. We spent a long time exploring the nooks and crannies of the expansive building! If you are staying in Marrakech you must make time for a visit!

Get cultured!. I enjoyed the architecture of this school, the entry door and the country yard. Very cultural tour and highly recommended for the first time travelers to Marrakech. For more information visit alextravelblog.com

Stunning building dating back to Shakespeare's time. This building, restored in the past 20 years, was a sort of campus for Koranic scholars. Most of the rooms are small cells, plain and simple, many without daylight, where the scholars used to sleep. The most amazing part was the central courtyard where the patterning (tiles, wood and plaster) was overwhelmingly beautiful. A peaceful, inspiring space - definitely worth a visit.

Great arab design. We, after a long trip from the main square, found the Ben Youssef Madrasa and we did not regret it !It has a great history and some wonderful arabic design. We took lots of pictures and really enjoyed seeing the orginal arabic design and it is really unspoilt. It is worth every penny !

Interesting place. We visited this place and found it to be one of the most interesting places of historical and religious meaning in Marrakech, especially as the mosques are not accessible for not-muslims.

Beautiful and SO interesting. At first, visiting a school seemed like an odd and potentially boring trip. However, the building itself was worth the small fee (we bought a double ticket that also included entry into the Museum of Marrakech which is also worth a quick visit). The architecture was stunning, the intricacies of the stone and mosaic are astounding. We spent most of our visit taking photos in every room and corner. There is also an educational function in that you get an insight into what life was like within an Islamic school- there are still little individual bedrooms and a communal bathroom.This is a great place to visit and it is close to the Museum of Marrakech and the souks in the centre of the Old Town.

Impressive architecture.. A very good restoration which does not make it look too new
A very intriguing neighborhood and a perfect stop after The Photography museum

Beautiful example of Islamic architecture. If you are into history , religion,art and architecture, you're in luck this has it all. Beautiful example of the symmetry incorporated in Islamic art and architecture. Also great insight into the life of Islamic students in the glory years. Gives a totally different connotation to the word "Madrasa" then what it is often associated with in today's charged political climate. Must see

One of the few opportunities to see Islamic architecture in Morocco. As other reviewers have explained, non muslims cannot enter mosques in Morocco, so the madrasa offers an almost unique opportunity to see historical Islamic architecture. The building is not only beautiful, but also gives an insight into the lives of the students who studied here. There is a joint ticket for the Madrasa and the Museum of Marrakech, which is less interesting, but worth the few extra Dirham (I wouldn't pay full price for the single entry ticket to the museum only). If you get a bit lost on your way here, don't accept directions from "Guides" (there are no official guides) as this will result in demands for money, or a trip to a shop, which will overcharge your to pay your "guides" commision. If you want directions ask a shop keeper or a restaurant receptionist (and express interest in returning after you have seen the madrasa to shop or dine).

Simply breathtaking. Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa put me at a lost of words. The attention of this building is amazing! The quality of materials used is the best...A lot of history I learned and a few times I felt chills...

always a stunner. I've visited twice. It is truly beautiful. Try to go early to avoid the crowds. Go up both sides of the courtyard to the student rooms. One side has a little student room set up as it would have been. You can buy a combined ticket to the museum here too.

Lovely week in Marrakech. As you are not allowed to enter mosques unless your a moslem. this old mosque and school because it is not used anymore as a religious place can be visit.Nice architecture and nice to see how the student leaved in this place.

Beautiful architecture. The architecture and the intricate works were beautiful! Being here felt like you were transported to another era. The small courtyards and the dorm rooms are well worth exploring.

Nice school!. Beautiful arab architectural building, walking through it with cool breeze and seeing how the students used to live their lives in the school. Good students got better rooms and bad students got rooms without windows...Great ceilings, doors and walls hand carved and painted.

Better than El Hamra for us. We visited Maroc before Spain. So we saw Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa before El Hamra in Granada. Since Madrasa Youssef attracted us in deep, we did not excited for Nasrid Palace.

Beautiful!. For me, this place is a must visited place when you are in Marrakesh. The architecture is very very beautiful, the most beautiful I've seen in this city. Quite hard to find eventhough I have followed the map and asked some people to get there.
Go for the architecture. No information given or needed as the building and decoration is enough. Could do with a couple of well placed seats!
Worth a trip. Good in site into Islamic life but our guide rushed us through so we could visit his cousins carpet shop, uncles antique place, aunties shoe shop etc!!!!

Highlight of Marrakech. This is one of the must sees in Marrakech. A little tricky to find but well worth it. Beautiful architecture, amazing woodcarvings, stunning mozaics,
Cheap entry fee and walk around at your own pace.
Well worth a visit. Fantastic and interesting, use an authorised guilde as they have super knowledge of the history of the building, but well worth a visit and only a short walk from the medina.

Fascinating building. Try to get here early to avoid the big groups. It cost 50 dirham for entry, you can pay a little more to go in the museum but I didn't bother with this. Get the tripadvisor city guide and use the map to find it. It is quite a simple journey from Jemaa El Fina square. There are some basic information in french which isn't too hard to understand. Make sure you see the room in the balcony set up as it would have been when there were students there. You don't need a guide to explore it all.

Breathtaking. From the moment you walk in to the moment your foot steps out the door as you leave your jaw will not close at the wonder that is the Ben Youssef. I can't put into words the splendor that you'll see or the amazing artwork that you'll encounter. Go, experience it for yourself and soak it all in.

Fantastic!. The Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa in Marrakech is BEAUTIFUL! Built in the 14th century, it is covered in intricate tile mosaics and plaster carvings. It is the largest Medrasa in all of Morocco so it definitely warrants a visit!

Interesting but hard to find!. We went to this old school one afternoon, and only just got there in time to look around quickly before it closed at 6pm as we struggled to find it. However when we eventually did it was very interesting to see the boarding rooms and the beautiful architecture. As other people have mentioned, it was a shame that there aren't signs in English - a tour guide would probably be worth investing in. For only 50 Dirhams entry it is definitely worth going to see, just make sure you allow yourself enough time to find it! Also, don't be fooled by locals telling you that it is closed and that you should go with them to see the tanneries instead.

Very good example of Moroccan arquitecture. Similar to the Madrazas in Fes. Beautiful, quiet and full of details. Nice example of the intrincate details of Morocan decoration. Beautiful inner patio surrounded by student cells.
Must See. One of the oldest Universities in the World. Provided a great insight into the life of a Quranic scholar. The architecture was stunning.

Such beauty!. For us, this was the most impressive monument in Marrakech!
The Madrasa used to be and Islamic college.
So calm, beautiful and inspiring... Don't miss it!
P.S. The ticket is 60 dirhams (about 6€) but it includes the entry to the Museum of Marrakech wich is very near by.
Interesting. Very interesting place to visit although we found it difficult to find. There is a lack of signposts in Marrakech.

Probably The Most beautiful old Coranic School in Morocco. The medrassa Ben Youssef is a historic school which is perfect for those interested in looking at old lifestyles (especially Islamic ones). I have Visited Medrassa of Attarine in Fes, but this one is better. An all-in-one ticket for entrance to the Medersa, the museum as well as the ancient mosque, can be purchased for a reduced cost. Well worth a Visit
Madrasa. Our guide taught us about the history of the place. Pleased we had him - very little info around the building otherwise
fascinating. a fascinating visit - i knew nothing about the Koranic school & it was fascinating to learn how it operated. Not too busy & a wonderful way to spend a couple of hours

Like the fact that we can visit the living quarters. The Ali Ben Youssef Medersa is exquisitely decorated with stucco, marble and cider. We liked the fact that we are able to visit the upper level of the medersa full of tiny little rooms like monk's cells (not so in the medersas of Fes). These rooms are divided into several courts that gives one the feeling of a maze. Even though this is just a dormitory area, they are still richly decorated with beautiful stucco and wood. Definitely worth a visit.

If you had to chose muse/madrasa. I would have just chosen the madrasa because I enjoy the carvings on the wall. It's one of those quick tours unless one likes to just seat and admire longer or people watch. The rooms on the side well the insides are plain, once you've seen on side there is no difference really. Small rooms with barely any window all around but the carving on the outside and beautiful....if you like this kind of art.The muse had a few artifacts and beautiful lamps as well as a gallery of artist pieces. If history is what you enjoy there is little to get from here, but still worth a view if you don't want to miss anything.
Beautifull Islam. Beatifull place to understand better the Islam culture and all their habits.A place you must go in Marrakesh!!!

Good place to see, but..... It would be much nicer if it is maintained properly....There are no explanation on English. Everything is just on Arabic or French. This is not a big investment to place a couple boards with basic info on English.

Get lost in this beautiful Medersa. Truly amazing medersa where I lost myself in the rooms and stairwells. The main hall was awe inspiring. The work on the walls and ceilings phenomenal. The ability to wander at will and in your own time allowed a better appreciation of this wonderful medersa.

Ali Ben Youssef. This old coranic school was an amazing place to see, vibrant and detailed walls.
A nice place to relax and see historic life in marrakech and at only 50 Dh (or 60Dh to see marrakech de musee) makes this a great value to not be missed.

A semi interesting building. This place was an ancient school or something, I liked the courtyard and the designs were quite interesting. It's got shade so that's especially nice if you are walking around through the day.
very nice spot in Marrakech. very nice old coranic school in the middle of Marrakech's crazy medina. worth a visit, mainly because of the very nice spots to take photos!
a must-see place in Marrakech. most interesting place to see in Marrakech, gives insights into life of students of more than 60 years ago, ornaments were fantastic

Worth seeing it!. The place is very interesting. I really liked the architecture, wood carving and the colors. The students’ dorm was very interesting: some small and quite dark, some a bit larger and lighter. We visited this place in the morning so it wasn’t very crowded. Maybe a guided tour will be best!
Worth a visit. We were shocked by how many rooms were at this place and how small they were. But our guide explained to us that back in the old days, such small room was a luxury to the students.

Not the best sight in Marrakech. The main courtyard was very pleasant and walking round the building was interesting at for a while. However, after you had seen a few small former student rooms and the courtyard from different angles it did get a bit tiresome.At the cost of 50 MAD each, you got to walk around the site freely and weren't pestered by tour guides etc. Also, it was quite difficult to find (maybe we were being idiots) due to the highly placed signs, unhelpful locals trying to guide you to the tanneries, and close proximity of the streets in Marrakech. Recommended viewing time about 30 mins maximum.
Impressive. Really impressed by the sculptures and 'dorms', definitely a place worth visiting. Museum was ok, but mainly because of the building itself. Exposition was nothing special.

A little boring. Was a little disappointing compared to much of the other sights that can be seen in Marrakech. We enjoyed the Palaces and Jardin de Majorelle very much and this fell short of what we had come to expect in the city. However if you are religiously curious i suppose it could be interesting.

Worth a visit.... Interesting, peaceful escape in the centre of Marrakech. Fairly cheap entry price, combined ticket with museum is about £5. Architecture is amazing, with ornate and beautiful wood carving everywhere. Not huge, but worth a look.

Beautiful Inspiring Building. We spent about an hour here, wandering around the courtyard and school rooms. A beautiful building well worth a visit - go early if you can to avoid the crowds. You can also buy a joint ticket for the Musse de Marakech which will save you money, although of the two we found the Madrasa much more interesting.

Beautiful. We probably should have used the audio tour for this attraction. While the building is LOVELY, you loose a lot of the meaning if you just wander through. Definitely worth stopping in to appreciate the architecture.

An amazing Islamic school. This is one of the best attractions in Marrakech, serene, beautiful, educational, spiritual, fascinating. A little hard to find, and you need a good guidebook or guide to discover some of its features, but even without those, this is an amazing place to visit, especially in combination with the museum next door. Don't forget to visit the student rooms upstairs.

Not to be missed. Wander through the Souks northwards from Place Jemaa el Fna and you will come across one of Marrakech's finest examples of Moroccan architecture. About £5 entry (children free) and it doesn't take long to look around but it provides stunning photo opportunities and a chance to have a close up look at the Islamic patterns and carvings. For a couple of pounds a very friendly and talented artist will draw out your name in Arabic and this was a highlight of the day for all five children in our group! Really worthwhile visit.
Fascinating interiors. Fascinating - non-muslims cannot visit the mosque, but the Medersa is intriguing, and worth visiting for the beautiful interiors.

One of the best sites you'll visit. Slightly expensive for Marrakech but definitely worth a visit. The beginning of Islamic architecture in Africa and Spain is a must visit. It’s a shame they haven’t refurbished all areas of the madrassah.
Very beautiful architecture. Stunning wood and plaster carvings are amazing. Best seen with a local guide, who can give you some of the local history that might not be covered in the guide books
Worth the visit. Well worth the time. Beautiful school with amazing architecture and a step back into Moroccan history

A masterpiece. The architectural details of this ancient coranic school are splendid. Go around 4 o'clock where the light is not as strong for good photography. You can visit the room cells where the students used to live. A masterpice in the medina of marrakesh
Beautiful. Well worth a visit, but take a guide to tell you about it! Gorgeous building and interesting history.

Still amazing even on a 2nd visit. We visited the Medersa 7 years ago whilst in Marrakech and on our latest trip it was the only place that we wanted to go back to in the city. We would even go as far to say that if we ever found ourselves in Marrakech again, we would visit here again.
Most beautiful place in Marrakech. The artwork there is just increcible.Especially if explained! I am Lucky to be able to know Morocco so I could tell my friends about it....

Easy to miss but worth a visit. In an unprepossessing area the Madrasa is well worth a visit. The entrance into the main area is beautiful. Don't forget to look up as ceilings and use of light in the building should not be missed.

Excellent photo opportunities. This was such an interesting place! It's like a photographer's dream in there. We enjoyed exploring the grounds and the rooms, though wished we had taken a guided tour so we could understand it all a bit better. The informational signs were in French and Arabic only. Buy the combo ticket for the museum nearby, they are both worth it.

One of the better sites in Marrakech. This museum like most in Marrakech is primarily in French. Do your research before you go or get a guide. With a few paintings and photographs depicting some of the history this museum opens up to the large courtyard pictured above. Going up to the second level where the living areas were you can imagine and sit in the windows. The good photo is to catch a picture of your partner sitting in the window from across the courtyard. There are many small rooms on the second floor and again to have an explanation of most of these you will need a guide. I expect you will need about 40 minutes to complete this museum.

A wonderful historic building. Easily the place in Marrakech that we learnt the most on our stay, its worth it if you are English to pay a guide to explain the school areas and the muslim religion to you. Buy the double ticket for the museum as well.
Must see sight of Marrakech. Do not miss this wonderful historic building. Don't forget to bring your camera roe the great shots.

Beautiful palace!. This old coranic school is rightly one of the hot spots of Marrakesh. Its patio, main rooms and student cells give a good idea on how the life should have been back in those days. The palace is very well kept and offers many corners for beautiful pictures. If have already visited the Alhambra in Granada (Spain) you may find similarities in the style. Obviously the Alhambra is much more impressive but I think this Medresa is really worth a visit. We did it on our own without a guide and were done in about an hour.

Spectacular. The courtyard has the wow factor. It's grand, impressive and impeccably kept. On the second floor you can visit the student's accommodation and have a peek through the windows into the courtyard. Overall it's a magical place and should be at the top of your places to visit list.

Interesting Islamic Architecture. This is a beautiful building and it is easy to imagine the scholars still studying here. I would not have cared to have had some of the rooms with no windows which must have been awfully dark pre-electricity.Make sure to buy a joint ticket including the museum - it is really great. The exhibits are ok - but it is the building itself that is the main event. Even the toilets are done in a fantastic ornate style.There is also a really good café where we had a nice meal accompanied by an orange cat which ate most of my tuna :)
Madrasa. Nice to visit locally the architecture was beautiful. Nice place to take photos. There was a tour guide there to go throught the history.
A Must See!. Amazing, the architecture and detail is unbelievable! Great history behind this historical building.
Interesting bit of history. If you have been to another medrasa-well you get the idea... Hard to dialog, even with an educated guide about 'compare and contrast' to Western education.
Absolutley beautiful. The palace is beautiful. Defenetly worth a visit. You can buy the ticket for the entrance togheter with the Musée de Marrakesh also very nice

Well worth visit. bought combined museum and Ali Ben ticket, well worth it the ticket. Amazing architecture and attention to detail. The museum is small but the building is worth a visit on its own. After which you can go to the souks which are close by.

Fourty people visited.. Very peaceful and thought provoking visit. Amazing how dedicated the students must be. Their living quarters are quite bare, and small. The carving of wood and plaster in the main area are amazing, and beautiful.
Excellent Example of Old Morocco. Although it was not high on our list, we enjoyed it more than most of the other palaces and buildings. Great building for photos and fun!

Amazing Islamic architecture. The tiling and carving are amazing. It was also interesting to see the student rooms . I would like to know how you got to be a student at Ben Youssef Madrasa but otherwise really good.
Well worth a visit. This was a very interesting place and wished that we had read more about it before we visited so that we could have appreciated it better.
amazing place. The guide books do not do this place justice. It is very atmospheric and gives you a feeling of what it must have been like to study there.

Cool, calm and great architecture. Really worth stopping here to admire the architecture and to avoid the worst of the afternoon heat - lovely and cool! Most impressive toilets! Visit the museum a few steps away, not much to see exhibition wise but again the building is impressive, and they have toilets and a cafe.
amazing place. just round the corner from our riad' riad cinnamon so we were advised to visit this and the kouba at same time.

beautifull decorated. Just a must see!
There are a lot of empty rooms but at the first level there is a furbished room. For our kids it was a game to find that room!
The entrance fee was 60 dirham for adults and 30 for children.

Big place, little rooms. This was the dorm rooms for students studying at the university. 132 rooms or cells. Worth a short meander to see the variations on size, windows, levels, etc., plus the courtyard spaces have lovely tile and woodwork.
Stunning. Although the entrance is a expensive compared with other attractions in Morocco, the expanse and beauty of the structure justifies it.
Beautiful architecture. fascinating place and a good understanding of how rooms for scholars were like. the place is filled with beautiful architecture
Must not miss!. Beautiful building. Reasonable entrance fee. Very interesting, giving an insight into the history of country. Fairly busy, but no queues. Fascinating.

Wonderful building, worth a visit. Certainly worth a visit to this wonderful building, it is a delight for the eyes BUT the experience could be made so much more interesting if they provided some information about its history etc.
Judging by the number of visitors when we were there they cannot be short of the funds to do this.
Living history. Very atmospheric, You can just imagine the students studying, wonderful serenity in the center of all the bustle.

Beautiful. Not necessarily a must see, but we spent an hour or so wandering and taking photos. A beautiful building, nice to sit (on the floor) in the courtyard and listen to the fountains. Like many things in Marrakech, a little tricky to find, be careful you don't venture into the nearby Mosque, we very nearly did then realised it said 'privee' on the door!
Nice Islamic architecture. This Madrasa is well maintained and gives you a way to see how Koran students had to live in there small rooms, but looking at very nice artwork.

Beautiful carvings and building...shame lack of info. I really enjoyed the serenity of the building and the lovely work and carvings. It is a shame for non french speakers that there is no information or signage in english. So before you go, google the background so you understand what you are looking at.

Beautiful carvings and building...shame lack of info. I really enjoyed the serenity of the building and the lovely work and carvings. It is a shame for non french speakers that there is no information or signage in english. So before you go, google the background so you understand what you are looking at.
A showcase of Moroccan artistry. One of the best places to see the fine crafsmanship of Moroccan artists in mosaic tile, carved plaster, and woodworking. Don't miss.
Amazing place to visit. This restored building is a must see, and offers wonderful photo opportunities. The wood carving and the tiles are stunning and it is an amazing building - worth the visit.
Ancient Beauty. Beautiful architecture, tiles, carved plaster and cedar wood. A glimpse into an almost unimaginable past way of life.

Best in Marrakesh!. If you visit only one sight... Marrakesh does not have many sights worth seeing: if you can find it, this is one of the best. Just don't listen to the hustlers on the street trying to send you in the wrong direction!

Fine Moroccan Art. Old religious school. This is the Medersa. The rest, amazingly nice decorated walls, micro-room for students, and plenty of beautiful spots where you can get a nice view of the finest Moroccan decorations. You get there from the souk of Dar el Bacha quite easily!!!

Very interesting. This place was lovely to walk around and to get a feel for the history. I was a little disappointed as I had read all about it on the internet and felt it did not live up to the descriptions and exceptions. But all the same I would recommend to go and visit it so you see what it was like, the size of the rooms, the wood work,carvings etc. But be careful we had a local man try and latch onto us when we were making our way through the souks to get there and demanded money and tried to drag us into a shop. We didn't pay him and he said a few words but left it at that.

A quiet and interesting spot.... The Ali Ben Youssef Medersa is no longer a school..but is an excellent example of a long ago time and its architecture. The lower level consists of a huge courtyard with reflecting pool and wonderful examples of Moorish architecture. There is also a prayer room that you can enter. Upstairs are the rooms the students stayed in..small and labyrinthine...with one room set up as it would have been back in the day. This is not an exciting trip and honestly there is not much to see after you have been there for half hour or so, but it is quiet and peaceful and worth the stop!
Islamic School. Some beautiful mosaic work and wooden and stone carvings inside parts of the building. Interesting history. A peacefull space amidst the hustle of the souq.
Beautiful building. Beautiful building to visit but that is all it is, we had a guide to explain the history of the school and what the different rooms were used for.
Worth the visit. Worth the visit. For those with a view to history, this is a must see. Use a private guide. Not one that comes up to you in the street.

one of the few monuments to see in Marrakesh - a must in my opinion. The patio is nice, the rooms of the former students impressive (as very small). You have to pay to enter but you get to see some nice architecture.
Lovely for a bit of respite in the Medina. Worth a visit to sit and take in the atmosphere. Beautiful carvings, really interesting to see all of the dorms.

Beautifully decorated madrassa. This is one of the few religious buildings that non-Muslims are permitted to visit in Marrakech. It has been exquisitely decorated with patterns and reliefs.
The price of entry is nominal, but there are few explanations of any kind so you may wish to ask for a guide.

In the old town.. Nestled inside the wall of old town, this old school is worth visiting. It is slightly derelict and run down and at 50MAD per person it seems like an expensive attraction. You will see plenty going into the old town and the souks are on your doorstep which is close to the main square Place Jemma el Fnaa.
Stunning. A bit tricky to find, but persevere as it's well worth it. Don't listen to the locals who'll tell you it's closed and offer to take you to the tanneries instead.

Worth a visit but needs more information in english. 50 Dirhams entry although you can buy a combined ticket with the Musee de Marrakech next door for 60 dirhams. It is not easy to find but locals showed us the way. The site is pretty well intact but poorly maintained with very few signs or information in English. Much of the stucco work has been restored and is fantastic - very similiar to the Alhambra in Granada Spain. Some of the artwork on the ceilings is also very impressive.Initially it is awe inspiring and interesting but there is a lot of it and it is easy to become a little blase about it after a while. The site has great potential to provide a great visitor experience but currently it is great to look at but unless you have a guide book(we did) it fails on a number of levels. It would be easy to kit out some of the rooms to show what the students had to experience. There were only 2 out oof 132 rooms with some furniture etc but no signs showing where they are so without a guide book you have to stumble upon them.

Very worth seeing. Walk through souks to get there if possible. It was set up in a convent way where the students lived in cells. The architecture and wooden carved walls are like a little Alhambra. See the museum next door on joined ticket.

Interesting . We had to follow a local guy to show us the way. Very near to museum of Marrakech so easy to combine these two attractions. Take your time and enjoy the souks till you arrive. Our guide show us a bakery in a small underground room. When you arrive, its the same ticket for both Ben Youssef and museum 3?. Interesting yard and roofs. About a half of hour is enough.
An amazing place. A great insight in to life as it was. Beautiful and interesting. We had a combined ticket with the Musee De Marakech--greay value!

A little over rated. The Madrasa is architecturally interesting to visit - but once you've seen the inner quadrant and start looking at the classrooms, once you've seen one you've pretty much seen the rest of the building.
Well worth a visit. My husband and I really enjoyed looking around Ben Yousseff Merdersa. It's not very big but really cool with amazing architecture.

Cheap & worth a visit. It's kind of interesting to see how the students used to live but this wears after about ten minutes. It's cheap to enter so you might as well check it out but don't expect it to take up a lot of your time. Once you have seen one bit then you have seen it all. Nothing is in English so you have to use assumption a lot of the time.
A wonderful break from the heat.. Beautiful examples of ornamentation in wood and tiles. Worth a visit for the amazing architecture. Interesting to see the students rooms.

Worth to visit, is one of must see here. The medersa centers has a large courtyard with a central pool for ablutions. The building is covered in an abundance of decoration: carved cedarwood, exquisite stuccowork, and colorful zellij tiles. Some elements of the medersa are very similar to Alhambra palace in Granada. Go to visit this wonderful piece of islamic art!
Cultural must!. A feast for the eyes, a lovely peaceful space . . .then go to the Museum courtyard café next door for a coffee!

One of the better sights. Fascinating look into the lives of the many that walked through those doors. Well preserved (by Moroccan standards), and beautifully designed, this is one place that should be on any visitors to-do list.

A must-visit in Marrakech. If there is one thing you need to visit in Marrakech I would suggest going to the Ali Ben Youssef Medersa. The Medersa used to be founded in the 14th century. It was rebuild by the Saadians. It used to be a Koran school until 1962 before it was closed down. Up to 900 people lived in the 130 student rooms of the Medersa. The architecture and the displayed craftsmanship were amazing. Especially the inner courtyard was beautiful. Whilst walking across the courtyard you could look up to some of the dorm rooms. There were a lot of astonishing wood carvings, stucco- and tileworks. In the middle of the courtyard was a little pool. The architecture was fantastic and I loved all the details, unfortunately all the rooms were empty. I felt the entry fee of 50 DRH was a fair price to pay for this attraction. Usually shrines and mosques are not open to be visited by non-muslims. Therefore it is incredible interesting to enter this old Koran school. Another highlight for me was that there was a local calligraphy artist in the courtyard who offered to paint your name in Arabic letters.

Astonishing. The Medersa has its fame, and there are solid reasons for this. Is a beautifully preserved monument full of all the best examples of arabic-andalous architecture. Its visit is jump in history and transmits the sensations of life in a middle Ages Medersa. Despite now is no more a religious building an the lots of tourists, the sense of peace and meditation it can transmit is unbelievable. Definitely, this visit alone is worth a journey to Morocco and marrakech, to me.

Worth Seeing but nothing special. it is worth seeing as not much to see in Marrakech but was nothing special. It has beautiful moasiac tiles but i have seen more beautiful in Turkey and Spain. It is a pleasant building - so would add it to the list to see.

Step into another world.... Why would you come to Marrakech and not visit here? A slice of history, fantastic architecture and history. Wander around in awe and whilst there don't forget to visit the museum next door. Its an additional MAD10 on the entry price and also worth a visit.

Well preserved Koranic school. The Merdesa is beautifully designed and most parts are well preserved. It is expensive by Moroccan standards as the entry fee is 50 dirhams. It was interesting thing to see the rooms in which the 132 students were housed - varying in size, they were austere and would have been cold, and most had no natural lighting. Although it costs only 10 dirhams more to combine this with a visit to the Marrakesh Museum, it is probably wiser to save the 10 dirhams as the museum is not worth spending your time on. There were six in our group, and the 60 dirhams saved would have paid for one pair of leather slippers or 18 fresh large beignets with honey or three large breads stuffed with meat or 15 orange juices at the place Jemaa-el-Fna.

A Hidden Gem of a place. The Medersa could be very easily passed, and when you do find it. it is simple gorgeous. It is hard to believe that this tiny little school, done up beautifully with stucco and zellij architecture, used to hold 800 students, who were taught the qu'uran here.The place is very good value, but dont come in without a camera with plenty of storage left... you'll need it!

Amazing architecture. Loved wandering through this spot.....amazing architecture and history. Great stories of the students and teachers.....some of the best examples of architecture and history you'll find in Marrakech.

Wow - breathtaking!. We were recommended to visit this by both our guide book and our riad owner - and thought it was one of the most exquisite buildings we've seen. We could've spent hours admiring the carvings on the many walls and just imagining what life would have been like as a student in this place. Well worth a visit!

Worth a visit. Finding the Madrasa is half the fun as you wonder through the souk and try not to get lost. The Madrasa itself is not magnificent but is an architecturally interesting building and it's easy to imagine hundreds of students pursuing their Islamic studies whilst being crammed into the small dormitories which served as their home. It would be a shame to spend time in the city and not find half an hour or so for a visit.

Good but could have been better. Definitely worth a visit but I would recommend printing off some information about the Medersa before visiting as there are no guide books or signs telling you about the building.As we entered someone said we could have an English speaking tour guide in about 10 minutes - so we waited (and waited). In the end I went back to the gentlemen who had said this and he said he would guide us. Five minutes into his 'guide' we said thank you but no as his english was about as good as my arabic. We couldn't understand a word and I was concerned at the end he would then want a fee and we wouldl be none the wiser about the building.
Architectural feast!. A taste of Moroccan architecture in an old school. Pleasant retreat from the busy streets! Get lost in the maze of hallways and rooms, definitely worth a visit!

A Students must see. A wonderful guide called Ben (i know) took us to the souks and this wonderful historic university. An absolute wonder with both the architecture, history and planning which went into both the buildings design but also the usa of patterns, flowers and maths to make the building work in a climate such as this whilst considering political and religious beliefs.A must see by all but would reccomend a guide as their knowledge and english is second to none and worth the money.
Very cool!. Beautiful tile and stucco work downstairs, really cool tiny rooms where students lived in the maze-like upstairs. Definitely worth a visit!
Beautiful building. Very beautiful building with a pretty long history I presume because there was nobody or nothing there that could tell us anything about it?

very great place to visit. nice place to spend a sunday morning. beautiful architecture, but no where near as good as the amazing buildings of the Al-hambra or Cordoba mosque in Spain. well this is where it all started, interesting history.

Beautiful. Amazing carvings of wood, marble and plaster and best examples of ceramics around this old coranic school is so peaceful. You can visit the rooms where all the students used to stay and see the different styles depending on how rich they were.

Lovely architecture!. I really liked this place a lot, but would have preferred to have a guide give me a bit more history on the location and its uses, than my travel guide could do. The location is stunning, and I had a lot of fun walking around peeking through the student rooms and windows onto the courtyards.
Must see. One of the best attractions in Marrakech with wonderful interior decoration Dont miss this when in Marrakech

Interesting place. Very interesting to see the koran school and the small rooms the students lived their lifes in. If you like taking photos, you will find some beautiful motives here. Again not much information in English available, but one of the best attractions in Marrakech in our opinion.

Ben Yousef Medersa. Our guide said he was taking us to a museum and my heart sank. I'm not into museums. But this place was spectacular. The architecture and decoration was simply amazing. And the old "schoolroom" where the pupils used to sleep are a real rabbit warren. So glad I went to this "Museum!"

Wonderfully preserved. The price tag to get in is more than any other main attraction in Marrakech, but it is well worth it. You'll only need to spend 20 mins or so in here exploring, and there's no documentation of anything in English, but there is in French and Arabic. There are a few guides walking around who will answer questions and give you a little history; it's a must see. The word carvings and tile work are stunning!

Worth a look. Though going to a school doesn't seem like a big attraction, a quick tour through the Ben Youssef school is well worth your time. The architecture is exotic and ornate. The school is a dizzying grid of rooms, pillars and passageways. Everywhere you look, there is something to see. I enjoyed sticking my head through the tiny windows and climbing up the primitive ladders to the various rooms where young students once stayed. Pay special attention to the delicate wood carvings that grace the door and hallways. The tile and inlay work is beautiful. When you buy a ticket for the museum (another worthy outing), you can buy a package that contains entrance to the Ben Youssef school. The school is just steps away from the museum. I highly recommend a visit. ***Also, there is an amazing shopping square nearby that not only has incredible colors and textures for photos - they sell baby turtles and chameleons. Keep an eye out for it!
Come play hide & seek. Not your usual monuments/museums.Kids had fun playing hide and seek in this beautiful medresa.Mom & dad felt medresa is underrated.Simply elegant and serene
Interesting. Interesting with beautiful architecture. Fascinating and worth seeking out. In a maze of alleys. Atmospheric

Beautiful Koranic school. i was a bit sceptic, but definitely worth visiting. come to think of it, it was the best attraction in Marrakech. its part of the ticket to the museum. therefore its worth visiting both places. minimum will be 30 minute, we spent 1 hour and some. great picture spots.
Absolutely beautiful and peaceful!. Wonderful carvings, water spouts and tiles.Fantastic central courtyard! Loved it! Was like an oases from the hectic Souks.
Fascinating and evocative. Very enjoyable and could imagine student life in the Medresa due to ability to climb around the buildings. Beautiful architecture and a great visit

Amazingly courtyard and buildings. This old Quranic school is so amazing on a sunny day. In the courtyard you can look around at so many beautiful details. Afterwards going around you can see how the students used to live, and that was really cool to step in a room, and look how things used to be and how people used to live.Also, you can take a look out of into the courtyard in some windows. Leaving one behind in the courtyard and you can have some nice pictures with your head popping out of some beautiful building :)

Small but pretty. Not too much to see except its beautiful central courtyard. It was slightly invaded by art students but you could explore the maze of rooms and little courtyards. Definitely opt for the joint ticket with the museum for the sake of a few dirham!
A must to see. This ancient school has beautful ancient mosaics and carve plaster preserved and restored, and is one of the highlights of the Medina of Marrakech.

Stunning decorative detail. If you head north through the main souk, eventually (possibly...) you will arrive at this gem of a building. Dozens of study 'cells' where the students used to mug up on the Koran, but the real star turn is the incredible detail in the plasterwork, tiling and wood carving in the ground floor prayer hall and courtyard.

Beautiful, Mystical. Enjoyed this museum very much. The architecture is just outstanding. We had a private guide who brought us about and showed us the various rooms, but it's also possible to visit without. Very peaceful after having walked thru the souks to get here.
Interesting. The Madrasa was fascinating. History buffs will enjoy it and it only takes a few minutes to visit. Many great photo opportunities.
so hard to find. an interesting building but very difficult to find tucked at the back of the souks.Beware of locals offering to take you there - a few may be genuine but many have ulterior motives !

What a beautiful building!. Beautiful architecture, elaborate tiles work and wood carving. Take great pictures and enjoy everything your eyes see. What a great teaching and learning environment this must have been!

Architectural gem. Wonderful building where hundreds of students used to learn the Koran. Fantastic decoration, wood and stone carving and mosaics. Tiny cell-like rooms upstairs where the students stayed: some without natural light. Buy a joint ticket with the Museum of Marrakesh (60DH).
An amazing place. The small entrance lead to a wonderful surprise in this old Koranic School which has been carefully restored. There are cells for 132 students and beautiful tiling and cedarwork.
Wow!. The architecture was amazing. Incredible. It was a lovely place to see and we took many pictures. There was a huge class of art students there to sketch and take rubbings of the carvings.

Beautiful Artwork. A former school for scholars of Islam, it costs about 50Dm to go in, but it is worth it, I feel, to see the former rooms of the scholars, the beautiful wood carvings, and the calligraphy on the walls. You can also go to the cafe without having to pay to go to the museum.

a must see!. Out of all the palaces/gardens we thought this tops it.. not far from jemaa el fena... definitely worth seeing. ticket costing 60 dhirams each to visit this and the marrakesh museum (they are both next to each other)

Beautiful, do not miss. Fantastic, do not miss - we went with our guide, Abdul, who really explained its significance to us, which makes a big difference, as there are no (or few) explanatory signs etc
beautiful building. the Medersa is worth seeing - lovely architecture and Islamic design, very peaceful place to spend an hour or so. Recommended.

Lovely Courtyard. Another lovely courtyard, however the difference being this was school rather than a palace. The detail in the carving around the courtyard is good to see and the rooms upstairs, which are hollow shells allow you to view the courtyard from a different view! All in all a good place to visit!
Brief visit - will return. Magnificent moorish Islamic architecture - unspoilt. Unsurprisingly popular with tourists - wait for a lull between groups so you can see it without many others about.
Fascinating. A must see spot in Marrakech. Make sure you have a guide so as to learn more about the Madrasa and don't forget your camera.

Want to see maroccan architecture - this is the place!. Beautiful building, all you would expect from typical maroccan architecture. Great place to take lots of pictures.
Tip: the place is pretty much in the souqs of Markech, so when you visit, make sure you bring some time, as you will inevitably get lost in the tiny market streets on your way there and back!
Well worth seeing. Interesting and good visit to this amazing, beautiful and historic building. Displays and information could be improved, but still a memorable place to see

Islamic Architecture. MEDERSSA BEN YOUSSOUF, a beautiful, ornate building which is currently a traditional school where the Quran and Islamic sciences are studied. Built in 1565, rebuilt in the 16th and 19th centuries with restoration work completed in the 60's of the 20th centuryI would recommend this site to anyone visiting Marrakech. This is a great opportunity to take some great pics.Entrance fee is 40dhopening 09 am – 7 am April - Sept

If you see nothing else in Marrakesh, this one you cannot skip. The best of the best!! The only Medersa where you actually see how the students used to live in their little rooms in the upstairs area. Great place for good picture taking or the architectural details. There is a combo ticket for the museum as well.
Very interesting but take a book. Very interesting but would have got more out of it if we had taken some literature so that we knew what we were looking at.
Amazing detail. The mosaics were amazing, but the student rooms made it feel like a prison - poor guys! You can buy a ticket that covers the Museum, Badii Place and Medersa which is worth while.

Interesting, but not Extraordinary. For the price (60 dirham for the school and museum, I think), I was not very impressed by this Madrasa. Yes, it's one of few things you should see if you're in Marrakech, but don't expect to be blown away by the stunning architecture or unbelievable history. It's just an old school building with a lot of dungeon-like study rooms and a nice looking courtyard. Worth a visit if you're interested in the history, just don't expect to be wowed.
Interesting architecture. This site is well worth a visit, the architecture and the history are fascinating. The workmanship of the interior decoration is exquisite.

Hire a guide. Or simply read about the history on wiki before going. The role of Medersa in the life of people and islam is quite interesting. The level of detail of the building itself is fascinating and very photogenic.
beautiful building. Don't believe the "guides" who try to get you to go see their friends tannery or spice store. The Madrasa is open on Fridays and is a must see if you're visiting Marrakech.
Worth a Visit. Wonderful workmanship and interesting insight into Moroccan culture, many good photographic opportunities.

Truly Stunning!. This is a little difficult to find, but well worth visiting. The building is absolutely stunning with its wood and stone carvings and beautiful ceilings. The students quarters are also lovely to look around and if you are keen on photography this is definitely a place you should visit.As it is quite hard to find there are lots of locals hovering around the Souk waiting to guide tourists. Be aware though that if they help you, they will expect you to give them a tip.

Superb. Beautiful architecture. Doesn't take long to go round definitely worth it. We had a guide from the hotel who took us there his information helped our enjoyment of this place. Our guide rated it as the most beautiful building in southern Morocco. I think I agree.

historical insight. into the lives of religious students of yester year, seeing the cells where students ate slept and learnt around a breathtaking central court and pool, the decorative plaster, wood and tile work is astounding

Stunning Architecture. Take your time to wander round the Medersa. The architecture is stunning, and it is worth waiting for the crowds to disperse to really enjoy the atmosphere. You can purchase a ticket that includes the Medersa, Marrakech Museum and Almoravodes Koubba. Large cameras restricted in the museum. Don't rush these places, they are very special.
A must visit. Beautifully restored Koranic school with courtyard and pool withthe most exquisite craftsmanship.Oddly , always reminds of S.Marco in Florence --maybe all the little cells.
must see this.. Beautiful and peaceful, like a little Alhambra. No rush, no crowds, just enjoy being in quality space.

A Gem. Incredible that this beautiful madrasa likes within the souk, you could so easily miss the entrance. On entering you can immediatly feel the sprituality of the building that was a former theological college,at its height being home to some 900 students. There are over 100 dormitories or cells where the students lived, no *5 star accomodation for them! the view from the windows into the courtyard with stucco and artwork of cedarwood and marble is breathtaking. Buy a joint ticket to visit the museum next door if only just to see the magnificent metal chandelier.

Exquisit. This is Morroco as I imagined it to be....tiles, tiles, tiles. Great place for photos, the windows from the dorms onto the alleys of the medina offer the opportunity to catch a snap of the many donkey carts without intruding. The craftsmanship is incredibable.

Truly amazing. Easy enough to find by following the signs from the north end of the souks, not very far at all. The main courtyard and chamber are breathtaking, we took a 360 panorama photo and it is a really great souvenir from the trip.
Interesting to explore. Loved wandering around all the nooks and crannies, trying to imagine life as a student in middle ages.

Amazing old architecture. Worth spending 1-2 hours on. Wood and stone carvings breathtaking. Many great photo opportunities. Student accommodation gave an insight to how dedicated students would have been - several lived in each bedroom. One of of the the finest buildings we have ever seen.

Guides are worth hiring to see historical places. It is worth going with a guide because they tell you details that a tourist book might not. We hired a full day guide for 400.00MAD, make sure you tell them ahead of time that you have done all your shopping and do not need them to take you to the souks. You are better off eating at a place of your choice duiring the guided trip better yet insted of stopping to eat just grab some street fare.......our favourite was 'Musammen'.....fried flat bread plain or smeared with honey or chocolate.
Fascinating and beautiful. Worth a visit to help one understand the history and culture of Morocco. Beautiful mosaics and architecture, and very peaceful. We loved it.

Beautiful place to visit and photograph; combine with museum. Access is via Ali Ben Youssef Square - you will see the museum in front of you and turn left in front of the museum gates. There is a combined ticket for both museum and Madrasa (60 dirhams), which is a good option. The most impressive tiling and carving that I saw on this trip, and the building can deal with a large number of tourists without it seeming really busy. The inner courtyard is stunning, and great to have a sit in the sunshine.

A challenge to find, but worth the search.. We had staff from our riad walk us to the site, and we were VERY glad that we did! We could see how some people could have a bit of difficulty finding the entrance. One could easily walk past it a few times, and never notice it. Once inside, the building is beautiful and a bit of peace and tranquility with the craziness of the medina.
an amazing site. we liked the history and the 900 rooms but be careful of being led to the tanneries afterwards, that was awful.

A haven of calm from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. After navigating through the winding side streets I found my way to the Ben Youssef Madrassa. This 14th century college was a place of Islamic study. From the courtyard you can take time to admire the ornately carved walls, doors and windows .The area around the courtyard and the interior, where you can wander the 130 or so small dormitory rooms, provide some shade from the heat of the day.Some wonderful photo opportunities. Take time to admire the colourful symmetric tiles and the Islamic carved inscriptions.It wasn't too busy when I visited and it provided an hour or so of calm and quiet from the activity outside.
Very lovely building. Worth a visit, the building is attractive. You can but a joint ticket to visit the museum which ius only a few yards away.
Beautiful Mosacis. Lovely building & delightful tiny classrooms. Great views in the courtyard and intricate carvings. Well worth a visit :)

Murky Marrakech leaves me unimpressed. all the sited seemed to be kept open for the sole purposes of extracting maximum monies from gullible tourists without any maintenance of the sites or spending on their "splendour" apparent. There was very little to like, I'm afraid to say. To dislike - the list is almost endless. the bus tour which proudly pointed out the several UNESCO sites was a joke, narrated by someone who clearly had no concept of what she was talking about - for example describing the Art Deco influence in certain buildings where there blatantly was none....

A beautiful place.. This place is a total surprise on entering, like a lot of the buildings in Marrakech, very plain on the outside and very oppulant within. The intricate wooden and plaster carvings are fantastic, I can see why this has been used as a film set. Well worth a visit.
fascinating. arriving there coming out of the suk, you will enter in a palce of calm and spirituality, something you would not expect
Cool architecture. We enjoyed the cool architecture and ancient feel, but didn't like the slightly overpriced tickets (5 Euro) and hordes of tourists.
Breathe Taking. What more can I say! It's only a small place, so will only take a short while to look around, but the tiles and wood and plaster carvings you'll see are amazing, a must see.

Peaceful. I loved it. very interesting to follow the guide explain to you what this place is all about. if not its just a pretty place. Don't just go through the motions but take it in.Also the most beautiful bathrooms ive ever seen (but need TP)

Beautiful.. Beautiful and majestic building close by the Souks, though with no explantion in English.
Reasonable cafe by the gate.

Beautiful oasis of Islamic architecture. Peaceful beautiful and fascinating place. Intricate stone and cedar wood carving. Built round a central courtyard with a square water feature. A tranquil relief from the noise and buzz. Worth hiring a guide who will approach you inside very politely.

Interesting. The building is very much complete, and it is interesting to get a feel for how the students would have lived in their tiny rooms.More explanation of the history would have been nice, as would some English translation.Definitely get a joint ticket to visit the museum too which is less than 10 minutes away, and has a nice outdoor cafe.
Great architecture. We walked through the madrasa in 25 minutes. It is beautiful, stunning architecture. Entrance was 50 Dirham/adult
amazing architecture. this building was stunning lovely to walk around peacefulland interesting. great examples of tile work,ceilings and otherbeautifull morrocon architecture.

Go visit!. This is a very old Islamic school, situated in the heart of Marrakech. Superb architecture - cheap tickets to this and the museum next door, both very worth while a visit. Crown prince Willem-Alexander of The Netherlands and his wife visited, as well as Queen Sofia of Spain.
A must see. One of the best-maintained buildings in the Medina. For best value, but a joint entry ticket to the Medersa and Marrakech Museum from either site
Architectural treasure. A beautiful building. The perfect place for hide and seek. I sat in the central courtyard and just took in the beauty around me whilst grabbing some sun.

Beautiful!. We visited this on our last day in Marrakech and we are so glad that we did! Ornate is an understatement! The building is phenomenal. There are such intricate carvings. The entire building is stunning! A must-see!!
Well Worth a Visit. Stunning building and welcome respite from the souks. A cheap ticket lets you in to both this and the museum next door and is good value.
Beautiful building. You get a real feeling for how the students lived by being able to go into the rooms (cells, more like).
A wonderful surprise!. We thought we'd visit as we had several days in Marrakech but I wasn't particularly excited at the thought. It was AMAZING! A true hidden gem.

Beautiful. I love the tiles and all that wood work and painted!
All that colors, its a incredible work!
Like all traditions had things very beautiful and some others very bad, but a nice Museum to visit!

A must-see attraction. Just north of the souk the madrassa is the most expensive property we visited whilst in Marrakech - 50 DHR or 65 if you do the museum as well.It is probably the best £5 I have spent - the interior is amazing. There is incredibly intricate carving, plasterwork and painted decoration. A lovely pool in the courtyard displays enchanting reflections as you walk around it.The upstairs is a warren of rooms but gives some nice views iver the courtyard and the amazing doorways.
Must see. fab Architecture - interesting peaceful place away from the hustle and bustle for a few hours. wondering around the small student rooms you can imagine what life would have been like.
Fantastic architecture. If you have a good imagination, you can imagine e the students filling the rooms. The courtyard alone is worth the visit. Does not require a prolonged visit.
Exquisite Traditional Architecture. In my judgement it is one of the most perfect examples of ancient Moroccan design. It is a must-see.
Beautiful architecture. Beautiful court yard & mosaic work. Tiny little rooms, where the students use to live. Reminded me of a monestary cell.
amazing architecture. stunning building, interesting to see where and how the students lived here. allow no more than 1 hour.
Interesting sight but not amazing. The architecture and decoration is interesting to look at, but nothing to see other than that. One of the more interesting sights in Marrakech though.
