Dull. Not much to see unless you like architecture, a lot of guides wanting to show you round on a fifteen minute tour, not sure what you could see for all that time, but quite a cheap entrance fee about 60 dirham so on great loss

Worth it. The museum was a bunch of badly installed rubbish, the contemporary art section was (excuse me) a joke, but the real part of the madrasa, where the little cells of the students were, was incredibly pretty and interesting. Reminded me a lot of the cloisters and monasteries in Italy. Then there was a very impressive courtyard in the middle which made the hassle at the entrance worth it. Amazing woodwork.
Top sight of Marrakech. Beautiful place to visit, lovely colours and work on the walls. If in Marrakech this is the one place I would recommend definitely stopping at.
Worth a Look. The Medersa is worth checking out, but there was not a lot to it. It's located near the Museum of Marrakech and Maison de la Photograhie so altogether they make a nice excursion.

beautiful medersa. beatiful building and a very peaceful refuge from the hussles and bustles of the medina , the decoration is one of the amazing things that makes it very pretty and worth visiting. highly recommended.

Must have been special place. Empty rooms, some amazing decor but practically no explanation of the usage and purpose. Apparently this used to be the largest religious school in North Africa - a Hogwarts of Morrocco? I could have used a guided tour, an audio guide or at least some signage.

Must see in Marrakesh. This Koranic school, which closed in the sixties, once had 900 boys studying the Koran. It is an amazing building with lots of lovely architectural features and is certainly worth seeing

Calm in the middle of clamour. Its difficult to find in the warren of streets but worth the effort. The courtyard with the rooms overlooking was a serene spot of calm in the middle of a busy city. It is difficult to image hundreds of boys being taught here.
A hidden gem. Beautiful building, well worth a look. It is also a great photo opportunity as there are lovely internal windows.

Beautiful and peaceful. It's a little difficult to find the Medersa but worth a visit. As tourists can't go into the mosques in Marrakech, this is the perfect place to experience the spiritual and cultural side of the area

Stunning. A truly stunning building, where colourful tiles blend with warm terracota tones, and the contrast between the blue sky and cool courtyard make for some great photos. Explore the rooms where scholars once sat and savour the coolness and stillness. If you've seen the film 'Hideous Kinky' you'll recognise that the Medersa was used as the place Julia went to find enlightenment in Algiers.
Stunning architecture. A beautifully restored traditional madrasser with wonderful details, definitely one of the highlights of our visit

Like going back in time. This madrasa has beautiful architecture, the tiling, the courtyard, the woodwork, the ceiling, the plasterwork, everything is just perfect. A must visit if you are in Marrakech

Good to see. Entrance fee was 50 Dhrms and its also worth paying the extra 10 Dhrms for the Mesuem ticket at the same time as its only round the corner from the Medersa (at the door its more expensive). Check out both and see the history of the place.

Impressive Koranic college. Shut yourself into one of the 100 small rooms that made up this Koranic boarding school and you can begin to guess at how the 900 students here might have lived. The central courtyard with its decorations and water feature are impressive in scale and execution. But even the living quarters are finely decorated with moulded plasterwork. It is by far the most fascinating building to be seen on a joint ticket with the Museum of Marrakesh and, when it's not closed for renovation, the Koubba el Baroudiyn. It's main drawback is that it draws crowds of visitors which can detract from the calm of the place.

Stunning!. This is really worth seeing - definitely the historic highlight of the city. The intricate detail of the decoration is incredibly beautiful, and the tiny students' cells are fun to explore.

Needs TLC. The building is a historic site but not properly preserved at all with bits of the plasters coming off, broken door frames, no English descriptions or explanations of what it was, how it was run, its history etc. Not the best value for money for the combined ticket of the extremely dirty and dusty museum and the madrassa.

Worth a visit. Amazing structure and intricate sculpture details. Tiny rooms giving you an idea of life in a Madrasa. 50DM to get in. No dislikes although it can be a bit difficult to find through the maze of streets and alleyways.
Old monument. very interesting monument and i recommand to everybody to see this monument. the medersa need a small reforme in order to make it as pefect as hestorical as much as possible.
Interesting but poor value. Ornate building but little explanation and only 2 rooms had any artifacts etc . It is not easy to find and some more signage would be helpful
Worth a visit. Very good place to Visit when in Marrakech. Don't forget to go to the museum as it's courtyard is beautiful.

Unmissable!. This ancient Koranic college is an exquisite example of Medieval Moroccan architecture and design, and gives very interesting insights into what life would have been like for the students and tutors there centuries ago. The style is like the Alhambra in Grenada, but it's a much smaller building of course. Finely carved plasterwork, beautiful mosaic tiles (zellij) and a gorgeous pool in the central courtyard, plus you can visit the interior and some rooms are set up as they would have been, with typical artefacts like study desks and cooking equipment. The only problem is that this famous site gets so crowded, especially with coach parties. Top tip is to get there as soon as it opens in the morning or just an hour or so before it closes - you'll enjoy the experience much more. The Medersa is right near the Museum of Marrakech and also the Dar Bellaj (House of the Stork) which is a very itneresting art gallery.

beuatiful historical site. The medrasa is a great place to get a sense of what Marrakesh was like in the 1600's. Seeing the 132 cells where students studied gives you a feeling of the type of life they must have lived

Must see. This is my favourite building in Marrakech. Better than the museum next door. It's an old Koranic school and you can still feel the rigour and the beauty of the place. Little cells where the students used to live around a big and splendid courtyard. Visit if you can.
ben youssef madrassa. interesting location in the heart of the souks. more information at the location would have been useful. nothing in english, french or arabic descritions only
A "must see" for beautiful architecture and atmosphere!. It was right at the end of the Souks, and if you get tired, you have to walk all the way back, but it was worth it!!!
Beautiful building. Lose yourself in the maze of rooms and marvel at the stunning interior courtyard - definitely worth a visit.
Interesting!. The history and the carved stucco took our breath away.It displays all the wonderful decorative detailing what was the golden age of Moroccan architecture. Well worth a visit!
Interesting site - an insight into centuries of learning. This was a very interesting historical site, best advice is to go with a guide who can provide much more information than a book

Impressive building which allows entry to non Muslims. Well worth seeing. You can visit the 130 student cells which are very much like monk cells and where nearly 900 students from Muslim countries studied until the 60s. The building also consists of a main courtyard area with beautiful tiling and carved stucco and Koranic text, an ablutions basin and an elaborately decorated prayer hall also with Koranic calligraphy. Impressive.
Stunning architecture. Islamic art and architecture fantastic to the eyes! Probably my favorite monument in Marrakech! Water basin reflection heaven for photographers..

Gorgeous retreat, fashionistas, designers and photographers will love it. The Jardin Majorelle offers two separate tickets, one for the garden itself and one for the Berber Museum, set within it. It's worth getting both. The garden itself is a lush if a little strange oasis, offering a haven to tired, hot visitors. There are oversized cacti (like a Dr Seuss book), vividly coloured flower pots and yards and yards of the amazing blue. The Berber Musuem is a small but very well turned out museum that displays the culture and crafts of the Berber tribes, including beautiful and striking pieces of jewellery, rugs, cloaks etc. The ticket prices are expensive in comparison but worth it for its uniqueness.

An Old School for Boys for Koranic Study. Hundreds of little rooms, some with outside windows, surrounded lightwells in this amazing large courtyard building where the First Koranic School in Marrakech educated Moroccan youth in life's essentials from the time of the Scholarly Ali Ben Youssef, an Almoravid Emir 1106 -1125.
Stunning. ... architecture. Peaceful and interesting. No need for a guide unless you really want to know details.

Beautiful. This was a truly worthwhile trek through the souks to eventually find this, the only mosque non-muslims are allowed in in marrakech(apparently). It is absolutely stunning and has some great history to go with it.

Interesting. As with many of the buildings in Marrakech - it is difficult to single any out. This was complete with the "cells" that the pupils had lived in until 1962. All the signs are in French or Arabic - so unless you read either language it can be a little awkward. I have "schoolgirl" French - which was sufficient to get the gist! It was certainly worth the trip.

Beautiful and relaxing. Do not miss this place if you stay in Marrakech. The courtyard is beautiful and relaxing with impressive architecture. The walls are full of details and the place is more impressive than the other palaces in Marrakech. It is not so big and located in central Marrakech. It is easy to find if you have a map. The entry fee is quite high compared to other places in Marrakech (but not to in many other countries). You can buy a ticket that also includes the Marrakech museum.

Very impressive. Worth to visit! Marvelous decorations. They furnished two student rooms to show you the differences between a peasant and a city student. It is a good idea to visit it together with the museum.

What a beautiful site. Very peaceful and beautiful monument in the heart of the Marrakech Souk. Liked the caligrapher who will inscribe your names in arabic for a very reasonable price. And loved the mosaics, the fountains, in fact the entire experience.

Beautiful Architecture!. Our of all the places we visited, except for maybe the Hassan II Mosque in Casablanca the Madrasa al ben youssef had the most beautiful architecture and mosaics that we saw. I highly recommend a visit.
Wonderful. The architecture of this place is breathtaking, and although there were lots of visitors around, one can almost feel the tranquil atmosphere

Hidden Gem. Hidden within the souk, this was a bit of a walk but the architecture was beautiful with lots of carved details. It would be a shame to go to Marrakech and not take the time to visit this Gem
Educational. Loved the architecture and guide was very interesting when he talked about the history of the place.

Interesting architectural design.... People who are interested in history, architecture and calmness then this is d place of interest. Total calm n peaceful inside and beautifully designed with perfect workmanship. Fascinating wooden carving, mosaic flooring n beautiful ceiling...worth a visit.
Amazing!. Unfortunately it was very crowded but itá a fantastic place to see. Just try to image all those boys running around, sleeping in the cambres, studying....
Medersa. Fantastic architecture, mosaics and history. Very evocative, couldn't believe how small the bedrooms were

A very humbling place. A very aesthetic and humbling visit. The walk there is a particularly good souk and once you get there you will notice the vast difference in the atmosphere - it is so calm within the madrasa. The fee was reasonable but there wasn't much to read or explain - this didn't matter too much as we just soaked up the aesthetics and atmosphere and enjoyed a peaceful hour away from the hustle and bustle.
really impressive. little harder to find but the carvings are breathtaking,and in pristine condition, loos available and cleanabsolutely recomend a visit

Oasis of calm in the medina. Well worth walking through the souks to find this beautiful place: a myriad of small cells, great wood engraving, tile-work and impressive arches around a tranquil pool. A wonderful place of calm amongst the heat and madness of the medina. Recommended.
Rare insight. Fascinating "monastic" college and seat of learning. A good hour wandering round and exploring, admiring the Islamic art.
stunning. A historical and architectural gem. Very peaceful and well priced. educational and interesting with lots of photographic opportunities.
Sublime. Try and get there before the crowds to really feel the beauty of the place. Explore the warren of side rooms as well as the main halls

A must visit. Really pretty place, so much detail. We were taken here by our guide for the morning and bought a ticket for here that would also get us into another tourist site. Well worth a visit and make sure you have your camera!
Interesting. Inexpensive opportunity to witness some great Moorish style architecture and to learn about Marrakesh history and life in an Islamic college
The only mosque non-Muslims can go in.. We liked the history of the place and admired the artistry of the tiles and carvings. You could hire a guide if you wished.

My fourth visit. A superb example of Moorish-Andalucian architecture. It is still in good condition and great fun to play in (yes to play in). There lots of student rooms to look in and to poke your head through their windows. Lots of beautiful spots within it. A true gem

An outstanding bit of history. The architecture and decoration of this centuries-old school make it a "must see" for visitors to Marrakech. It is easy to imagine a scholar's cloistered life in the 17th century, and the displays help bring that to life.

interesting. really good, a very different life . Kids could imagine what it might be like to be there. Beautiful peaceful place in the middle of a loud busy city. A quiet moment after the colour and noise of the souks. Goos value for money

Nice building. Nice architecture with great decorations. Well worth a visit.
There is very limited information - and only in french and arabic - so you need a guide or a good guide book.

December visit. We found Ali Ben Youssef Medesa (Madrasa) with a little help from people in the Medina. It was a lovely building and beautiful architecture. It was quite busy and is a little more expensive than some other sites, but really compared to UK prices very reasonable.

The only building worth seeing in Marrakech. With many features recognisable from the Alhambra in Granada, Spain, this is a beautiful building. Don't buy the ticket for the museum as part of the package deal, it is a waste of time.

one of a kind. a brilliant and beautiful mosque, very elogant and gives an understanding of how things were during that time and also the materials used to make the mosque reflects a lot of how the time and trade was during that era
awsome. The whole of this medersa is so well preserved (or possibly renovated), and so beautiful in its architectural form and decoration, it is definitely worth a visit.

short break to marrakesh. liked everything...the people, the food, the weather. good quality rugs n carpets available at reasonable prices so bought 2 rugs, the botanical garden is a MUST as is the museum /moasque

Former Koranic School. Situated to the north of the Medina, near to the Marrakech museum the Ben Youssef Medersa (entry 60 dh incl Marrakech museum) is a fascinating place. The walls covered by Koranic verses, the style is reminiscent of the Alhambra. You can visit (upstairs and downstairs) the rooms in which the students lived and studied, most of them set off from small, enclosed squares which themselves surround the main internal courtyard. A must see in Marrakech
Good architecture. Old school with very nice architecture, there is only the building, no brochures or guidesInside the Medina easy walking
Worth it. you should go see this medrassa. It is the #1 tourist attraction and worth the visit. Especially the students quaters are quite interesting to see.

The highlight of our trip in terms of historic sites. The sheer beauty of the designs and inscriptions. It was a school for learning the Quran but such time and love must have been spent on decorating the building that goes to show how highly the people of the time regarded learning.

Same tiles as in other places. The Ali Ben Youssef Medersa was the last of buildings we visited during our trip in Marrakesh. And we encountered the same tiles, other decoration, and explanations only in Arabic and English which we encountered before.It was fun to see the the small rooms where the students were tought and the two rooms which still had furniture in them. Tip: It is hard to find, so get a cab and ask the driver to wait for you so you're sure to have a ride back.
Just beautiful. A must see when you visit Morocco, beautiful tiles and woodwork. It seems to go on forever when you start climbing the stairs. A lovely peaceful break from the madness of the Souks!

Nice, but get a certified Guide. We lucked out and found an English speaking guide near the Market area (main road). He had a certification card around his neck - not sure if it was valid or not. One piece of advice, tell him you'll pay accordingly at the end of the tour. If you don't want to go to a hard sell antique rug store - tell them up front. The Madrasa was a school at one point and gives a good look into the historical school environment. I couldn't imagine living and studying in such small little rooms (cold, cold rooms in December). Our guide took us to the Madrasa as well as the Marrakech Maison - one ticket gets you to both. Then we got led to where the tanneries are, where the old Berber hotel is, a Pharmacie, etc. Places to always buy something, just have to have thick skin and say no - not interested.
Beautiful!. Very interesting to visit, and soooo beautiful. Especialy the court yard in the middle. Don't miss it!

Superb Architecture. This is one of the best attractions in Marrakech. A little more difficult to find at the northern end of the Medina. I spent half an hour wandering around the Ben Youssef Mosque trying to find the entrance, which is an unassuming dark doorway opposite the Mosque. For 50 dirham you get access to a very old Islamic school.I went first thing in the morning and had the whole place to myself. Awe inspiring does not do the building justice. The quality and sheer beauty of the carvings and mosaic work are simply stupendous. How 800 plus students fitted into the building defies belief.The ground floor dormitories were obviously for junior students with no windows apart from high level ones, presumably to discourage young students from being distracted by the outside world.Upstairs the rooms are bigger and there is a more relaxed feeling.The main courtyard is light and airy and it is hard not to simply gaze in wonder at the beauty of the building.I felt it a real privilege to be able to access this madresa and hope that many more people will do so as well.
few days in Marrakesh. Impressive...pictures to follow, but well worth a visit. This was a 20 -30 minute walk from the Hotel Della Rosa
Beautiful building. Beautiful and historic building. It is possible to explore the old student rooms with their austerity offset by the carving and design in the main areas.
Exquisite Architecture. Ron told us that the inspiration for Hayati's magnificnet courtyard came from the Medersa. It is worth the few minutes walk from the taxi to see this structure.

Medersa excellent. For non-Muslim tourists to get glimpse of inside how people learnt Koran etc and study Islam this is one of the few places you can visit (with combined ticket with Musee de Marrakech next door). Excellent architecture and one or two rooms are furnished to give you idea on how people used to devote time studying Koran etc. Stunning architecture and camera friendly. Strongly recommended
Ali Ben Youssef Madrassa - school. When you go into the Madrassa, go up the stairs and to the left to see the staged rooms with artifacts

Simply beautiful. This place is a feast for the eyes, from the elaborate and intricate designs of the courtyard to the simple dormitory rooms where the students lived. Like most museums in Marrakech, it is short on signage compared to Western museums, and paying for a guide probably would have enhanced our visit...Though as usual in Marrakech, caveat emptor.
beautiful. Amazing architecture. Worth getting a guide to explain the details to you. Well worth a visit. Cost 60 dirham together with entry to the nearby museum.

if this is your first contact with moorish architecture style and decoration you'll be awed!. if this is your first contact with moorish architecture style and decoration you'll be awed! but even if you have been to Granada before, this is still a superb place and a unique opportunity to get to know how this extremely important (even today) religious schools were organised. Don't miss it,

Interesting!. This is a very nice building right in the heart of the medina!
Come here if you want to feel the spirit of the ancient Marrakech :)

Beautiful place to visit. This is really a good place to see and admire the gorgeous design and work. This was a Koranic school founded in the medieval era. Located above the souks, it displays all the decorative craftsmanship that Morocco has to offer and in superb fashion. Don't miss it
Beautifull place. Just take your camera and go! Buy a ticket for this place and the museum together, it will safe you about 60 dirhams and the museum is just one minute away from the Madrasa
We enjoyed the Ali Ben Youssef Medersa. Located in the heart of the Medina, this old school boasted gorgeous tile, plaster, and wood work. The tiny living quarters were rather fun to explore.

Average - ok to kill an afternoon (even if you're interested in art). The Ben Youssef Medersa may be the only example in Marrekesh of its kind, but not a good example on a world wide scale (for example if you've already been to Cordoba or Granada etc).

Discover Marrakech. We visited the Madrasa as part of our day long excursion, our guide was very good and gave us lots of historical information, without this it's difficult to appreciate the importance of Madrasa.
Beautiful. This is a truly wonderful and spiritual place to visit! Learn from this wonderful man about the culture and history of his art museum and visit his beautiful gardens.

You've not been to Marrakech unless you see this!. Truly impressive Koranik School, which is in a very good condition still. Like every other building in the Medina of Marrakech, it does not look like much from the outside, but once through the main door, you will be very pleasantly surprised. Take your time to visit!

One of the oldest Koran school in Marrakech. Impressive building well preserved. Beautiful tiles all around. Rooms for students rather small, some with window (only one) to the outside world, others with small window on the courtyard.
A bit of calm amidst the souks. Very beautiful courtyard and austere chambers, but a little overpriced compared to other Marrakesh attractions.
worth finding. very interesting - seems totally original- could have done with a little more info but good value. Might walk past it if not careful

Nice place. Nice place to visit. I thought the price to get in was a little too much, considering the lack of information once your inside. Yes, the building is beautiful, but I enjoyed it as much as I enjoyed the Palais Bahia, less expensive and as beautiful. But I still consider that the medersa is a must see in Marrakech.

Beautiful Surprise in the Medina. We were taken here by a guide, not really knowing what our day would entail. This is a beautiful compound in the heart of the Medina that was once a Koranic school. Every inch is carved and decorated and about as close as non-Muslims can come to enjoying the beauty of mosque architecture.

Best attraction of Marrakech!. This was absolutely the best place we have been to in Marrakech. It was the only attraction that was completely renovated and therefore stunning. We went to Ben Youssef on our last day, and I can truely say we saved the best for the last! I must say that the little rooms inside the palace (where the student lived) are a bit boring. Every room is the same and there are only +/- 3 rooms with furniture, and those rooms are not even fully decorated. If you go to Marrakech for only one day, make sure you visit this place!
Hidden away!. Eventually found this with the help of a local shop owner tucked away down a narrow alley way.Beautiful interior/main courtyard.
superbe. Great place to visit even if not interested in decor, location next to the souk area so very convenient
interesting. as a first glimps of marrakchi history, nice but a little run down. worth the trip though to better understand the coranic school and tradition.
Beautiful. Worth a visit for the wonderful architecture. Stunning rooms and tiling. The students quarters upstairs were interesting
Worth a visit. A small amount of rooms but some serious art and decoration, its not the Alhambra but worth a visit.

Very Interesting. The quality was a very nice surprise compared to the general tattiness. Great fun wandering through the medieval student cells around the main courtyard. Built by the same guys who put the Alcazar in Seville and the Alhambra in Granada. But the Spanish have taken more care of theirs.
Not to be missed. This review is for the school. Entrance price a bit up there, but still worth it. The carvings and the mosaics were fabulous.

Hard to find but well worth the visit - beautiful architecture. Difficult to find in the souk neighbourhood but well worth persevering. Bought a combined ticket for the Medersa and the Museum of Marrekech. The Medersa was beautiful, lots of religious study rooms overlooking the main courtyard. A good mock-up for two student rooms (one from the city and one from the country). Cedar wood carving and non-image mosaics. Excellent photo opportunities with the sun streaming through the minute quadrangles and on the main central fountain. Wished a tossed dirham into the water. Very tranquil and idyllic. Time to contemplate!If you want a coffee and sit down then the Museum of Marrakech is just 2 minutes away.

Stop in if you are passing.. Paid 60dhs for entrance to here and museum of Marrakech. Its been ticked off the list and the architecture inside the building is quite impressive. Stop by for a picture!!

Definitely a Must See. We were advised that if you've been to the Medersa in Fes you don't need to go here, but I completely disagree. This one was much better because while the decorations, shape and size are much the same as the one in Fes, this one is no longer used for religious purposes so it is much more open. You can walk upstairs to see the student's chambers, which is very interesting. It is so easy to find this place and with the combined ticket price for the Marrakesh Museum, there is definitely no reason to not check out the Medersa.
Amazing building and architecture. A bit challenging to find but well worth the visit. Much larger than we were expecting and a mere 10 dirhams to enter.

Beautiful examples of traditional Moroccan building. The tiles, stylised texts from the Koran, the carved cedar wood etc. are all beautiful. A must see if you can run to the £4 entry fee for here and the museum.
amazing place. get there early as photographs fab in early light especially the lake. Not easy to find as south of the old medina but worth the trek
Wow. Go for it if you are culturally interested. Worth every penny and no charge for photos - rare! Can't make up the characters needed.

Get there early. It opens at 9am and I would recommend getting there at 8:50, getting straight in and getting the photo with the reflection in the pool before the hordes of tourists arrive with their loud guides shattering the peace.
An interesting glimpse into the past. An interesting visit if you read up about just how many people lived and studied in these cramped quarters.

a Marrakech must-see. I have been to the madrasa twice now and it's my favourite Marrakech attraction. I love the architectural features: the tiled floors and walls; carved plaster ceilings; balconies and archways. Catch it between tours groups (or escape upstairs while they whizz around the courtyard) and it is also a peaceful haven away from the bustle of the medina. The Museum of Marrakech (almost next door) and the Maison de la Photographie (around the corner) are also very worthwhile. You can get a double ticket with the Museum which offers a reduction on buying two separate ones. For lunch nearby, try Le Jardin.
Very Interesting. The architecture is beautiful, well worth a visit. We spent about an hour in here. Its a great insight into a muslim school and how the students lived.
Nothing spectacular. . .. Didn't really see what all the fuss was about. Ok if you're passing but otherwise I wouldn't go out my way to visit.
Reminds me of school. Stunningly and intricately beautiful architecture. The myriad rooms are a medieval warren.Try to avoid the crowds.

Good for a half hour. Its fun to look around. And the architecture is beautiful. But we were not blown away. And the structure is very easy to figure out. So i do not see how people get lost in this place.

Beautiful and educational.... A lovely building with amazing carvings and a couple of rooms that give an idea of what it would have been like to study here. The only thing missing: pamphlets with a little more history and explanation!

Beautiful. This is a great place to get a sense of Moroccan design and architecture. Get a guide for the day though b/c they will be able to tell you more about why this school was started. The tile and architecture is amazing.
Beautiful. A must see. Beautiful Madrasa, completely renovated. very interesting to see all the students rooms and the courtyard is breathtaking.A must see.
Cultural must do. A fantastic building. Quite a labyrinth and therefore great for kids. Mine loved exploring this one.
Great. This is a beautiful building, with lovely ceilings and tiles. There were not many tourists and we had a good wander around.

Architectural Gem. We have visited Marrakech (and Essaouira) 7 times in the past 5 years, and apart from the Badi Palace, this is a definite 'worth a re-visit' place. The architecture is amazing, as is the wood and the carvings. To be able to move freely around the building, in and out of the Student's tiny rooms, and 'feel' and appreciate the solitude of it all, and touch the wood, is a real joy and a great photo opportunity. Travel back in time a few hundred years, and enjoy !
Well worth an hour of your time. Great for photographs and a little local, if historic, architecture. Also good to take the heat out of your day.

Study in Time. We went on this visit as part of a trip to the souks. Although a wet day this was a real highlight and to see the original work and materials there since the 15th centuary made you think about the work that had gone into the building as well as a differant way of life from modern universities.
Lovely building. This site is simple and beautiful, with restored tiles, woodwork, and plaster carvings. Definitely a gem in the heart of the Marrakech medina.

Outstanding example of Islamic architecture. Do yourself a favour and don't miss this place! The architecture is fabulous with the carving and wall calligraphy as good as anything I've seen before. Lots of nooks and crannies to explore and also a cool oasis on a hot day.

Calm in the chaos of Marrakech. It was a real delight to be able to see inside a Muslim historical monument. The decoration of the main communal areas was beautiful, the scholars spaces minimal to say the least, small rooms with tiny opening in many.

Beautifull. The Ali Ben Youssef Medersa is one of the few medersas (Islamic-colleges) that can be visited by non-muslims and therefore it's already a worthwhile visit. The traditional architecture is really beautifull.
Classical Moroccan Islamic school. Ancient islamic school with student dorms in quad like courtyard and teacher rooms reminescent of western universities.

Very nice place. Actually, it's not a school rather than a place where students used to live. A very old place which made me contemplate about studies at that period of time. If you can find you a guide, it's better. If not, try to read and gather as much information as you can. I like the visit and the decoration of the main square as long as the roof.

Ageless. This is an old university, still in perfect condition with with the teaching areas and bed rooms, interesting for a twin room with the seperate floor above. The old timbers and carvings are simply perfect, our entrance fee for here also included the former residence of the defence minister - another palacial building
Madrassa. Fascinating & beautiful but don't miss the magnificent Museum a few hundred metres away. Together they gave us a superb insight into Islamic architecture & a glimpse into another culture.
interesting building. we went around this building as part of a tour of the Souk / marrakech. it is a very interesting building and gives a good impression on what a madrasa is like
Peaceful, reflective place. Well restored, not very crowded, interesting architecture, peaceful location. Wonderful views from the upstairs rooms. Courtyard pool very relaxing.

Well worth a visit. If you are looking for cultural sightseeing in Marrakech, Ben Youssef Medersa is well worth a visit. The entrance fee is minimal (80p) and allows non-Muslims entrance to a previous place of worship. Probably only takes 45-1hr for a self-tour of the ground and student rooms upstairs, depending on how much you wish to take in. Stunning tile work and very insightful to see such a place.
Fascinating tour. Our guide brought the place to life. He took us though the upstairs rooms and explained how they housed the students and teachers in the not-so-distant past.

Beautiful - make sure you have enough time. It was a highlight of my first trip 10 years ago, and a highlight again this time. I was glad that I knew how much there is to see and that it's worth seeing it slowly, so we had enough time.
Top site to visit.... This site is simple and beautiful, with restored tiles, woodwork, and plaster carvings. Definitely a gem in the heart of the Marrakech medina.

Madrassa ( if you can find it!). Wonderfully restored and you can wander at will amongst the scholars rooms. Maybe some information in English would have helped us appreciate what it would have been like to be there as a student

Beautiful and fascinating. This is a really big madersa, and the decoration inside is spectacular. You can also go upstairs and see the student rooms, some around the main courtyard, but as it was home to many more students than would fit in just those rooms, there are several light wells with other rooms. It is very clear which rooms were for the better off, and two rooms are furnished so you can see what it would have been like for a well off student from the city, and a poorer student from the countryside
Exquisite Islamic Structure. Ron told us that he got much of the inspiration for Hayati's beautiful courtyard from this building. It really is quite exquisite and must be seen.
Beautiful. Since non-muslims cannot get into the mosques this is a rare opportunity to witness some splendid interior architecture
Nice. I liked the visit but we made the mistake of following one of the local guides there. It is not really necesary

2 other locations included with tickets. The ticket also included a museum next door and a riad that is used for art exhibits and other events. All were well worth the time. Great exhibits, art, culture, and history.
fantastic. we didn't have a guide, just walked through medina and found it right in the heart of it. was quite crowdy, but worth a visit, you can even climb stairs to see all the rooms.
The old school days. Some wonderful architecture to see, and something of an insight to days gone by... However, somewhat lacking on information and explanation. Door staff not too helpful.

Amazing detail. enjoyed seeing a view of life for students studying the Koran in historic times. Saw an insight from the preserved bedrooms, seemed like a very large maze with surprisingly small rooms for some students. Worth a visit if you enjoy history and culture

Best place to visit in Marrakech. Great architecture and mosaics here. This is worth seeing and I actually prefer this to places like Koutobia Mosque, Saadian Tombs and El-Bahia Palace. The courtyard is simply stunning. Probably the best monumental building in the whole of Marrakech

not enough comments. court yard paved in mosaic and with music is really great place to take a pause. I like it .
This place is not indicated at all from Souk, we need to ask help for the direction and trying to avoid to be miss leaded to a shop by the people who tried to show us the way.

Well preserved gem!. The madrasa is a must see in Marrakech. The architecture and beauty of the building is well preserved. If you want, there are guided tour guides in the madrasa who will provide you with information on the location

Amazing architecture. On my recent trip to Marrakech, this was my favorite building! I took some amazing photos and learned a lot about the school. It is just stunning - absolutely worth visiting. I liked it better than the Saadian tombs, it was just amazing.
history. amazing how people were studying before,state of the art architecture. the monument need to be taken care of by the responsables , it is getting depreciated. You absolutely need to visit.

Jinx. Archetecture of the time is preserved . In the medina, this is the first koranic schook in morocco. The first class included a woman. The center of the medrasa (or school) was where the imams spoke. In this pre-microphone era, the imam spoke from an small alcove to take advantage of the exho.
Wonderful architecture. The architecture of this former medrassa is stunning so it is well worth a visit, together with the next door museum.
Fascinating. Thoroughly enjoyed this fascinating place, full of history and an insight into life many years ago. Amazing zellige and plasterwork.

A must see. Definately under the heading of culture, but should be seen even if you don't generally 'do' culture to help understand Islam a little. And as non Muslim's can't enter the Mosques in Marrakech this is as close as you'll get. A guided tour is handy to explain what you are seeing, the carving of wood is unbelievable. This is a calm, tranquil experience to counter the hustle & bustle of most of Marrakech.
One of main attractions. Its quite an interesting place though like many of the sites in Marrakesh could benefit from better information and placards. Its still an amazing thing to see.
Stunning beauty. The beauty of the courtyard brought tears to my eyes - truly a special architectural achievement and a celebration of a perfectly designed space. Inspiring!

One day this will be well presented and it will be great. If you want to see Moroccan architecture at its finest, go. They need to do more to make it informative and interesting and I'm sure that will come in time.

Amazing to see such an old building so well preserved!. This is a must see - you don't get to walk around buildings like this that have such a great history and are so well preserved. It it only 20minutes out of your day and it is one of the highlights of Marrakech.
must see. amazing to hear the history of this school and be able to walk the grounds and see the actual rooms occupied by professors and students.

One of Marrakech highlights. A must see site. Nice too wander around and have a look through all corner and small rooms.
Easy to find at the corner of the Soukhs
Wonderful. We were taken here as part of our tour and found it very interesting and a great place to visit. The building is beautiful and walking round the upper floors was magical.

Most interesting & impressive architecturally building we visited. Marked contrast between the bare student rooms on the upper floors , and the stunning stucco plaster and carved woodwork in the main courtyard and lower rooms .We wandered round without a guide enjoying the tranquility of the surroundings .Pleased we made the effort to visit it. Entrance fee 60 dirhams combined ticket for this and the Marrakech museum which is just 40 yards away . Not that easy to find if you go through the souks to get to it ! Someone showed us the way but as usual wanted money for it .

Beautiful interiors. This former religious school turned tourist attraction delivers when it comes to beautiful carvings, tile, and architecture. It's also fun to get a bit lost in the student dorms and courtyards. Everyone is there with their expensive cameras trying to take the perfect photo in the gentle light that comes through the courtyard openings, but even your little pocket camera will capture some seemingly expert shots. No explainations in English unfortunately, but you'll still get the ambiance. Ticket of 60 Dh also includes the nearby museum which has also been restored with lovely interiors, with a few forced and awkward display cases.
Small but beautiful. Not a lot to see but the most beautiful site we visited in Marrakech, courtyard just lovely. Definitely worth it.

Interesting place, if we could just find our guide..... A beautiful place and well worth the visit when you're in Marrakech. Just make sure you get a good guide though, we took an offical guide but he dissapeared after about 5 minutes and left us to explore on our own. That was ok, but some other visitors were being shown around and given the detailed history of the place. Just insist on your moneys worth! The main thing you're looking at here is the architecture and detailing around the courtyard which is stunning and really takes your breath away. A total contrast then the student rooms on the upper floor which make our halls of residence look like palaces themselves!

A fine example of Moroccan architecture. Excellent, amazing mosaic and roof details, this is again walkable from the main square. It is best to buy a ticket for this and the Museum as it works out cheaper. Although the tickets to all the main buildings of interest are cheap anyway.

Not sure whether worth the time. Not too many interesting sights in Marrakech, but definitely liked the museum nearby much more. Given it's close to the soukes, it's probably worth to go. Just don't expect anything breathtaking.

Facinating insight. Visited as part of a Thomson tour of Marrakech and worth the time spent. The building radiates from a central courtyard made of mosaic tiles and the simplicity of the design and tranquility is abundant. It was previously a school of learning, an old university if you like and the number of student "bedrooms" was numerous all spralling over the first floor. You can visit as part of a package with the museum next door and its only about 60 dirams, about £4. A good example of Moroccan architecture from more than a century ago.

Absolutely fascinating. The real beauty of the Ali Ben Youssef Medersa is the silence and the distance from the bustle of the medina of Marrakech. the architecture is absolutely fascinating, it reflects the mixture of Islamic, Saharian and Berber creativity.

don't miss it. atmosphric and beautiful with plenty of variety if you look for it. The long pool in the courtyard cools the place nicely on a hot day and although there are no facilities as such the museum next door has a small cafe you can use without need of a ticket
Stunning Architectural Gem. Stunningly beautiful example of architecture. I spent an hour to two just contemplating the beauty of this religious icon.

Nice central courtyard. The main courtyard is very pleasant with some excellent carvings, tilework, and calligraphy. However, there is relatively little historical interpretation of what you are seeing, and the price is perhaps a bit inflated for what you are getting.

Spectacular design - photog's dream. Photos here are a must to add to your Marrakesh album. The colour, the details, the architecture, the craftsmanship, tile patterns, colour - all absolutely beautiful.
Worth a visit. Good value to get in, beautiful building, worth an hour of your time. You can combine visit with museum which is next door.
Best place to visit in Marrakech. Do not miss this fabulous school. It is the best monument in the city of Marrakech with its beautiful walls - celling and courtyards.
Well worth a visit. An excellent introduction to a North African Madrasa completed different from those in the Middle East

An Interesting Visit. If you're looking for a day immersed in the history of Marrakech, Morocco and Islam as a whole the Ali Ben Youssef Medersa should definitely be visited alongside the Museum of Marrakech and the Maison de la Photographie. Beware - in the area these attractions are located many tourist touts operate, some are not adverse to lying to get you to follow them and a common offering is a tour of the tanneries, which are a good 20-30 minutes walk from the centre of the Medina.Warnings aside, the Medersa has some great architecture and gives a relatively intact glimpse of what life would have been like studying, worshipping and living there. The mosaicked courtyard and sparse student rooms are probably the most impressive parts of the building.No tour guide is necessary.
Lovely!. Don't miss it. The architecture is amazing. It's a little hard to find, but worth it. There will be locals that misdirect you - my suggestion is women should ask women for directions
Very interesting history.. I thought it was well worth the visit. You get a real glimpse into what life was like for these young men and boys.
Not to be missed. One of the best examples of Islamic architecture and in my opinion one of the most beautiful buildings in the world.
A return to the Middle Age. This former Coranic school has a beautiful architecture. Perfect balance between intricate crafstmenship and absolute simplicity
magnificent. Exceptional example of ISlamic architecture, a haven of peace. The courtyard is majestic, with a pool very refreshing.
Beautiful koran school. Great tiling, wood carved ceilings, etc. Interesting to see the student's rooms. It's a nice peaceful place in the midst of the hectic medina

Hard to find. Stunning place but difficult to find (avoid the false guides-even the female 'students'). Even inside you are waylaid be people wanting to show you round. However, worth the walk there as the place is beautiful and you can get a sense of how it must have been when used as a theology school.

Wow!. My wife and I visited the Madrasa during our honeymoon in Marrakech. This is a truly amazing building. I have hundreds of pictures taken during our visit, and pretty much every one that shows my wife shows her staring open-mouthed at the beauty of the architecture, carving, tilework and decoration.If you like old buildings, architecture, carving, stonework, historic sites, religious buildings or just beautiful things generally, then come here!
Very beautiful building. Lots of culture and lots to learn about how people live. The building is very pretty. It costs 60 dirhams with joint entry to the museum which is also well worth a visit.

Family Visit. We did visit on a very hot day, and found the water to be of wopping 15 dirhams at the Madersa, but it was a lovely building. As with all sites in Marrakesh you wish they would put more information or artists impressions around the place so you have more of a clue what you are looking at.
Beautiful Relaxing Place. Like the Bahia Palace, this is a great place to chill out away from the hussle and bustle of the souks.

Medersa. We visited here as part of a trip we took part in and found it one of the best places we visited, pretty and interesting all in one. the rooms upstairs must be seen, and the history is interesting. as usual beautiful architecture, and a must see.

An interesting old building. Really nice Islamic architecture. Only 10dirhams to get in (about 1euro) and no hassle inside either. You can wander around at leisure and take photos. It would be nice if there was more information available about the building without hiring a guide's services.

magnificent monument. This feeds the spirit and the culture when accompanied by an explanation of knowledgbale local guide! A stunning beauty and rich history!
This magnificent monument is worth a visit both for the richness of its architecture and the history of this place.
Stunning. Amazing architecture - well worth a visit. An oasis of calm in the centre of the city. Purchase a ticket that includes the museum, too.

Beautiful. Vert interesting, beautiful and thoroughly worth the visit.
Also a very cool place to escape from midday heat!

Lovely architecture. As a keen armature photographer.. I loved this place for its beautiful colours, architecture, patterns and mosaics. Truly stunning to walk around and enjoy the beauty of this place. If you're not into these kind of things, avoid.. Personally, I loved the history and atmosphere of the place.
Beautiful. Beautiful decorations in a building that was initially a mosque before becoming a school. Pay 60 dirhams for entry into both the school and the museum of Marrakech
Favorite building in Marrakech. Beautifully harmonious building, spectacularly decorated. This was our favorite building in Marrakech.

largest Medrasa in all of Morocco.. The Ben Youssef Madrasa was an Islamic college in Marrakech, Morocco, named after the Almoravid sultan Ali ibn Yusuf (reigned 1106–1142), who expanded the city and its influence considerably. It is the largest Medrasa in all of Morocco.
Really fascinating. Our guide took us here, an Islamic school of which he was very proud. We really enjoyed the trip around

Dazzling Decor. This Koranic School is just breathaking.
The workmanship whether it's the tiles or carving is so intricate it takes your breath away. Only 40 Dirhams entry or 60 if you combine a visit to the Museum next door. Not too difficult to find in the Medina
Must go. It is a place that is a very important part of their culture, actually is is a nice start-up, but a guide is highly recommended
mosque. cannot go in to this building if non muslim but what a building large over powering and seen from a distance is still good..great photo opportunity with this one
This is a must. Take a look at the small rooms, imagine how is must be to study here about the Coran etc. Go early in the morning before it get crowded.
Madrasa. not particularly interesting - tour guide speaking English which was not a comfortable language for him - but info very repecetitve
Worth a trip. The site itself is beautiful and we got some amazing pictures. A guide talked us through the history of the building and the architecture. Definitely worth a visit!

Beauty and inspiring tile work. Again, go with a guide! Guidebooks are great for sitting and dreaming of your trip, but while you are there, you need to see and have things pointed out that you would surely miss. Beautiful site, do not miss it.

Interesting. This was an interesting place to visit, though all the information boards were in french so we perhaps didn't get as much from our visit as we could have done. It took us a while to find but was well worth the effort!
Exquisite Courtyard. The uislamic design of this ancient building is something to be seen.

Interesting old boarding school. Very nice architecture
One can imagine all the students cramped up in small rooms in previous centuries
Amazing!. Go with a guide - you'll learn a lot! It's an amazing building with a rich history.
Fasinating. Beautiful tiles and carvings. Probably the most famous and important sites in Marrakesh.
not to be missed. This is the most beautifu monument of Marrakech. Take the combo ticket wich also icludes the Marrakech museum.

Marrakech artistry. There's so much that's stunning to look at; whether you look up or down. See where students used to live and compare the rural one's belongings with those of the urban student. Even though there were lots of visitors when we went, it was a restful place to be.

Get a tour guide to get the full story. Beautiful architecture, get a tour guide from your hotel which is not expensive so you can get the full story or what you are seeing, a must do while you are at Marrakech
Nice but should be renovated. Why doesn't they ask for more money, they could renovate it.
interesting cultural tour. Very evocative of discipline and education in the past

Stunning Architecture. This is one of the proper attractions in Marrakech but don't go in expecting a museum with everything labelled. It's an amazing piece of architecture that is well worth a visit. We saw it after visiting the marrakech museum ( be careful there are 2 marrakech museums) and there was an offer if you bought tickets for both the museum and the medersa next door. It wasn't the easiest place to find but then not much is here!

Breath-takingly stunning.. This building is a stunning example of the local architecture. The level of detail in the design is nothing short of mind-blowing. Note as you look around that there are no images of people or animals, as they are not permitted to be drawn or recreated in artwork here. Everything is geometric shapes, and it is just beautiful! You must go here, do not miss it!
Top site. Beautiful building inside. Great craftsmanship. Well worth a guide to explain the history

Best of the best. Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa is a must see. It is one of the largest and has been greatly maintained. The tile and clay work is in an excellent condition and shows the best of Marrakech architecture. Marrakech otherwise does not have a lot to see in my opinion and in terms of culture and history this building was worth the visit. We found finding things in Marrakech quite difficult so a map is a must and constantly asking for directions is a good idea.
Laced ornaments and pool in courtyard. Fantastic work of Islamic art! Laced ornaments and pool in courtyard was wonderful. Even on middle of day is not hot there and all you can see is like a dream.

It was ok, but not a must see!!. This is an old koranic school which does have some amazing architecture. We found it quite hard to fine, its down a dark corridor which opens into a very pretty courtyard with a pool in the center. inside you can walk up two staircases which take you into the very small living spaces of the students that used to go to the school. One downside is that all the information is in french, it was also quite expensive for what it was, but overall im pleased we went.
A very interesting place. A great place to visit & has a beautful pool in the courtyard.
N° 1 Marrakech Medina. Marrakech Museum, Koubha and Médersa on the same place for 5 pounds !!! we had a nice guide who explained us a lot of things about history.

A must-see in Marrakesh. Beautiful place to see and take pictures of. Just wish there was more to see in it or a little more explanation about what it was, what the rooms were for and more info on the architecture and materials used.
fasinating. beautiful well worth a visit. found in the medina it is just off the main souks next to the marrakech museum

Must see. We visited here with our tour guide and would definitely recommend arranging a guided tour as the place really came to life as we were shown around and had little details explained to us. The Madrasa is in a good condition and makes for a lovely visit even in the heat of the day. Would most definitely recommend anyone of all ages to visit here.
Interesting and educational. We took a guided tour of the Medersa in May and found it interesting and educational. If you are there, do it. But not worth a second visit.
Worth Seeing. Built in the 16th century, this site has loads of historic interest. Price is only $2 (USD). And great photo opp. But read up before you go-few historic plaques or explanations.
Real design and attractive work. Stunning School, fascinating work and beautiful designs. Medrassa ben yousef is the best monuments and historical sites to be visited in Marrakech.
fascinating Madrasa. Appreciated the history, architecture and ambiance. Would have appreciated the opportunity of a short tour or more explanation and signage.
must have seen in marrakech. one of the most beautiful buildings i've ever seen!
getting to the place. You must get a giude to take you because it is in the middle of the souk and is very easy to get lost the place is great
Lovely Architecture. Worth a visit if you can find it! Very beautiful decor!
Beautiful courtyard here. It was interesting to see the cell-like rooms occupied by the students

A step back in time. Only a small entrance fee - the architectural structure and decorative elements are lovely. A step back in time! The student rooms provide an amazing window into their educational history. We were fortunate to have an excellent guide with interesting stories and anecdotes about the building and school.
Beautiful building. Worth a trip as very cheap and lovely to archatecture
Don't miss this!. One of the best examples of Moroccan architecture standing. Beautiful and impressive.
Wonderful. Loved seeing how students studied so many years ago, and the architecture is beautiful.

Interesting. This is a spectacular building with amazing architecture but there has not been a great deal of effort to bring the place to life or recreate the feeling of life in the place - lots of empty rooms. Well worth a visit but don't expect a dramatic experience!

"The place" to visit in Marrakesh. Beautifull place.. "The place" to visit in Marrakesh. Beautiful place. Gorgeous architecture and idea of the decoration and conditions of the students at that time. Shown of splendor of Morocco back in history.
Beautiful Historic. Great Tile work, fantastic Medersa in the Medina. Great historical site.
When going for culture a much go. As the largest medrasa in Northern Africa a must go if you are interested in muslim culture

Beautiful building. Worth getting the combined ticket for this and the Marrakech museum. Both really beautiful buildings. I recommend going at the beginning of the day before they get filled with tourists as it is a much more pleasant experience!
fascinating. A real insight into the cuture and history of Marrakech
Beautiful architecture. Bought a two-part ticket for this and the Museum, both are worth a visit.

Best attraction in Marrakech. We were mis-led twice in getting to this place- definitely only trust the shopkeepers and not the people on the street! It was worth the effort in getting there, though- a lovely courtyard and lots of little rooms to explore.
This is a must. We thought Ali Ben Youssef Medersa was beautiful. The architecture and craftsmanship is amazing and it's obviously hugely culturally and historically important.
interesting historical site. A rare glimpse into a madrassa, or Koranic school.
For a carpet of pattern, colour and architecture. Amazing work and when you hear the history - a must visit!
Cannot be missed!. Architecture - this was truly beautiful, just be careful with people showing you around, say "La Shukran!"
Beautiful. Really this is a beautiful building but there is not a great deal to see. Worth it for the photo opportunities, the architecture is breath taking.
Interesting but .... We were handicapted by having a surly and not well informd guide
Beautiful. The most beautiful islamic architecture and decoration I have ever seen. The high light of our trip.

Worth a visit. I thought that this place was ok!It is an ongoing process, I think, in terms of the renovations, but there is definitely a sense of the history and grandeur of the place just from walking around what is available right now. Probably not somewhere to spend a lot of time in, but worth a look and only a couple of pounds to enter. I may be slightly biased though - as any time I was actually in somewhere, rather than fighting my way through the ridiculous streets of Marrakech was fundamentally a happy time for me!I have just noticed that I have to say whether there were toilet facilities at the museum as part of the review - yes there were, but of course, as in nearly all places in Marrakech, there was also a toilet 'attendant' who would want money from you for using them.

Interesting place to wonder. Architecture is impressive so nice for some photo opportunities. Once inside we were greeted by a guide who just went straight into his tour pitch so after 5 minutes of talking felt obliged to keep him,A friendly man who spoke limited English but you could make out the basics to get the jist of what you are exploring! He wanted 50dh for his 20 minute tour which seemed fairly reasonable.Worth a visit I think to see some history and walk in the cool. Can be hard to find though but the kids outside let you know when you have arrived here!

Student accommodation, medieval style. Little or no interpretation or highlights but an intersting insight into the life of Islamic students and the architecture of functional buildings of the period. Interesting but not exciting
Medersa. Very interesting and well worth a visit. Good photo opportunities. We spent several hours there
Fantastic architecture. A great introduction to fabulous Moroccan tiles, carving,and overall style. Be sure to go upstairs for a view of the courtyard from above.

amazing architecture. Go inside and visit the place, buy a combi-ticket for the Musée de Marrakech and the Medersa. Our visit was part of a guided tour, our guide explained a lot about the history and architecture.

Beautiful building. Doesnt take long to see. We were unfortunately nabbed by a 'guide' who tried to tell us about the building but didnt speak English, ended up paying for a 3min tour we couldn't understand!

Interesting Islamic school. Is well worth the time to visit this as the architecture in the courtyard is amazing. The rooms are so tiny, it gives a real sense of what a medersa was like for the students who attended. There are guides available outside and there is a small entrance fee but you are allowed to take photos.

dont miss this.... the architecture of this beautiful old madras is stunning. you could look at it all day. there's such a serenity here. its a very busy tourist spot. so you have to be patient if you're taking photos for people to move on. not to be missed...
Beautiful historical site. highly recommend. get ready to take lots of photos. There could be more signage and explanation but that is typical of all of Marakesh.

Real work to admire. To enjoy and admire the Morrish work. You need to visit Ali Ben Youssef Mederasa which is the real sample of the beautiful hand made work on the basis of carved cedar - the intricate plaster work and the gorgeous Marble.
Don't miss this place in Marrakech it is a real experience.
intresting. Beautiful place to see how it was as kid to visit school. The differents between poor and rich. Mozaik wall's nice place

Our best attraction in Marrakech.. We spent about an hour or so in the Ali Ben Youssef Medersa, a centuries-old Koranic school, located in the old part of the medina. Beautiful tile mosaics, carved plaster, Moorish architecture. Very interesting to see a couple of the rooms set up still as if there was a student from the countryside and one from the city inhabiting them.
Enigma. Really interesting if you like history and culture
beautiful tiles but otherwise. Sort of like an abandoned school anywhere except for a few very cool pictures, normally crawling with tourists who want the same pictures.
Best site in Marrakech. Most interesting site in Marrakech, this old religious school is well worth a visit.
Beautiful mosaic decoration. Beautiful old building with ornate mosaics and a string of tiny rooms where youngsters apoparently spent time studying the Koran. well worth a visit.
A must see !. Best Islamic architecture in Marrakech. Beautiful place

A place of learning and of beauty!. The medersas in Marrakech and Fez represent some of the very best of Moroccan architecture and offer an insight into the religious schools of former times. This is a great example.

An almost must-visit place. The madrasah in Fes allows you only a visit of the courtyard as it is still.functional. This one you can roam freely in the courtyard and the dorm pn the upprt floor. It is interesting to see the tiny rooms set in a maze-like dorm. There are two rooms with display of the artefacts used by the students. Guess which belonged to an Arab student and which, a Berber. The carvings on the walls are beautiful, but the mosaic tiles are less refined than the ones in Fes.
Have to see. Amazing beautiful architecture. A very soecial space

Absolutely beautiful. The former Quran school is beautiful. We went to see the small rooms where the scholars slept first, then we came across one with a view of the courtyard and the view almost took my breath away. It is stunningly beautiful, with mosaic and carvings. The former prayer hall is also amazing. A must-see.
excellent !!!. small museum but it is forth to see. it is quite hard to find that place- we got lost in the medina.

Do not miss this. This was a special insight into the religious life. The building is very ornate and even full of tourists there is an interesting and different atmosphere.You can see the little bedrooms where the boys lived.
one of the only medersa one can visit. This medersa (school) is completely open, so that one can visit the little rooms where the students lived. Very lovely.
So ornate - great photo opportunities. don't miss this whilst in Marrakech. do take time to explore the maze of little bedrooms - amazing how many differences each one has.

Very pretty, interesting. Visited the medersa on the last day in Marrakech because it was low on our list of things to do. It was better than we expected, very pretty and interesting and definitely worth a visit.
Wonderful. Really beautiful and awe inspiring. Bring your sun hat.
liked it. Worth a visit although it will be a short one. It is a stunning building with beautiful carvings and a serene atmosphere
Closed early. We missed seeing this site because it closed at 6pm although our guide map said it would be open till 7pm in April. Very hard to find, we did a complete tour of the Souks to get there !

Not as good as expected. Unlike many places where we went was all bare rooms, there were some lovely ceilings all original and in good condition but again the rooms lacked character as there was no historical furniture in them

Best medersa to view interior spaces. While other medersas may be as pretty or better restored, this one offers you the advantage of being able to visit the students' rooms and really get a great idea of the spatial arrangement of living there. two rooms are even decorated as originally. The kids/teens will love this one - clambering through all the rooms, shrieking with delight at the mezzanines and stone steps, etc.

A Must See !!. I recommend getting the combo ticket for the madrasa , the museum and the tomb nearby . Exquisitely handcrafted . Make sure to ask for directions in your hotel or riad . Luckily for me , a merchant was kind enough to redirect me to the right way to the school !!

A Must Visit. A beautiful example of Moroccan architecture, especially the inner courtyard. Also dont miss the labyrinth of corridors and bedrooms of the building itself, and take some photos of the courtyard out of the bedroom windows

amazing building wonderful details. interesting court yard with nicely detailed interior facades. around the courtyard there are corridors that lead to the students rooms. these are located around smaller courtyards. an architectural masterpiece that is definitely a must in marrakech
Ali Ben Youssef. This is a 15th century Koranic School. Worth a visit. The pupils lived in very humble accommodations.
Nice. Would recommend going as the inner courtyard is beautiful, can easily see the whole building within a half hour
Place with incredible scholar atmosphere. Architecture: every room is around the main claustro; detailed decoration; silence.
Great medersa. Second time I visited the Medresa, and I still found new things to see. Beautifully done. Just perfect.

small cousin of the Alhambra. Beautiful tiled courtyard and hundreds of tiny bare rooms that kids can explore whilst the adults take arty photos! Don't forget to visit the toilets as the room they are in is also stunning!
Cultural experience. A beautiful cortyard and I also liked all the detailed artwork on the doors

Good example of a Madrasa. Average may be a little harsh. If you want to see an example of a Madrasa then this is as good as any; Beatiful architecture, fine examples of craftsmanship.ButGuaranteed to be busy (feels like this is a stop off for the coach tours) and there is very little variety once inside. (This may, of course, be down to my lack of appreciation.)For 10 Dirhams you may aswell go have a look, but don't expect it to make a holiday highlights package!
Impressive history. History is unrivalled, woodwork is impressive, echos of Elhambra
Wow. Just beautiful and full of amazing history. Helps to have a tour guide to explain the details.

Beautiful Madrasa, open to the public. This is a gorgeous site with ornate tile-work and wood working. It is not big and is easy to take in amongst the shopping excursions of the medina, and was also engaging to my children who enjoyed a rare bit of freedom there running in and out of the archways-

Delightful architecture beautifully restored!. An unexpected insight into the conditions (somewhat cramped) of the 900 students who occupied this theological college from the 14th century. We loved the ornately carved facades in the courtyard.

A Stunning Example of Moroccan Architecture and History - Don't Miss It. This is a gorgeous place, an architectural wonder, and one of the best example of zellij tilework and wood carving that we say in Morocco. It was interesting walking through the medersa cells surrounding the stunning open courtyard. There were plenty of tourists there, but still the place evoked a sense of wonder, serenity, awe, and respect.
great for anyone intersted in design or history. Get your camera at the ready - you won't be disappointed

Historic and beautiful on the inside. This Quranic school was in use between the 12 century and 1960. It is a great view of how students lived when coming to study over centuries. The inside courtyard and prayer area are beautiful with detailed plaster and wood work.
Amazing architecture. Nothing to dislike. Just an amazing building to see where students lived and studied. Definitely worth a stop!
historic school. Interesting architechture. opportunity to walk throughout
Beautiful. If you are pressed for time and have to choose one monument in Marrakech, this is it. I could have spent hours just admiring the tiles and woodwork. Wow.

Worth a visit. Certainly worth a visit although not that easy to find. It is good to walk around and see how the students lived back then. We went late morning in late March and it wasn't too busy to be annoying plenty of room.

Interesting.. My partner and I visited in January 2011. We had a guide who brought us here and we were so glad that he did. The building itself is really beautiful and provided us with an informative afternoon.
very beautiful. Location was very hard to find, but well worth a visit. Very beautiful colour, tiling and architecture.

A fascinating insight. If you are lucky enough to avoid the coach tour arrival you can have the place to yourself the better to imagine the life of the scholars in their small rooms far from home.
The tiles and carving are superb.
It is worth paying the extra 10 dh to gain entry to the museum and kuuba.
unexpected. a breathtaking buiding, gave a good insight into the history of the city
Amazing Building. If you are at all interested in architecture and historical sites this is a must. The only down side is that all the signs are in either Arabic or French.

The best medersa to see in all Morocco. This gem of a Koranic school in the heart of the Marrakech medina is a little hard to find. You might have to pay a kid 5-10 Dh to take you there. But it is magnificent. It's a signature piece of Moroccan architecture. The colourful tile work, intricate plaster carvings and amazing cedar woodwork are the epitome of Morocan craftsmanship. We viewed 2 other great medersas in Fes, but this one beats the other 2 in beauty and wow factor. Also this one has access to the second floor where the students used to live. You don't need a guide to take you there or show you around. A sight NOT to be missed in Marrakech. A+++
super. a great place to visit & imagine what it must have been like for the little boys who studied & lived here

Beautiful building - some lovely colours!. The tiling around the courtyards was really lovely - some great colours. Despite the number of people around, there was plenty to see without feeling unduly crowded. Only 2 of the students' rooms are furnished, which is a bit of a pity, but you just need to use your imagination a bit more! Well worth the visit.
Outstanding couple of hours of history course !. Outstanding couple of hours of history course ! a guided tour of this old university dated for hundreds and hundreds years . Not to miss !
World cultural heritage site.. Islamic history and North African architecture at its best.

Beautiful building. The courtyard was beautiful and it was interesting to look at the small rooms on the first floor where the students studied. Some rooms looked out onto the courtyard, while the others didn't have an outlook at all. I wondered how they selected the students to have the better rooms.
Nice. Well worth a look, fantastic central courtyard with great mosaics.
Must be Seen. Worth the little walk from the taxi drop off poin. It really is quite magnificent.

Must see if only for the supberb Islamic artwork. A little difficult to find but well worth it. Read the guidebooks for the full description but if you have any interest in Islamic architectute and decoration then this is a must. Supberb,
fantastic. 15TH cen Koran school,you still feel the peace in the space and it is so beautiful !
So interesting. A great place to visit and cool down from the souk madness

Amazing carvings. Stunning surroundings, would not recommend the guides though - they tend to say the same things over and over again and ours although offering a guide and haggling in perfect English then seemed to lose his English and spoke mainly in French!
Medersa Ali Ben Youssef : getting a feel of things then. Beautiful architecture, real plunge back in the scholarly days of the Medersa.
Great space, but more information would be welcomed. It's a must see from Marrakech, but as many other buildings in the city, there are not many explanations

Place of Interest. Very well preserved building, lovely decor and architecture - definitely something to see. As with a lot of Moroccan sights, they haven't started really making the most of their treasures (in my opinion) but in someways the simplicity is better than the commercialism you tend to get elsewhere

Fascinating and beautiful. Definitely a must if you are in Marrakech. An old Islamic school, still in wonderful condition. The central courtyard pool is interesting, with it's optical illusion of going downhill from either end!

Amazing!. Interesting to see how students lived and beautiful building. People met on the way said it was closed and showed us fake closed door, it was actually open! Great value with combo ticket for museum.

Beautiful building well worth a visit. This is reached by walking through the souks from Jamaa El Fna square, the walk was a very pleasant revelation as the souks open out and become more Moroccan than touristy, head for the market of vegetables, you will pass a couple of small butchers stalls but nothing to distress on view. There are a couple of well patronised cafes offering well priced lunches on the way. The Medersa is a beautifully and tastefully restored school for the teaching of the Muslim faith. The intricate detail on the walls and around the doors is delicious and quite unlike any other form of architectural detail I have seen before. Its fascinating to see the rooms that where occupied by the scholars. The pool in the centre of the courtyard is very inviting on a hot day. For 10 MADs more you can visit Koubba El Badiyan which is opposite Musee de Marrakech (also included) The ticket is valid for one day. The Musee has a small cafe, and although the exhibits are not all that amazing the building itself is a restored palace and has some spectacular rooms. These are certainly well worth a visit. We did continue to find the fountain which is listed as a Unesco world heritage site, which makes it sound a lot grander than it is, it is simply a water tap in a coloured wall with a carved wood ceiling, to my mind its not worth the trrek.
Beautiful details!. The building itself is great, and there are so beautiful and delicate details to watch.
beautiful interior. A lovely example of the best of local architecture.
THE place to visit. beautiful old very well maintened buiding, exquisite in its simplicity; its the nicest building we have in marrakech and its worth an hour visit;
must see in Marrakesh. Very pretty and filigreed architecture. It's huge and beautiful. They stopped using as a school to preserve it. Great tile, wood and plaster work.
A must. A beautiful site to visit, as well as the nearby Museum of Marrakech. Among the most important cultural sites in the city. Not to miss!
Beautiful spot. Such superb quality carving and tiling, and a calm space with frendly staff after the busy souks.

Stunning Moroccan Architecture. A great visit, finding your way through the study rooms surrounded by breathtaking, intricate architecture. Wonderful for photographic opportunities although it is very limited for any information regarding the everyday living within the medersa.

A must. The Medersa is a must for everybody visiting Marrakech. The fee is rather high (60Dh for a combi ticket with the Marrakech Museum), but it's worth it. Try to visit this attraction in the early hours, before the groups arrive.

Oasis in Marrakech. A well restored, attractive Medersa from the 16th Century. Quite an attractive shortish visit option. Wonderful decoration. A bit of interpretative material but not much. A good place to escape the crowds and hassle of the Medina for half an hour!
Worth a visit. This old Madrasa has been well preserved and is worth a visit when you're in Marrakech.

Must see. It was very beautiful: here you see how much attention they have for detail and how important it was to know the religion.
