Disliked the entrance price (when you compare with other attractions)
a quick visit. Beautiful architecture but not enough information on its history.

beautiful place. the medersa was a school for studying Islamic religion. It is beautifully decorated, although most of the rooms are now empty. All signs are in french. Recommend paying a little extra and visit both the medersa and the museum of Marrakech (right next door)

Gorgeous worksmanship. One of the most beautiful sites in Marrakech, incredible plasterwork, gorgeous symmetry and a rare glimpse inside a koranic school. Only drawback is the location as it is fairly hard to get to for the uninitiated, situated as it is in the warren of alleys at the northern end of the souks.

Definitely worth a visit. The Madrassa let's see 'behind the scenes' and both view the buildings of an Islamic school (no longer in use) and also get the 'feel' of the place. It is amazing and well worth a visit - just north of the souks.
interesting place. Interesting visit to the old Islamic school, very well preserved building, beautiful design.
Hmmmmmm. Got very lost trying to find this place....and when we did find it eventually there wasn't really any info about the place - a lack of leaflets!
Worth the little walk. It's a magnificent building that really illustrates the beauty of olf Morocco.
beautifull. Beautifull place, be aware for boys that want to guide you!
Beautiful building. I loved the atmosphere in this lovely building. The decorative work is beautiful.
Poor. The building is on a reasonable state but it lacked authentic furniture...

beautiful and peaceful building. This is just an empty building but the intricate arabesque carvings are beautiful and it is interesting to see how the students live in a quoranic school. I would like to see some artefacts or explanation of how these schools are when they are in use, especially as all we hear in the western media about madrasas seems to be negative and I know that most madrasa's are not about extreme views
Worth a visit. great architecture and history gives a real feel of what life was like going back in time.
Stunning. Beautiful architecture, fine craftsmanship, great photo opps!
Ooh, the wings of history!. This is an excellent place to see what ancient Marrakech was like for students. Easy to find and an absolutely beautiful example of muslim decor!
ben youseff. Eventually found it and glad we visited as its truelly beautifull and peacefull
Medersa. Fantastic stone carvings. Insight into the life of students. Beautiful architecture
Beautiful!. Amazing, intricate decoration and architecture. We spent a relaxing morning in this tranquil site in the heart of the Medina.

Culture Fix. The Medersa is well worth a visit, a fascinating insight into the culture of religious education and stunning Islamic design and decoration. You can buy a triple card from the Marrakech Museum nearby to see the Medersa, the fountain and the Marrakech museum, good value.

An atmosphere of studious tranquility!. One afternoon, we decided to do the three attractions - the Musee de Marrakech, the Almoravid Koubba and the Ben Youssef Medersa - which of course can be paid for on one ticket.The Medersa was the third place we visited. It may have been our favorite of the three buildings. The beautifully ornate courtyard, the small square courtyards, the students rooms with the ornate doorways and the lovely little windows that looked onto the large central courtyard. All quite intriguing, very memorable.
Average. It's still under renovation, but it deserves a visit
Good day. Good day, looked at the historic sites. Enjoyed it.

didn't meet the expectations. None of the palaces or other buildings of Marrakech have overwhelmed us. The Jemaa el Fna, the souks and the overall atmosphere of the city are unique and terrific, but the buildings (open to the public) aren't impressive at all to be honest.
Spectacular. This is the most beautiful medersa in the city and well worth a visit.

Not to be missed......... Do not be put off by the experience of the museum, this is the place to go in fact and to spend time looking at the detail in the artwork and design. A wonderful find and a very good introduction to the proud history of this city.
beautiful architecture and decoration. peaceful place with stunning decorative plaster on the walls. just at the entrance to the souks and nearby museum of marrakech. well worth a visit

Little Oasis in the Medina. If you are interested in Islamice Culture have a stop by, a nice and peaceful older Koran school where you can just relax and sip on a nice mint tea. Be aware that a non islamic person maybe restricted in entering some places and is not permitted to take any photos. But here you can go and ask. Not open every day, so check before going.
Very ornaite. Worth visiting, only takes an hour to get around so plan other places to see in the area

Take your kids to see what school was like!. This old school building is done up from floorboards to roof tiles in spectacular tilework, plaster, and calligraphy, all of it meant to glorify God. Up in the dormitories, though, you still can clearly see how many of the students lived in cramped dark corners on their "down time!" The place is wonderfully preserved. If time allows, see it with a guide the first time so you don´t miss the stories, but go back on your own late in the day to soak up the quiet beauty and enjoy the symmetry of the place without 600 other visitors jostling you.
Unmissible. Your visit will not br complete without seeing this ancient learning centre

Fantastic attention to detail in decorations. You can get 3 entries for the price of 60 DH - Madrasa, Marrakesch Museum and one other place nearby - a ruin site. It's worth paying a visit as the structure is magnificent.
A must see. Truly fantastic. THe courtyard is a work of art with carved plasterwork and cedarwood. The school housed 900 student in 100 (small) rooms. Very tranquil.
Learning experience. We learned a lot of arabic and especially morrocan history by our fabulous guide Ahmed . this was the first school in Morocco and definately some interesting stories to know.
Don't miss this. An oasis of learning and calm in the crazy Medina - now a museum. Beautiful Islamic arches, marble halls, go upstairs to see wood-carved student rooms.
Difficult to find, but worth a visit. The visit is interesting, it doesnt need a lot of time and gives you an idea of how the students lived and the decor of the time.
Fascinating. Particularly liked the 2 rooms set up for a student from a city and another for a student from a rural area
must see. fantastic traditional steep in the past just make sure a coach party doesnt turn up at the same time as this will spoil the experiance

Worth a visit. This medrasa is worth a visit, it was quite difficult for us to find it and it was in the middle of the medina. It was good fun going there as we found a few nice shops along the way that we ended up buying some soveniers from. You will need to spend around 1 hour at this place, it is very peaceful inside and there are some great photo opportunities there.

Worth to visit !!. Absolutely a must-visit cultural attraction in Marrakech ! The only problem is the lack of full explanations insite the Madrasa, just partial and only in arabic and french. Better ask for a guided tour at the reception.Cheap tiket to get inside. No student discount.
goog architecture. It's a must see with little rooms and big yard but unfortunately there is nothing inside just walls.

For non-muslims, this is the best access to muslim culture. You get access to the school where muslim clerics once studied. Since all mosques and other muslim cultural sites are off limits to non-muslims, this was the best access available to Europeans.
Coranic school. Nice example of architecture. Very well preserved. It's a must-to-have.

sorprendente. molto bella e grande scuola coranica che poteva accogliere circa 900 studenti.Molto suggestivo il cortile decorato con piastrelle colorate,intagli su stucco e intagli su legno di cedro e bisogna assolutamente visitare anche l'attiguo museo Dar Si Said

A Must-See in Marrakech. This is a tremendous building, and gives you the opportunity to take a close-up look at the amazing architecture and design that is prevalent in Marrakech. Meandering through the halls and into the small rooms was really a lot of fun. Definitely not to miss.

very beautiful. it's amazing what men can do. observing the carved wood and stones make you wonder that god does exist and has led the hands of the artists who made such beautiful things. worth going!

A step back to 14th century Islamic teaching. This 14th century Islamic school is well worth a visit, grand courtyard surrounded by small windows of carved oak rich tiling, small rooms used by students up until early 1960s
Stunning architecture. I was just spell bound by the beauty of the architecture. Worth a visit.

Very nice architecture, take you back in time.. This medrassa is in the middle of the Old Medina area, it can be quite tricky to find but if you get lost, just ask one of the shop keepers where it is and they will give you the directions without "attaching" themselves onto you (like some of the locals may do, then ask for money at the end).This is a great building to visit, the architecture takes you back in time, the building use to be a school and walking around the many rooms you get a feel of how things use to be. There are lots of nice photo opportunities at this place, go just after midday and the sun will be shining at you will get the best photos. We would recommend a visit to Ali Ben Youssef Medrassa.

Highlight of Marrakech. An exquisite building - the most beautiful we saw in Morocco - some relief from the extraordinary ornament in the others that covers the walls from top to toe - here beautiful chalk coral or buff plaster walls give some breathing room for the mosaic, wood, and carved plaster ornament. Also, a chance to see and learn how students of all classes (rural and urban) lived and studied as their quarters on the upper level are open for viewing.
One of the highlights of Marrakech...must see!. I love the beautiful architecture and seeing the students' rooms. It made me imagine a different time.
Beautiful designs. Traditional Moroccan art, a lot of history, well-kept. Very, very interesting - well worth a visit!

Hard to find, but worth the search. We enjoyed visiting the Madrasa very much - the inside was gorgeous, and it was interesting to see a school of that design. We had quite a bit of trouble actually finding the place, but it was worth it when we finally arrived.
Lovely tilework. Visiting off peak in December, we had the Madressa to ourselve at one point. Entrance fee is 30/40dhm, well recommended to visit this place.

Beautiful building. took us a while to find it (the medina is a confusing place) but well worth it once we did - beautiful example of islamic architecture, unrushed (we didn't take a guide) and pretty good value - about £4.50 per person. We took a tonne of photos each!

Beautifully details and total suprise for a school.. The ground floor is beautiful with lots of details and colour. Upstairs really gives you an idea of what it would have been like as a student hundreds of years ago in the cramped rooms.A scholar shows you around in a group for about 20 mins, after which you can wander at will. Some had their one to one guide and one american was having a heated discussion about religion. If you have any questions about islam this is probablly the best place to ask.
The Coran School for Boys!. This is a must see in Marrakech to have an idea of the architecture of the arabs. The building is quite impressive from the inside. The courtyard is breath taking!
very special. It is just amazing to see something like that. I can recommend for everybody who is travelling to Marrakech.
Wothwhile experinece. Quite difficult to find but well worth the search. Decoration is spectacular
sublime!. Such a beautiful building - stunning architecture, mosaics and woodwork; and a thought-provoking glimpse into a very different lifestyle. The joint ticket withe the Musée is great value.
worth a visit. simple, beautiful ceramic, a important historical building!

Stunning. Gives a marvellous little insight into how the students lived but hard to imagine 900 there!
Beautiful - a privilege to be able to enter this site.
best attraction in Marrakech. amazing , beautiful building. Worth the visit and payment of entrance. Beautiful palce decorated to the smallest detail

Walk around and 'feel' a part of history. A lovely place to relax, take pictures and really try to remember the old days when this was actually being used and not just a place for tourists. Sit in the window arches and 'feel' like you were there in that room and experiencing life in Morrocco.
beautiful. not outstanding. very nice to see but not super impressive unless you consider the importance of the facility.
Interesting place. Definetly in the top 3 things to visit in Marrakesh

Beautiful Andalusian-Arab architecture. As with everything in the medina, it can be a bit hard to find - but it's well worth the trouble to get there! Although the building it not very big, you can spend a long time there just looking at all the details, and if you're a photographer you'll be in heaven. It's very interesting to visit the students' rooms as well and see the contrast between their austerity and the intricate decorations of the courtyard.

Beautiful. The intrigate woodwork throughout this old koranic school is worth a visit. Absolutely beautiful You are given a guided tour whereby the guide explains everything. It is next door to the Marrakech museum so you can buy a ticket that gives you the two entrances.
Wow factor. A beautiful Koranic school with stunning courtyard and decoration
Fascinating. Really interesting place where people used to study the Koran. Amazing architecture, and you can combine your visit with the Musuem next door.

Really quite astonishing!. I counted about 190 small rooms in which some 800 students lived and studied. Goodness knows how? The architecture is also quite brilliant. It's a "must see" as far as I'm concerned.
Breath Taking. Hard to find on foot but well worth the effort. Absolutely fantastic!

Marrakech's top indoor attraction. I love Islamic architecture but all the mosques in Marrakech are barred to non-Muslims. Fortunately in Marrakech there's a religious building that is open to the public which will give you a glimpse of classic Islamic architecture and that's the Ben Youssef Medersa.A Medersa is a form of Islamic college where students go to learn the Koran. The Ali Ben Youssef Medersa was founded in the 14th Century and takes its name from the nearby Ben Youssef Mosque which in turn was named for a 12th century sultan of the same name. Most of what visitors will see today was built in the 16th century and has been renovated since the college closed back in the 1960s. On our first visit to Morrocco about 8 or 9 years ago, we were taken to see the medersa and our tour guide used it as a great way to introduce us to some of the classic elements of Islamic architecture and design. With some of that teaching still embedded in my mind – and many more visits to mosques and other Islamic religious places since then – I was pretty sure we could show my sister and her girlfriend around without needing to join a guided tour during our recent holiday.The Sunni form of Islam places a lot of very strict constraints on architects and decorators which are noticeably absent in the Shia form. Struct Sunni Islam bans the depiction of people, animals and the like and with that in mind, artisan craftsmen developed highly decorative design styles that rely on the use of geometric patterns and calligraphy. As so often happens, constraints can force creativity rather then restrict it if you're determined enough to pursue beauty. Technique include the use of tiling, painting, wood and stone carving and stuccowork, all of which are in evidence at the Ben Youssef Medersa. The layout of the Medersa is a classic example of such buildings throughout the Muslim world. There's a large central courtyard with an ablutions pool where people perform their cleansing rituals before proceeding to the high ceilinged prayer hall beyond. Down either side of this courtyard on the upper floor are a series of small 'cells' where the students lived and slept and beyond them smaller inner courtyards of tiny and very simple rooms arranged around wooden balconies. The doorways are particularly eye-catching with highly decorated arches and finely carved wooden doors hung inside them. They won't keep out the drafts but they look fabulous.The Medersa gets very busy and you'll possibly have to bite your tongue with frustration when you're lining up a lovely photograph and one of the many other tourists walks right into the middle. It takes patience to get people-free shots. If you have control over your time, try to go early in the day or late in the afternoon when fewer people are there. Go only at mid-day if you want to avoid shadows in your photos.The Medersa is open every day so don't believe anyone who tries to tell you that it isn't and lures you off to a shop or stings you for a 'private tour' of somewhere you weren't planning to go. The entrance fee is 50 dirhams but for another 10 Dirhams on top you get access to the Marrakech Museum and a strange old bathhouse on the same ticket. The bathhouse is a bit of a non-event but the Marrakech Museum is well worth the supplement.

Reverence. A beautiful museum type school, of the pupils who studied Islam and the Q'ran through history. You pay a small fee to enter and once inside are free to roam with or without a guide.The architecture is beautiful, and the main courtyard with the carved and tiled walls features in a number of guidebooks as a must-see. There is a room still set up as an example of the living-quarters of the pupils, with a small lecturn ready for the Holy Book studies which last for hours. A beautiful peaceful place to visit, and quite humbling.It is near to the Museum, and the early fist places of worship,
Stunning building. Fantastic tile & plaster work - awesome. Not to be missed - once you have found it!
Amazing place!. The architecture is absoluty attonishing! Important to visit to understand how they teach the Coran in the past.

the Medrassa Ben Youssef.. Located in the heart of the Medina ,very decorated from the inside, with ceder wood and marble, one of the old medrassas , it s minaret is 132 feet high.the area where there is a niche or the mihrab used to be a mosque for students, at the first floor small rooms for students.
Slightly overpriced. Bit pricy for Marrakech, but quite interesting once inside. Don't think I'd recommend it though.
Amazing. Enjoyed this site. Especially liked getting a glimpse of the dormitory. Our guide made the place come alive.
Koranic learning. Gorgeous place to chill, full of history and quite beautiful.
Well worth a visit.. Beautiful tiles and architecture. We didn't have a guide book and most signs were in French / Arabic so read up before you go. Still a beautiful place to wander around.

Really interesting, but still needed a quide. We visited the madersa/school on a day tour of the city with a guide (definitely recommended, but arrange for either a full or half days tour, and say what sights you want to see or visit).The entrance fee was 60dh (with 12dh to the £), so quite expensive for Morocco.There was loads to see, but you need either a good book or guide to explain the different rooms and everyday life of the students who attended the school. The mosaics, carvings and decoration were all lovely.We were told that 900 pupils attended at any one time and they all lived on site. Their rooms varied from quite large with a window and view of the courtyard to really small and dark with no window (but you needed a guide to tell you why). The Moroccans are still not very switched on to tourism so there are no leaflets, guide books or signs informing you of what exactly you are looking at. So on the whole a good guide book or guide are essential to get the most from any tourist attraction in Morocco.

Interesting history and amazingly beautiful architecture. The Ben Youssef Medersa is probably one of the more under rated attractions of Marrakech but it's definitely worth seeing both because the history behind it as a school and university is very interesting and also because it's architecture and the intricate detail used is amazing to see first hand. Also unlike other attractions, you can get away with seeing this without a guide but for a full appreciation it's probably better to go with one.
Interesting. I visited as part of a guided tour and I would recommend you visit to see all the detail of the building and to see how small these rooms were which students used to stay in.

Three for the Price of One!. For 60 dirhams you can enjoy the Medersa ben Youssef, the Museum of Marrakech and the Almoravid koubba on one ticket, ideal for an overcast day.The Medersa (madrassa) is a Merinid construction of about 1300 AD, but rebuilt during the Saadian period some two hundred years later. (same as the tombs.) It was the centre of Koranic studies. The courtyard is magnificent and the ornamental cedar ceilings are equally inspiring. Perhaps the most interesting part 'though were the two "cells" in the student dormatories - one for the "better off" the other more basic.There is a cafe associated with these attractions which is popular with visitors. Avoid however invitations to visit the tanneries at nearby Bab Debbagh.
Great example of Moroccan architecture. A must in Marrakech. It shows most of the elements of Moroccan traditional architecture and it is astonishing the Andalusian influence.Beautiful building.

A Must See In The Medina. This is the only must see sight within the medina, the courtyard is a stunning example of Moroccan design and there are a couple of hidden rooms upstairs which show how children used to study here centuries ago.Can buy a combined ticket to also see the Musee de Marrakech (which is ok but nothing special) round the corner.

Great example of Moroocan architecture. Well woth the visit. The courtyard and carvings are fantastic.In my opinion don't get the 3 monument ticket (allows you into museum and nearby ruin). Just go in to the Medersa.

Not much to see. The Medersa has a truely beautiful courtyard, but there is not much else to see and the entrance fee is definetly too high. Though not as damaged, the building has undergone a similar "restoration" as the nearby Musée de Marrakech, which is a real pitty. Visit only if you have loads of time to spare.

A fantastic building worth visiting. We paid up front for the Madrassa, Marrakech Museum and a nearby Tomb. (Sorry can't recall the name now). We found the Museum by chance and the Madrassa was a little trickier to find. It was well worth finding too. The Museum itself was small and there wasn't much to see at the nearby Tomb. The Madrassa was a fantastic building and I totally agree with the reviewer before me.

A great building, definitely worth visiting.. This building is magnificant, it takes you back centuries ago and it is hard to imagine how the youth of the day were taught in such cramped conditions.The medrassa is in the middle of the medina and it can take some finding, if you get stuck looking for it then just ask one of the shop keepers along the way, who will give you directions.The charge to get in was 50 Dirhams, it is worth the fee as it will take you out of the hussle and bussle of the medina and into another century. The tiling along the walls and the plaster decorations must have taken years to complete. If you are in Marrakech, then take a look at this Medrassa, you will not be dissappointed.

Remarkable building - medieval Oxford must have been just like this!. This really is a must see in Marrakech! Not too difficult to find if you start from the "big square", although we failed at our first attempt from Dar el Bacha.The main courtyard has beautiful decoration, but the real highlight is the student accommodation, with it's individual study rooms. Medieval Oxford must have neen just like this!Highly recommended.

Well worth a visit. 50dh entry fee so the most expensive sight we visited, but that's still only a few £ and we found it worth it. It has a lot of typical Moroccan architecture, beautiful doorways and entrances, very intricate and ornate carving work. There are toilets you may use, but I'm not sure if you need to tip.

A hidden treat. This old school is hidden away and is magically much larger on the inside. We found it very difficult to find and ended up paying a guide to lead us there. Go for the 3 attractions for 60 dirhams to get the most out of your visit.

Wonderful. The combined ticket for the 3 monuments was 60 dirhams - in my eyes worth it especially for this little gem. Loved the courtyard and student rooms, spent almost an hour here enjoying the coolness from the heat and the building. Would go back again.
Nice to see but expensive. It's a tiny version of the alhambra -or the alhambra is a big version of this- 50 dirham to get in is bit expensive, after 15 minutes I had seen all.
The school house was really charming and.... The school house was really charming and the wood work was amazing... It doesn't take long to do this but it's good if you have some spare time

an embarassing management. Medersa Ben Youssef is probably the only Koranic school still standing in Marrakech. Amazing architecture, beautiful spaces and very intricate stucco, wood and marble engravings reminiscent of the glorious days when the arab art was flourishing on both sides of Mediterranean. However, leaving the main patio and stepping into the big background alcove one can only be shocked by the poor maintenance of the building. Dirty painting, plaster falling off the walls and broken lights seem completely out of place in a monument which charges 50 Dirhams ( 5 €) per person to get in. The amount of money made from entries in just 1 day would be plenty to remiedate all these faults.Just another example of local authorities lack of initiative and laxism and a big embarassement for such an outstanding monument in such a magic city.
most beautifull medrasa. This is the most beautifull medrasa I've seen in Morocco. I visited 2 medrassas in Fes, bus this one in Marrakech is bigger and nicer. It's certainly worth a visit.

Amazing archiecture and history. It's an old school with a wonderfull architecture. We wnt with a guide and it was quite helpfull. If you're are planning to go on your own, try to read about it before you go, so you understand what you are seeing. NOT TO BE MISSED!
